Dedication

Dedicated to my parents
Philip and Leila Rosenblum, the
greatest, wisest people
I have ever known, and my children.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Acknowledgements

 

Acknowledgements to my son Moshe who put his time, sweat and tears into this book. Much of this book consists of discussions I have had with him and my son, Nachman Isaac. To my brothers David and Keith who have stood with me all the years through thick and thin. They are the greatest brothers one could have.

 

I did not originate the idea of using physics to explain the Torah. I got it from the book Genesis and the Big Bang.

 

 

 

 

 

INTRODUCTION

 

“By belief in the wise, we are able to bring our judgement to light. By belief in the wise of all the generations’, one can find the right advice for all his situations.”

-Rabbi Nachman of Breslov

 

“Nothing in this world is so powerful, as an idea whose time has come.”

-Victor Hugo

 

It is my hope that this book will show the higher root of philosophy and science and provide a basis for one unified system of science, philosophy, and Kabbalah.

 

The world is a symphony made of different instruments all playing different parts of the song that only God can hear. This symphony is “the revelation of the Oneness of God”, and the evil and cruel contribute just as much to it as the righteous and brave-for in the end darkness and evil will disappear by the light and by their disappearance God will be magnified just as much as the salvation of the good and just.

 

This applies to every person just as much as in the world at large-for in every person the good essence in every person will rise and be grafted into the holy light and the evil will fall away and vanish forever as the shadows before the light.

 

The root and basis of my path is faith -- faith in all the wise men of history, and especially the Sages of Israel. It is the conflicts between the sages themselves which force me to formulate a theory consistent with the Gemara and the later Sages as well as with history and the plain facts of science. It just happened that in the course of my studies I noticed many connections between systems that were considered to be contradictory, and many times I noticed how the questions that one system couldn't answer were answered by another. So, I decided that, perhaps, there really is no contradiction, and there is really only one great system. So here is my attempt to formulate it.

 

My motivation in writing this book was to give myself a reference book, to help me evaluate any new ideas or issues that come up, and see how they fit in the general scheme of things. My hope is that this will be a help for others also.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Section I - Philosophy and Faith

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 1 – God, the Song of God

 

Rabbi Eliyahu

The Gaon from Vilna said “there are two things about God that one always has to keep in mind; one is that he is infinitely great and beyond our understanding; the other that he is infinitely close to us.” Because of this, no matter how close we try to get to God, there are always many more ways to go. How much closer to infinity is a hundred than one? Not much. So even if we spend our lives getting closer to God from the aspect of his infinite distance, we are still far. But if we spend our lives getting close to him from the aspect of his infinite closeness, then we also can't make him much closer[1]. Since God is both infinitely close and far at once (and this is impossible to comprehend) thus the only place one can find God is really in one's heart where one feels God.

 

·

 

There is a force in the world called God.  All forces are included in Him, but He is really a separate force from the forces of nature. There are three aspects of God:

●       The spiritual level immediately above every individual level.

●       The spiritual level that is inward.

●       God as he really is--infinitely above and beyond everything.

 

When He acts, his mark is unmistakable like in the splitting of the Red Sea, or with the miracles associated with saints. But there is no way of predicting when or where He will act. He has a tendency to act in cases of prayer or trust but that isn't a rule it is just a tendency. He objects very strongly to being demanded to do anything. This is the reason the redemption didn't come during the second Temple period.

 

Even though He tends to act on behalf of those that trust in Him, that trust has to be strong enough to balance out the sins of the one trusting. One can never tell who is righteous, since a righteous person might be doing less than he could and therefore he is considered wicked; while a wicked person may be doing everything he can and therefore be considered righteous. Since force tends to act only for those who it considers to be righteous it can easily act for those that we consider to be very wicked people.

 

·

 

Spinoza's Proof of God - mathematical

The core of Spinoza's proof of God is that God includes existence in his essence and existence needs no cause because its essence is to exist (but God also has infinite attributes besides existence.) At any rate existence needs to exist only after it has some probability to exist which comes from the world of akudim which gives the wave function of the probability for the existence of the spiritual and physical universe. That probability function in itself has a cause, which has a cause etc., ad infinitum. This sequence of causes itself needs a cause etc., ad infinitum - vertically - until we get to God vertically and horizontally (ie. set of causes of the physical universe, set of causes of the spiritual universe, set of causes of the spiritual spiritual universe, etc.)  And this is the idea of God's infinite essences which are one with existence and the infinite series of causes, and the cause of the infinite series of causes, and the cause of the cause of the infinite series of causes etc. And then we are only dealing with the first type of infinity like the numbers between zero and one, or for whatever interval the universe was made in, but then we have to deal with the infinite types of infinite series of causes of the spiritual universes.

 

Spinoza, by his proof of the existence of God, wanted to avoid the problems involved with defining God as being the first cause (for who says there has to be a limit to the number of causes) He didn't want God to be the first cause at all rather existence itself (or the essence of existence). The way he avoids the opposite conclusion is by the way he defines a true idea in the treatise on human understanding. According to that work lack of existence isn't a true idea or a true essence at all. However Hegel considers BEING to contain its opposite nothingness and by the contradiction that each concept contains its opposite comes to the more refined idea of Being i.e., Becoming which is what God meant when Moses asked his name and he said “I will be that which I will be” for the name Ehyeh means “I will be” and is the name of the highest sepherah in each world crown. This means that the real idea of Being is possible to come to only after an infinite progression of dialectic. This is the reason God is so hard to touch, since it really isn't accurate to say that he is since that is only the first approximation of describing Him. He is like dx which is not nothing but is infinitely small and thus contains two opposites, being and non-being. The end of Hegel's infinite progression is what I mean above by Existence.

 

Spinoza'a proof is like the Henkin sentence which by asserting its own provability becomes provable. It has the ability to reflect on itself and thus logically proves the existence of God on the real level, not just in logic. It reaches out of itself like the strange loops that logic is filled with. Since Spinoza's system is consistent it has to reach out so to speak into another plane as all formal systems do -- just as number theory, in order to be consistent, has to postulate super numbers.

 

Spinoza's proof of God is based on the basic idea that everything that exists either is self-causing or it is not. That which is, is defined as God. Now even though there is a possibility to say everything came from a quantum fluctuation, still if in fact that and the formulas involved with its creation came into being with no cause, that would be Spinoza's “Substance” or God. Only with the entirety of the Seven axioms do we get to God being one and infinite and indivisible. So the faith of the Torah is possible to prove but only if you have faith in the seven axioms of Spinoza, which correspond to the seven lower sephirot of Royalty.

 

Spinoza's Seven Axioms:

●       Everything which exists, exists either in itself or in something else.

●       That which cannot be conceived through anything else must be conceived through itself.

●       From a given definite cause an effect necessarily follows and, on the other hand, if no definite cause be granted, it is impossible that an effect can follow.

●       The knowledge of an effect depends on and involves the knowledge of a cause.

●       Things which have nothing in common cannot be understood, the one by means of the other the conception of one does not involve the conception of the other.

●       A true idea must correspond with its ideate or object.

●       If a thing can be conceived as non-existing, its essence does not involve existence

 

Spinoza Further Detail

As to B. Russell's and Kants' criticism of Spinoza's proof of God, where they differentiate between the existence of a thing and the idea of a thing, I must mention that Spinoza deals with the true idea or the essence which isn't the same as the idea. This however doesn't disprove Kant's major thesis. You need Hegel for that.

 

Russell didn't accept the concept of a strange loop and tried to disprove it by a hierarchical method, but his principle of a self-consistent formal system without loops has been disproven. Kant and Russell couldn't accept the fact that a self-consistent formal system can be forced out of itself into a higher or lower level of existence. Thus, they couldn't accept Spinoza's proof. Spinoza does postulate cause and effect, so assuming this, would Kant say the mind causes itself? If so then it would be God by Spinoza definition, and this is apparently not the case anyway!

 

·

Idea - God is infinitely distant behind many screens

 

To use the things scientists cannot explain to prove the existence of God is not the right approach, for what will be done when science gets around to explaining these things (as has happened many times before)?

 

The only real proofs I have seen are Spinoza’s and Descartes’. But it seems that God has removed His light from the Empty Space and the closer we come to proving Him the further He recedes. So we see that after God's existence is proved logically, Kant comes around and attacks the ability of logic to prove anything. And as we reveal His presence in the empty space that He has created the further into the background he recedes. He hides himself in an infinite series of hidings, i.e. first he hides and then he hides that hiding, so that you do not know that he is hidden, then he hides that hiding, so that you don't know that he is hiding that he is hiding the hiding etc.

 

This hiding refers to the mental universe of logic and also to the physical world where God is sometimes revealed by miracles. Yet He still hides Himself further after the miraculous action. The only place one can really find God is in one's heart, for God reveals himself inside the hiding place. Only by faith can one jump over the doubts and into knowledge.

 

Regarding faith, mathematics itself is founded on faith. Von Neumann and Gödel proved the lack of a logical foundation for mathematics - disproving the basic thesis of Russell and Whitehead’s Principia Mathematica.

 

Whitehead held that a priori knowledge is possible, and the Principia Mathematica represents that belief. Von Neumann, however, disproved the premise that all math can be based on logic.

 

In the Lekutai Moharan, Rabbi Nachman hints at the Big Bang Theory. He equates the empty space with the lack of belief and says also that the more one knows God the more one realizes that they do not know. That adds up to the idea that the spiritual empty space is expanding. This would imply the same reality in the physical realm (i.e., the big bang).[2]

 

·

 

Idea - Flux of Secular/Religious Litvak/ Chasid

 

The idea that nothing exists besides God is on the level of, “He surrounds all worlds'', i.e., the circular sephirot. But on the level of the straight sephirot, in which God fills all worlds, His life energy is divided among the different levels that exist in the order of creation. That is, even though his infinite light is everywhere and nothing exists besides It, It is not manifest in the individual creations. The light that is manifest in individual creations is divided by level. So there are the sparks of holiness in everything, which keep those things existing on a manifest level. Then, there is the life force and particular holiness inside ideas and spirit, which keep those things existing, and gives to them their individual character.

 

When one concentrates on the idea of their existing, nothing exists besides God, that is when the idea has the most power. Just as matter cannot curve space unless it is in a concentrated area, in the same way, this thought cannot draw the light of God unless one really works at it.[3]

                                                    

 

 

 

Chapter 2 – The Song of Faith

 

·

Faith is a force that encompasses various forms. In scientists, it takes a hold of them, causing them to seem to understand the world; and for mystics -- the understanding of God. Devout people are guided by a different Divine trait than non-devout. So, for example, non-devout people, by trusting in God might not get their needs fulfilled unless they actually do something physical for it; whereas for devout people, they might have all their needs fulfilled through only faith. It might actually be the opposite of the Divine will for them to do something about it!

 

 

According to the Jewish viewpoint, most spiritual systems represent a valid frame of reference in the local sense, as long as they fulfill certain criteria. For Jews then, it must not deny the commandments of the Bible, and for non-Jews, the validity of the 7-Noahide laws must be maintained.

 

This idea is reflected in a certain book of a Jewish mystic who lived during the Middle Ages. He stated that it is forbidden for a Jew or Christian to convert to the other's faith since “he just mixes up the flow.” One may learn from the other’s but not convert.[4] I believe, however, that all faiths hold mistakes that should be ultimately corrected.

 

 

·

 

Today, it is actually possible to test the validity of many statements of the Sages, for they make empirically verifiable claims, i.e., certain actions causally precedes certain results. With today’s methods of statistical analysis, it would be a simple matter to conduct research on such issues.

 

·

 

I believe that religion actually has little effect on one's character – and that is even if the power of one's faith is real and sincere. The Bible is only a tool for those who want to improve. It is a guide, or map, for ones improvement in many regards, but it is not a bus to take you there.

 

The characters of good and evil are real, and religion has no effect on them. In fact, while giving those who want to be good a way to do so, it also gives those who want to simply make money, also a way to do so. And those that are evil in other ways will find a way to be aided by the religion.[5]

 

The first authorities[6] have said that one needs to combine faith and reason. The Lekutai Moharan (Volume 1, Chapter 1) also echoes this when it says that you need faith and wisdom. According to the Pardes, wisdom cannot refer to the Torah because the Torah is actually Binah in the clothing of Glory. This may be visualized as follows: one needs two sephirot revolving around each other to create radiation and to affect character.

 

·

 

One can't help but notice that religions (Torah, Buddhism, the Sutras, Christianity, Islam) generally deal a lot with how to escape from suffering and come to happiness (in this world and the next). This can be understood if you visualize the religions as occupying the 7 lower sephirot, on the y⎯axis. But once you get up above religion into the 3 higher sephirot, the air has cleared, so to speak, and we are closer to the light coming in from the upper–vertical direction. Since good and evil are represented by the x–axis, even though we may be lying above religion, we are neither good nor evil. The battle is not between good and evil but rather between truth and mistake.

 

Perhaps this explains the opinion of the Rambam that ‘the suffering of Job came because he did not learn science and philosophy.’ Although he was righteous, he didn't seek knowledge. Religion is on the level of the 7 lower sephirot which when one gets involved in automatically causes him suffering. Usually he seeks for answers in the religion, i.e., via a rabbi or a clergyman within the religion, but from a higher perspective all knowledge is one.

 

·

 

Since every person's soul is different, the laws of religion can never fit perfectly with him. Accordingly, by nature, the results of one following the laws of any religion, if applied with rigor, will then follow patterns of chaos – according to each individual. If however the laws are applied in a more loose fitting way, the affects on the person, following patterns of probability, will average out—like the binomial distribution.[7]

 

·

 

There is a basic distinction between the humanistic view and the religious: namely, the humanistic view places great value on the concept of freedom whereas the religious view does not consider it at all. The reason for this may be reflected in that the source of the religious point of view is the world–of–correction, tikun–brudim, and the source of the humanistic point of view is the world of world–points, nekudim. The ultimate correct way is to have them included in the other.[8]

 

·

 

The main problem with the worldview of religious fanatics is the vigor with which they insist just how right they are. If one of their tenets is proved to be a mistake, say through science, it is science then that has to be rejected. This can not be held consistently. Those who believe have to have a high level of cognitive dissonance going on. Rabbi Nachman says that only faith combined with knowledge is sturdy, and can not fall.

 

·

 

Every religion has two aspects to it. The first aspect is the faith or individual commitment and the search for God. This can be seen as being on the right of the y-axis. The other aspect is that of organization (which is on the left of the y-axis). Those who occupy the latter area are left brain organizers, and not right-brain creative thinkers.

 

Organized religion reflects the idea of neurons being connected in a particular way and solidified—in a way that prohibits freethinking. Paradoxically that is how Liberalism, Conservatism, Democracy,  Communism etc., have all become religions.

 

I believe, though, that if one learns enough and absorbs the learning into their deep mind and soul, the force can reach critical mass and be able to break through and produce new ideas. But most people reside on the subcritical level and thus are merely on the “religious” level — spewing out what they have heard (as Lucas wrote in 1961).

 

·

 

There exists one principle to morality and of reaching God and this is individual prayer. Each religion, when it affects those who are searching for God, is inevitably good — for the person would usually find their way to prayer. The effect of religion, however, on those not searching for God but for money or power is bad, because they try to impose their will on others and thus interfere with the harmonies.

 

·

 

There is a special method of studying that is advocated by Rabbi Nachman. The method involves reading every page forwards and backwards. To learn in this way takes tremendous faith and one sees the results only after many years.

 

·

 

One can never really change one’s religion. Religion is the accumulation of stories, songs and religious general consciousness that one gains as a child. If one “changes” his religion all he is doing in fact is silencing himself — and say the person goes into politics he might bring into the new group ideas left over from his religious mindset — ideas that don’t belong there — ideas such as the necessity of his way of life upon all (or death).

 

The Catholics were very clever when they decided to incorporate various elements in the religions that they conquered instead of banishing them. The Rabbi’s today also, should not dismiss anything of the culture of those that come to them, unless he is keenly aware of what is involved (and what are the negative, and acceptable elements in it).

 

The Rambam explains why the Torah required sacrifices. And also regarding how some of the philosophical tradition came to be incorporated in Judaism by the Sages and the Rambam was also through this means. And today, the tendency of the rabbis to take out of the Torah (through ignorance) the things that generations ago were acceptable, only leads to the destruction of Torah life.

 

It is obvious to me the grand departure from the ancient Torah way of life by the Jews was the result of the rabbis not in being able to evaluate what really was acceptable in tradition, and what (of what was new) was compatible.

 

 

Chapter 3 – The Song of Philosophy[MR1] [MR2] 

 

·

 

The ultimate purpose in the creation of the world is the revelation of the oneness of God. One central method of its accomplishment is by the universal trait of reciprocity, i.e., the idea behind “what one gives is what one receives.”

 

By the active “rewarding” of truth and goodness, and the “punishment” of evil, the oneness of God is revealed. This happens in every society, in every level of existence. This process can also be seen as the sifting out of the bad and bringing up the good to be included in the oneness of God.

 

This principle results in infinite chaos depending on any slight variation in events. How the chaos here results in the oneness there is not known in detail—an element of it may be what the sages have said: that the good suffer in this world as punishment for their sin's which they have committed in this life time or in previous life times so that when they get to the next world they can receive the undiluted light of God with their loved ones, and the end result of good being rewarded does not happen until the next world where the oneness of God is revealed.

 

·

 

Because of the compassion of God, He created the world. For he wanted to reveal His compassion, and there was no creation on whom would He have to show his compassion. Therefore he made everything from the top of Emanation to the center of the earth for this purpose,” — Lekutai Moharan

 

The idea of the creation of man is for the expression of the goodness of God. For there was a basic lack in the Divine traits before the world was created — the lack of the revelation. This may tie in with Hegel’s idea that each trait implies its opposite.

 

Another way of understanding the “lack” in each trait in itself is that as long as it is not being, it is lacking the quality of being used.[9] This understanding leads one to assume that the Divine traits  creations, but essential aspects of God. For example, to correct the two deficits of goodness and wisdom there was created the circular sephirot and the straight sephirot.

 

·

 

God created free-will so man could choose God, this by choosing good from evil, and thus have a connection with God based on ones’ own deeds and words and thoughts and desire, and not based on a free handout. To receive via a free handout is from the level of royalty, whose nature is that it must receive. This is what the problem was in the very beginning.

 

But now man has united Royalty with the higher trait represented by giving through choosing God and his reward of the light come through his own merits.[10]

 

·

 

From the idea that God fills all worlds and surrounds all worlds the idea becomes apparent that one must unite the sparks of holiness in everything with the infinite presence of God Himself by choosing God in everything he does, says, thinks, or desires, and thus uniting himself and all creation with God. When one is united with God then he too can create Godliness. This is indeed the 1st commandment in the Torah — to be fruitful and multiply, i.e., in children and ideas, and music.

 

•

 

Pleasure is on the level of the tree of knowledge of good and evil, and therefore not good or bad in itself but dependent on what one uses it for. If one brings up the sparks of holiness in that pleasure into holiness, he himself goes up and the evil falls. Just saying a blessing has nothing to do with this. It depends a lot on how he raises the children. If it's food it depends on what one does with the energy. Pleasure for the sake of pleasure remains on the original level and it falls into evil and becomes evil itself. Pleasure however for the sake of God and done with attachment to God is like a sacrifice, and is on a very holy level.

 

•

 

Allowing free thought is important for ideas need room to flow, and when restricted like in a constricted vessel, they cannot. Similarly, logic, in its purest form, also limits free thought. Revelation also limits free thought--there are things beyond the comprehension of the mind that only revelation can reveal.

 

So, reason and revelation are the two outer vessels that contain free thought; they correspond to Chaya and Yechida. Reason and revelation (i.e., the heart) should be able to work together but when there is a disagreement, then obviously one of them is wrong. Reason then reigns usually tends to win out, and the intuition or revelation is left in the spiritual universe. The dichotomy of universities and religion (reason and revelation) is the dichotomy between chaos and correction, and the goal is to bring the light of chaos into the vessels of correction. Rabbi Nachman and the Rambam disagreed whether logic is subjected to revelation or visa versa, but in fact there is no disagreement. Each has its own area where it is qualified to judge.

 

·

 

The spirit can only reveal things that are of the spirit. There is nothing but God, so He permeates and is unified with the physical and spiritual universe so God's presence in the physical universe is subject to logical proof which is what Spinoza does. But he can't go beyond that into the spiritual realm which works with mathematical principles but isn't subject to proof. That is the result of the original condensing in which God removed the revelation and proof of his presence from the empty space, and only as we progress through time does God reveal his presence and proof of his Presence one level at a time — as Rabbi Nachman comments on the empty space and relates levels of revelation to the outer makifim (fields) in which one level at a time enters humanity. So at least Spinoza got the first step.

 

·

 

“It takes many years of sifting through false teachers to find a wise one. Don't be so fast to give up the wise teachers of history for they have been sifted from millions of false ones and their teachings have stood the test of the ages.” (Greenfield). The Bible the Sutras, the Talmud, Jesus, and Socrates may seem to contradict but in fact each sees a different aspect of and points to the same truth. Each were digging up the building blocks of the final structure. (Not to say that the structure is ever finished) Some people are content to poke around the stones, and others to try to knock down someone else's stone I think it is wiser to assemble them into one great building and then to ride the elevator to the top to see further.

 

·

 

Nietzsche was a spark of Jeremiah the prophet whose root is in pure Judgment. Since he wasn't Jewish he lacked the one defining characteristic of the Jewish soul – integration, i.e., combining and integrating judgment with kindness.

 

This is how Einstein was able to combine electro-magnetism with kinematics and also was the root of his idea of combining all the four forces into one. Other examples of this are the Rambam combining revelation and reason, Spinoza combining philosophy and mathematics.

 

·

 

God is both secular and religious. On the level of the 3 highest sephirot God is secular, and on the level of the lower 7, He is religious. The constant flux between these two poles creates the wave pattern that is so characteristic of Western civilization. The Greeks and Romans were quite religious yet their thinkers were secular. The Jewish world also is characterized by the interplay between the different poles that vary with time, e.g., chasidus and the Gra, Kabbalah and legalism, Sepharadi and Ashkenazi, etc.

 

•

 

On The Nature of God and Existence

 

God contains the set of all things, the existing and the non-existing. But that is only on one plane of reality. You have to go up to the next level and there God also is and includes the set of all ideas existing and non-existing, and so on vertically.

 

Existence itself is only one characteristic of God. The hidden face where he makes himself non-existent is a result of our own hiding ourselves from him by not talking and communicating with him.

 

•

 

Idea - On the Oneness of God

 

The idea of the Oneness of God is that the creator of everything is one and not many. The idea doesn't deny that there are many things and forces in the world, but the idea of God's oneness is that the One God created everything and controls everything.

 

The idea of the Torah that: “There is nothing besides Him [God]” is that only God has true existence and everything else derives its existence from him constantly.

 

Gods being one has to mean one substance, not one quality or quantity because if He is one quality and one quantity then he is by definition already two things. When the Torah says God is one, it doesn't mean continuous since then God would be divisible. If one means indivisible -- it says that nothing exists besides God since everything is included in or part of his Godliness -- then nothing can have quality or quantity. If it means the essence of God is one, and the essence of everything is God, then to be good or evil is the exact same thing!

 

Rather it is like I said above -- the intention of the Torah is that there is a Creator and that creator is one, the one cause of existence. These arguments I got from Aristotle (in his Physics) who used them to refute the idea that all being is one.

 

Idea - Coming to Absolute Knowledge:

Rabbi Nachman held that absolute knowledge is possible only by revelation. And if one lacks that, then he can depend on faith. He held that there is some point that the human mind can't cross in order to come to absolute knowledge without faith. Rabbi Nachman believed that one can come to faith by prayer.

 

It seems that in this, Kant and Rabbi Nachman agreed -- that by pure reason, a-priori knowledge is not possible. This seems to be vindicated by Quantum Mechanics for, as in quantum mechanics, the reality we perceive is affected by our perception of it.

 

Reason then, would be needed for the clarification of revelation. It is clear that reason has a higher place than faith in Rabbi Nachman's schema, as the first chapter of the Likutei Moharan makes clear. But to come to make that final step to God, even with reason, is impossible to achieve except through  faith.

 

However, Hegel pointed out that Kant was wrong -- because he treats ideas as mental entities rather than logical entities within the set of logic space. But even if we would accept what Kant had to say, we could still show the existence of God on whatever level we are willing to concede exists. For we admit that the laws of logic work in our minds, he just asks how do we know they work in the outside world -- so he is willing to concede the existence of an outside world.

 

Now, existence must exist and nothingness cannot exist, because if nothingness would exist, then it is not nothing - i.e., you cannot say about nothing the word “is”, because if it is something then it is not nothing.

 

Now, if existence caused itself, when did it cause itself? Either before it existed or after. If before, then it couldn't have caused itself, if after - then it already existed, and needed nothing to cause it to exist. So, it must have been caused by a Creator who needed no cause to exist but exists in and of Himself.

 

Since the existence of our own logic is created by some outside cause and that cause is not in our own minds, so the basic pattern of cause and effect hasn't been created by our own minds but comes from an outside cause.

 

So, cause and effect are not a product of our own minds. The limitation to one first cause is because if there would be an infinite number of causes then you could never get to cause anything to exist now for it would have had to travel in its causes an infinite number of times -- which is impossible, for it would never get to the “now” which has a discrete place in time. Thus, there is a limit to the number of causes.

 

You can't object with Zeno's paradox that this same logic would disprove motion since causes are discrete things and you need in fact one discreet cause to cause another: while measuring the distance is something we impose on the moving ball.

 

When you get to the first cause you come to God. Thus, there is a creator and he is one. Now, since time and space may curve in on themselves, we could say that the number of causes is finite but keeps going around in a circle. But that still is not an objection since we are still thinking in a time loop going around in a larger time space.  The point is we still are reduced to cause and effect which has to have a limit.

 

Hegel limits the number of causes in a different way. From two opposite concepts he goes to a more central concept, and so on, until he gets to God by encircling Him and narrowing down the range of the circle by his system of dialectics.

 

That is actually different than my way of a long line of causes and finding God at the end. Hegel uses dialectics like a Mobius Strip which starts at one side and ends up on the other side. Thus, he limits the number of causes by encircling the first cause. Hegel considered the array of logical contradictions in logic to be like the Mobius Strip that reduce two sides to one and eventually narrows down all truth to one point. The idea of my proof is different for I am saying that Kant admitted that the Spinozian proof of God did prove Him, but only in the world of the mind and logic. What about Reality? I showed that if we admit to a world of reality besides the mind then we have to admit that at least one law works there -- that of cause and effect. And once we get to that we have proved God in the world of reality also.

 

At any rate, I am using the idea of the Strange Loop in my proof having one level refer to another level and so on till we get to God by a progression from the physical universe to the spiritual one, until we get to infinite spirituality, which again reconnects to the physical universe. This explains my idea of Free Will in the section on Happiness -- which I would call the strange Spiral. Thus, just like if we postulate that the system of natural numbers is complete, we have to assume existence of super numbers. So, if logic is complete, we have to assume the existence of a super logic. This supper logic, if we assume it is complete, we have to assume the existence of a super logic etc.

 

·

 

To Hegel, by dialect, one can come to knowledge, by an infinite progression of dialect until one comes to the Absolute. [Dialect is the process by which every logical reality is shown to be implicitly self-contradictory and thus imply the need for a new, wider category that contains them and resolves them until one comes to the Absolute Idea. So, if we take the limit as the dialect approaches infinity, we get to God.

 

Aristotle's proof of God is that even if we would believe it possible for there to be an infinite progression of causes so you could never get to the first cause, still, by that same reasoning nothing could move for it would need to go back to an infinite number of causes to finally get to move. [This seems to me to be like Zeno's paradox]. Thus, there has to be a Prime Mover. But if it were moving then it also would need a mover. Thus, the prime mover must move things without being moved itself. That is, by causing motion by attraction rather than by propulsion. Attractive causes operate on intelligences, so it is an intelligence that keeps a star in motion. So, the intelligence causes the star to move by means of its moving toward the prime mover. Now to move and not be moved, that Prime Mover must not be matter. Now, all matter have to have form but not all form needs to have matter. Thus, the prime mover is form without matter. If we substitute existence instead of motion, we get a more modern proof that works along Hegel’s lines of God being the Prime Idea that combines the opposites of Being and non-Being, i.e., Becoming — which answers the infinitesimal problem (for Becoming can only be on an infinitesimal level, one dx at a time.)

 

·

 

This is Spinoza's proof that God is one. Here Spinoza limits the Creator of each universe, physical, spiritual, spiritual of spiritual etc., [horizontally], and the first cause [vertically] to One, by the fact that only one substance can be conceived with infinite attributes. That is, there is only one First Cause of all the sets. The immediate level of spirituality above every level is referred to as God in a borrowed way, since it is the manifestation of God, but not really God, who is outside the set of all causes, but also the set of all causes and the set of all the sets of all causes, etc...

 

PROP. XIV. Besides God no substance can be granted or conceived.

 

Proof. --As God is a being absolutely infinite, of whom no essence that must exist can be denied [ God is a being absolutely infinite--that is, a substance consisting in infinite attributes, of which each expresses eternal and infinite essentiality.] [An attribute is that which the intellect perceives as constituting the essence of substance.] and he necessarily exists (by Prop. xi.) [ God, or substance, consisting of infinite attributes, of which each expresses eternal and infinite essentiality, necessarily exists.] if any substance besides God were granted it would have to be explained by some attribute of God, and thus two substances with the same attribute would exist, which (by Prop. v.) [There cannot exist in the universe two or more substances having the same nature or attribute.] is absurd therefore, besides God no substance can be granted, or consequently, be conceived. If it could be conceived, it would necessarily have to be conceived as existent, but this (by the first part of this proof) is absurd. Therefore, besides God no substance can be granted or conceived. Q.E.D.

 

Corollary I.--Clearly, therefore: 1. God is one, that is only one substance can be granted in the universe, and that substance is absolutely infinite.

 

Corollary II.--It follows: 2. That extension and thought are either attributes of God or (by Ax. i.) accidents (affections) of the attributes of God.

 

PROP. XV. Whatsoever is, is in God, and without God nothing can be, or be conceived.

 

Proof. --Besides God, no substance is granted or can be conceived (by Prop. xiv.)[By God, I mean a being absolutely infinite--that is, a substance consisting in infinite attributes, of which each expresses eternal and infinite essentiality.], that is (by Def. iii.) nothing which is in itself and is conceived through itself. But modes (by Def. v.) [Things which have nothing in common cannot be understood, the one by means of the other the conception of one does not involve the conception of the other.] can neither be, nor be conceived without substance wherefore they can only be in the divine nature and can only through it be conceived. But substances and modes form the sum total of existence (by Ax. i.), therefore, without God nothing can be, or be conceived. Q.E.D.

Rabbi Issac Luria says that the generations from Adam to Noah were evil and so were reborn at the time of the flood to receive their punishment, in this world. Similarly, the generations before the dispersion and the tower of Babylon. Similarly, the generations before the destruction of the 1st Temple. And similarly, the generations before the Holocaust.

 

·

 

The purpose of the creation of the world is the revelation of the oneness of God. This is accomplished by the trait of what one gives is what one gets. By the rewarding of good and truth and punishment of evil is revealed the oneness of God. This happens on every level, in every society, in every level of existence. This is the process of sifting out of the bad, and the bringing up of the good, in order to be included in the oneness of God.

 

The idea of the creation of man is for someone for God to do good to. There was a basic lack in the divine traits before the world was created. This lack was not in the higher traits themselves but in the Royalty (the lowest) of the Infinite one, i.e., in the revelation of the traits.

 

So, God had to create man in order to have someone to do good to: and the highest good is God himself. But, how can man have any connection with God himself!? So, God created Free Will, so that man could choose God —this by choosing good from evil — and thus have a connection with God — based on his own deeds and words, thoughts and desires — not based on a free hand-out. This is in itself on the level of Royalty, which needs to receive, and that was the problem in the 1st place. But now, man has united Royalty with the higher trait of giving, by choosing God, and not needing a free-handout to receive his reward of the light of God based upon his merits.

 

This is based on the Ramchal, together with the beginning of the Eitz Chayim, and the Lekutei Moharan — but with a bit of integration.

 

The idea is: God fills all worlds and surrounds all worlds — so one must unite the sparks of holiness in everything with the infinite presence of God himself by choosing God in everything he does, says, or thinks, or desires — and thus uniting himself and all creation with God. When one is united with God than he too can create Godliness, and this is the 1st commandment in the Torah of being fruitful and to multiply, and children and ideas, and music.

 

·

 

The contradiction between absolute knowledge and free-will is that God knows what one will choose not just from the future but from now (ie. not just because He knows the future). This contradiction is the root of Quantum Mechanics.

 

·

 

Ideas are wave functions that travel at the speed of light and have all the characteristics of a quantum wave. That's why it's important not to think about your enemies badly so that yours and theirs wave function doesn't mutually interfere and just darkness is left. Don't send your waves in that direction at all, for their waves can't bother yours at all unless you do.

 

·

 

One can combine two points of view into one by considering the combination of each point in the first and the second and drawing a line through each of them into the new space of the name 45. This is in the straight sephirot and the same can be done in the circular sephirot.

 

·

 

The uncertainty principle applies to all aspects of life and is the root of free will. For instance the conflict between freedom of thought (thinking for yourself) and listening to the wise. We find in the Torah itself this conflict, for even though we are supposed to listen to the Sanhedrin, still there is a whole section of the Torah which describes the types of sacrifice which must be brought when the Sanhedrin makes a mistake. And the Sages say that if one knew they were wrong, yet still acted on their opinion, he is responsible for his own actions.

 

·

 

Ideas rotating around a common axis will give off its rest energy and energy of motion in the form of idea waves. That is the power of the works of philosophy of Spinoza who takes a few basic axioms and revolves them around each other until a whole work evolves out of it - which represents the energy of motion - for after Spinoza was done, the idea’s implications of the axioms were fixed in idea space. However, the rest energy continues to affect a larger circumference of people.

 

·

 

The book Madregat HaAdam created a vast mass movement but disappeared in one generation. This was because it was built on one idea alone (absolute trust in God) which is a great idea but doesn't give off much energy since it rotates on its own axis, not around another major idea.

 

That is the same problem with Rav Shik's books based only on the principle that nothing exists besides God which is also good but again nothing comes of it because it is only one axiom. (Most Christian books I've seen have the same problem except for Thomas Aquines, who basically does the same thing as Spinoza.)

 

Rabbi Nachman creates in every individual chapter a revolving system, and all the systems revolve around a common set of basic axioms. I believe that the Bible and Jesus represent one revolving system (on one axis God, and the basic 13 axioms of faith) and that is the reason for their power).

 

God created the world based on two principles, chaos and order, which stem from the Divine names, 63 and 45. The purpose of creation is to integrate them and bring them up to the name 72.

 

·

 

An old philosophy paper I wrote as a teenager:

 

A.       “To examine an object pedantically is not to think. It is an examination by a specific formula which has no bearing on the idea itself. It is examination from a different viewpoint than that of the idea's maker and cannot do (accomplish) anything. It is insensitivity to the idea. It is lack of understanding. [For example] to examine myself from an entirely psychological and rational point of view is not to understand myself.

B.       “Assuming that a person's essence is always good and that he can always choose what course of action he will take, then the closer he gets to his soul, the more the soul will control his will. And the more control the soul will have over the will.

C.       Genius is a sign that one is in contact with his soul.

D.       One can understand the logic of an idea, but not its essence until he is one with the idea.

E.       The bricks of the universe are beauty, and its blueprint is God. Beauty is the substance and God is the concept. [The idea or the form in Plato's terminology].

F.         “But true thinkers think with concepts and ideas with no root either in self or words or in logic. Pure thinking is just a free interplay of concepts between the mind and the soul with only intuition used to choose the good from the bad. If the ideas truly come from the soul, then they will eventually fit into the world of logic either by the one who thought it... or the idea will die until another time to be given birth by another mind. Ideas in this form are truly logical and not just rational.

G.      Logical thinking results in a creation of value or of no value depending on the path of the logic taken by the mind. Many paths may seem logical to the mind with only one resulting in some valid result. To find that path one needs the help of the soul.

 

·

 

Zeno's proof that there is no motion is that before an object can go any distance it has to go half that distance. And before it can go that much it has to go a half of the last amount. Thus, by an infinite progression it is impossible to move since the object always has to travel an infinitesimal amount — and infinitesimal amounts can't add up since you need an infinite amount of them to add up to anything.

 

It has seemed to me in general to answer Zeno's paradox to say that space is quantized. Just like there is no time below Plank time, there is no space past a certain point. However, Calculus derives motion by reducing the distance of the motion down to an infinitely small amount and by this it derives the true equations of motion.

 

So apparently there is a reality to an infinitesimal amount in the real world? 


 

Chapter 4 – Piety

 

“Piety dies not with men; in their life and in their death it is immortal.”

-Sophocles

 

 

·

 

The contradiction of the empty space not having the light of God in it and yet the fact that there is no place empty of His presence (“for the whole earth is full of His Glory.” - Isaiah chapter 6) is the root of Quantum mechanics and the wave function becoming a particle as it is observed is parallel to the fact that God's presence is everywhere until you try to observe it, and then the laws of the empty space take over which is the root of all non-belief in God. Thus, we find that trying to get close to God has the effect of destroying a person's spirituality. In Quantum mechanics we learn, change can only happen when you aren't looking.

 

·

 

Most people's lives have one focal point or center of mass (and so it is with nations also). If it is an elliptical orbit there are two centers. But this is on different planes of spirituality, i.e., on the basic level God alone should be the center of gravity. But on the other level how can one serve or know God? So, he has to circle around the righteous one who contains the light of God in him. So even though God is everything, in another way (the level of “He fills all worlds”) He is the light inside the righteous one -- thus we find people focusing on Jesus or Rabbi Nachman or Halacha or the land of Israel etc. The right way is to concentrate on God alone and follow all these things as tools to come close to God; but not to concentrate on the tools.

 

·

 

People's lives are like sine or cosine functions so that even as they progress closer to God (the origin) the function really doesn't change — just the ups and downs get less. This is the reason everything turns into its opposite. But this is only if one doesn't progress towards the origin (God) which dampens the oscillations. (The idea that everything turns into its opposite [as the Sages said in terms of the poor becoming rich and vice versa; “There is a wheel which is turning in the world.”] only applies on the level of the lower six sephirot, not the top three, so Science and Kabbalah tend to help one to rise out of the rat race.)

 

There is the sine function for the day, week, month, year, life. There is in every person's life one peak. After that they waste the rest of their lives trying to get it back. Nothing leads to as much unhappiness as the pursuit of happiness.

 

True Enlightenment comes only once in a lifetime. As we see with Jacob that first he had a great revelation from God and a great promise on his way to Laban. Then on his way back he had to fight with God [i.e., God revealed himself again to Jacob, but this time as a man and as an enemy.]

 

And then he had years of trouble in Israel. After that he only had years of peace in Egypt. For this world is only a preparation for the next. Here one must suffer the love and wrath of God, and only then one can become a man.

 

·

 

The commandments aren't an automatic drawing of holiness. They are like functions that you have to first put in the number 0. You have to draw the holiness by love and fear of God (as per the tikkunim of Rabbi Moshe Chayim Lutzato) which come only by science and kabbalah (known to the sages by the name, “Work of Creation”, and “Divine Chariot'', which the Sages of the Talmud call a great and important thing, in relation to the Talmud which they call a small thing) as the Rambam states at the beginning of Mishneh Torah.

 

·

 

The reason you have to pray alone in a closet or in a forest is that all spiritual matter and energy are a wave attached to God; until it is observed, at which point it is a particle. Like Rabbi Nachman said that observing something makes a “vessel”, i.e., makes something have a specific place and time. It seems in the Eitz Chayim that this was caused by the original breaking of the vessels in nekudim, i.e., the original symmetry. For before that, there was no reason to think that the vessels would have fallen just by being looked at. So, it seems that in their original state they could have stayed connected to God in their wave particle form even after being looked at. But I'm not sure about this, since the breaking was apparently from too much light coming at once, which seems like a macrocosmic event along the lines of classical Physics.

 

·

 

On Nov. 19, 1619, Descartes crawled inside a large stove, and spent the day in privacy, warmth, and darkness, meditating. There he had a vision - that everything, man nature, the cosmos all work by means of Mathematical principles. That is by hiding himself he got in contact with his higher root by becoming a wave. That was right after the period of Rabbi Isaac Luria and Rabbi Joseph Karo, so Kabbalah and Halacha had been brought to their perfection and the time for science had come.

 

·

 

Although there is an absolute center of the empty space, each individual also has, in a parallel way, the level of the line of God's light in his individual direction – just as space-time manifolds have, at each point, a double-cone of light-like directions.

 

·

 

The two types of prayer are speaking with God when the light flows horizontally from the circular sephirot and praying up to God when the light flows from the straight sephirot, vertically. This is why by the graves of the righteous it is usually easier to pray since the light is vertical, while away from there one can only talk with God horizontally unless by some merit, he can draw the vertical light upon himself.

 

·

 

The reason one must pray very hard before he is answered is because the Zohar says God is hidden and revealed. Which means that there are quantum states of prayer. So just like in the atom if you put some small amount of energy into the electron, the atom acts as a whole and hides its inner workings. Only if you give it a lot of energy will the electron budge individually. Thus, it is with prayer. Sometimes to get an answer you need to put a lot of time and effort into your prayers.

 

·

 

Many sages have offered a whole range of solutions to the problems of Yidishkeit ranging from learning books of ethics and fear of God [Musar], Chassidut, Kabbalah, Hisbodedut, extreme strictness in Halachah; some have offered different ways of combining these things by doing a little of each every day. I believe that all these things are merely tools. It's like climbing a mountain: some people are given one tool, and some are given all the tools. Some are placed on an easier side of the mountain and some on a tougher side. Not any one tool will work all the time for all the people or even one person. Everything depends on the individual alone, his desire to get to the top, his stamina, his perseverance, his intelligence, and understanding how to use the tools. And even with all that he can still stick the chisel in the wrong place! (Marry the wrong person and fall to his spiritual doom -- or divorcing the wrong person), so one need's just plain help from God.

 

The proof that none of the above doctrines really work very well except for certain individuals is the adherents themselves of each doctrine. But the lack of basic human integrity on the part of the followers of each doctrine wouldn't be a disproof unless the Torah itself made integrity an fundamental part of saintliness, – as mentioned in the writings of Rabbi Sar Shalom Sharabi, the Chafetz Chayim, and the first authorities (I admit however that this logic is limited for only 1960's people cared about finding the right philosophy of life while most people just search a bit to find something which makes them content and then cease to think and get on with what they consider the more important business of money and sex and power). So even a correct principle will have only a limited effect.

The real proof against all the doctrines is the fanatical adherents who according to their principles should have found some degree of perfection! Instead, we find people divided along the old lines of character traits which don't differ at all from religion to religion. The only effect of the religion seems to be on the people as a whole - to bring them to a slightly higher (or lower or just different) level than before and on the few individuals who use the tools rightly. What matters is fear of God, and each religion simply provides one way of expressing it if it already is inside of one. Even if each religion is wrong in the eyes of the other that doesn't matter as it says in the verse “in every place they are sacrificing to My Name – (Yechezkel), even though they are in fact serving idols, since in their minds that is what God wants, God accepts their offerings as if they were sacrificing to his name. As the Sages said along similar lines, “God said to do [the commandments]; however we to them is pleasant for Him.”

 

·

 

The soul will rebel if ignored. The Jewish soul demands the Torah and the commandments. For this reason, I have had to show how Torah itself gives the freedom necessary to develop artistically or scientifically. Baalei Teshuva didn't make up the desire to be religious. It is the essential core of all Mankind.

 

Even Einstein said that the basic essence of a scientist is the desire to understand the universe and that is essentially a religious principle.  The families of those who get the religious “bug” must learn to grin and bear it for many years and still stick with him/her. In the end they will appreciate it… It is not an aberration, it is a profound instinct in man, but it can cause a lot of upsets in the family and friends.

 

Each side must learn the importance of sticking with the other for our families are not accidental. Hey are essential parts of one’s soul. Life is about accepting our family and friends for who they are and not thinking that we are going to improve anything by going elsewhere — or else life is about learning this lesson.

 

·

 

“One has to be on the same wavelength as God to receive his Word, power receivers, closeness to him by a pure lifestyle, or big antennas won't help unless you've got the right wavelength.” --Keith Moore

 

·

 

“One has to be rein trained, like power steering i.e., willing to listen to a small hint from God and not to need a big revelation or an angel to come from heaven. God sends his spirit to a person willing to obey small hints like Moses going aside to see the burning bush.” – Keith Moore

 

·

 

Meditation is the main theme of Rabbi Shneur Zalman however it is mentioned by Rabbi Nachman as the calling to God from the depths of one's heart without voice or words. The Books of musar emphasize it as “Contemplation of the Soul” of the Chovot Halevavot.

 

The Sages of the Talmud said the first Chasidim used to wait one hour before and after every prayer. Then it was asked in the Gemara, “Then for the three prayers every day it comes out to be nine hours. When did they learn anything? The Gemara answered, since they were Chasidim [i.e., pious] their learning was guarded/blessed inside of them. To the person that said “guarded” it was only guarded. To the person that said blessed, their learning was actually increased.” Now it is clear that they weren't praying or learning but meditating. [Since the main problem in meditation is the discipline needed, I suggest taking an oath to sit and do it for a certain amount of time. An oath is a powerful tool because it turns a motivation to do a good thing into a motivation not to transgress a very serious sin which is stronger. The idea of oaths was given by the Torah to help the weak of spirit. Incidentally an oath should only be taken day by day, never for more than that since, “Who knows what tomorrow may bring?”

 

·

 

The Brit Menuchah mentions that Prophecy comes from the Tzitz of the Cohen Gadol which is representative of the sepherah of the crown and comes only through the path of judgment. And this helps to answer Nietzsche’s objection to the saints of old that afflicted themselves to come to some spiritual levels. Rabbi Nachman also mentions this in Likutei Moharan, Vol. 1, Ch. 24, that the crown prevents the mind from reaching the infinite light, and thus by the hitting on the mind on the constraint of the crown are made vessels to receive the light. [It seems it works like a RLC circuit.]

 

·

 

Fear of God is the key to wisdom, but many times the fear of God of the parents results in the wisdom of the children. Other times depending on its strength it causes the person that has it to be wise. University professors will in general have religious parents which resulted in their children being wise.

 

Since Fear of God is such a key factor in wisdom and besides that we have. Rabbi Nachman's way of learning I would like to suggest a way of learning that would result in even a stupid person becoming wise:

 

(a)   Learn books of ethics and fear of God every day and keep what they say to do.

(b)  Learn the subjects you want to learn every day by just saying the words of the book in order from the beginning of the book until the end without skipping or repeats. When you finish the entire book, only then should you repeat the book again. [Sichot Haran 76] This may take years, but I think over the course of much time one will see a greater blessing in his learning than if he had learned in the regularly accepted way.

 

·

 

“Fear of God increases days”

Stanislav Kasl of Yale and Ellen Idler of Rutgers, studied 2,812 people in New Haven. They discovered that outwardly religious people, whether Jewish, Protestant or Catholic, were less likely to become medically disabled, than those who didn't attend church or synagogue.

 

A study of 454 men and 85 women in Jerusalem showed that secular [non­religious] Jews had a greater risk of heart disease than Orthodox Jews. Analysts from the University of Florida found that counties in the USA with the highest number of religious people have the lowest rates of cancer. Dr. Larson and his colleagues did a study on 400 men in Georgia, found that people that believed in God and attended religious services had the lowest readings of blood pressure.

 

Those that had one or the other had higher levels. Those with neither had the highest readings. Dr. Larson and his team also reviewed more than 200 studies on religious commitment and mental health and found that religious people have lower rates of depression, alcoholism, suicide, and drug use than non-religious people. Young people who are religious also do better in school and are less likely to be sexually active. Married people that are religious reported greater marital happiness, more satisfaction with their sex lives and lower rates of divorce.

 

The researchers examined specific concrete behavior like attending services, not just abstract belief. [From the book Age Erasers for Men by Doug Dollemore Rodale Books, Pennsylvania, 1994]. This certainly doesn't seem like Saint Frances of Assisi who held that you can't live a lifestyle of peace and own material possessions and still be called a Christian at all. However, I think fear of God has to be entered into with a willingness to do what is required regardless of the consequences — but the end result in general is that of peace and happiness. We find Haran burned even though Abraham was saved because Abraham was willing to be thrown in the furnace regardless of the consequences. Thus, was saved. Haran was willing to be thrown in only because he thought he would be saved.

 

·

 

Since the Jewish people do not have the surrounding light of the circular sephirot their only evil is in community actions [actions that can be ascribed only to the community at large] like acquiescence to evil that their leaders and rabbis do, but individually they are righteous. That is why punishment comes upon them usually as a group as in the Holocaust, but individually their fear of God brings them blessing physically mentally and financially and in their children. The Christians on the other hand are collectively righteous as in America while individually they are usually coarse Goyim. [This is why Christian Evangelists can do miracles only in large groups where all the collective prayers and faith join together to draw the soul of Jesus, while individual Jewish saints generally can do only private miracles.] This is the reason why the Jewish people can't make a nation at peace even within itself much less with the Arab world surrounding it since they lack that outer light. This is the intention of the prophets when they prophesied that the Jewish people would have bad leaders as a result of their sins, i.e., the prophets saw the outer light would be taken from them and replaced by klipot so that the actions of the Jewish people as a whole would be evil though individually each person would be righteous. This is also the intent of the Zohar when it refers to “Rabbis that are Jewish demons”. And this is the intent of the Sages when they blame the world’s problems on the Jewish leaders and rabbis of each generation. They aren't engaged in hyperbole but a statement of fact.

 

·

 

The relation between mitzvoth and prayer to physical deeds is parallel to the relation between logic and revelation which is parallel to the relation between trusting in God and action. Saints went to one side of the spectrum and philosophers went to the other. The path of the Rambam was to defer to logic when there was a difference between Reason and Revelation. It is my opinion that revelation [the Crown] is the main thing and Reason [Wisdom] is only to understand and apply revelation to real life situations. Thus, it comes out according to this that trust in God is the main thing and action is secondary. Thus, people from the different faiths that chose separation from this world as the proper path would be going according to this logic, and in fact it seems that their great devotion to God resulted in their gaining some kind of closeness with him [Baba Sali or Saint Frances of Assisi]. I have heard that Rav Sonnenfeild from Jerusalem decided as a young man that he would take the first match offered to him and thus he did depending on God divine providence that she would be the right one. And in fact, they had a long happy marriage. Yet I would agree with that only in conjunction with the advice of George Fox of then taking advice from one's family. This would be in accordance with the principle of the sephirah of the Crown first [trust], then reason [Wisdom].

 

 

·

 

The Rambam's writes, “Consequently he who wishes to reach perfection, must first study Logic, and then the different parts of Mathematics in their right order, then physics, then Metaphysics (what today we call philosophy) -- [The Guide I:34]. Then when God sees that your spiritual vessels are ready, He will shine his light on you [The Guide III:52].

 

However, he says in connection with prophecy, that even after proper preparation, there is no guarantee that He will give you prophecy for the Rambam held that intuition is like IQ — it is a naturally born power, of which some people have more and some less — but everyone has to some degree [The Guide II:32 and 38].

 

He held the prophets increased this faculty by learning. The Rambam obviously held that there is a point that what is internalized in the mind becomes part of the spirit — similar to Hegel. However, I think that by meditation, which corresponds to the level of the Crown, one can increase his degree of intuition and awareness of God's will. The fact that the Rambam held the gift of prophecy to be a naturally-born thing, which God adds to if one merits, explains why the Jewish sages in the past that don't seem to have meditated, merited to great spiritual levels.

 

But it is also possible that they did meditate, for the unifications of the Ari and Rabbi Abulafia are clearly in thought (not speech) though some of them can be spoken — but not many.

 

The Rambam wrote in the Guide and Mishna Torah that one needs to learn Torah first in order to know the laws of conduct — however, he also writes in the beginning of Mishna Torah that work contains the entire Oral Law and one needs only to learn the First Testament and the Mishna Torah and nothing else.

 

Also, he writes that the Mishna Torah is for the great and the small (i.e., average intelligence). This suffices to answer those who try to avoid the Rambam's point of learning science and philosophy — by making the study of the Torah longer and harder than it has to be.

 

He specifically holds that there was written a code of Jewish law and only for special reasons were non-halachic opinions added, but theoretically, just a simple halachic book was all that was needed. So even if there are opinions not like the Rambam, it would be sufficient to add them to the Mishna Torah, and not spend all one's life learning that which the Rambam held was almost a waste of time.

 

The Rambam isn't alone in this, for there is also the Duties of the Heart that held that going into halachic matters that don't concern one is a complete waste of time and one rather should learn science and philosophy to come to love and fear of God.

 

In general, I have noticed that modern day Orthodox Judaism is a totally different religion than that of the Rambam, and the other Jewish Sages of the Medieval period. To me, that seems ironic, for they claim that the other Jews have gone off the path.

 

It seems that orthodox Judaism has been on a downward-spiral for some time to take the spirituality out of religion. If you'll notice in Hamlet, that Hamlet felt that since in his prayer he hadn't succeed to connect with God, that it wasn't really a prayer. Shakespeare’s whole attitude towards that is that this was in fact the case, for he considers it ironic that he was spared by seeming to pray.

 

So, we see a general attitude that trying to pray isn't necessarily praying, but in orthodox Judaism all the prayers are exactly like that, and if one even attempts to put a little extra into his prayers, he is looked down upon and all the more so if he tries to pray with the intentions of the Kabbalah.

 

[Nowadays, Orthodoxy has become an anti-spiritual movement].

 

Historically, I believe we can trace a long progression of Orthodox Judaism attempting to take spirituality out of the Torah. No longer is God a weighty subject in Judaism. Now it is the Laws [halacha] for the orthodox, or social justice for the Reform — but God simply has become a concept that is mentioned for the sake of lip service.

 

Thus, we see that the Sanhedrin in the days of Moses tried to convict him for being a false prophet [Korach and the heads of the Sanhedrin as Rashi says]. Thus, we find the Torah establishment of David's time siding with Saul — as the Gemara Shabbat explains [Doeg was the head of the Sanhedrin]. Thus, we find most of the rabbis of the Rambam's time trying to excommunicate him, and thus we find the rabbis of later times condemning the Kabbalah. In all these cases a generation has to go by, and sometimes much more, until the truth is accepted — but by then it is sterilized, so as to become non-effective.

 

Now, all of them are considered great, but their teachings are ignored when they aren't politically correct.  Physical mitzvot, to the Rambam, are to provide an environment for spiritual growth, but do not cause it.

 

Physical actions can in no way stimulate internal growth. If knowing lots of laws makes one spiritual, then Big Blue the computer is more spiritual than all the rabbis together!

 

In yeshivot, it is the accepted way to delve deeply into every word and letter of the Rambam. I wonder when they will get around to delving into the exact meaning of “Consequently he who wishes to reach perfection, must first study Logic, then the different parts of Mathematics in their right order, then Physics, then Metaphysics”! — and be exacting in every word and every letter.

 

·

 

It is a very worthwhile experience not to get your prayers answered so that you realize that your prayers and trusting on God and your good deeds can't cause God to do your will. This is the case no matter how powerful and deep your prayers are. It is a big ego trip to think that with your prayers you can force him to do your will. Trust and prayer are good things when done with the right viewpoint - that God will do what he knows to be the right thing no matter what. But prayer also can help but only sometimes.

 

·

 

There are two ways of approaching tolerance:

 

a)      Perhaps tolerance is not a virtue in itself, but what is wrong with the orthodox is that they forget that the Torah says don't add to the commandments, and they keep closing the bubble more and more until there is no room to breathe.  (They, of course don't keep these standards. They just sin and repent afterwards. But the conventions are useful in that they provide a way of oppressing everyone else.) Besides that, they are intolerant of behavior outside of their conventions, which have nothing to do with the Torah and many times contradict the Torah. But even the non-religious recognize an outer limit for the bubble. The good thing about the non-religious is that they have an outer limit and inner limit and so have a pretty good idea of where to put the limits of behavior. The religious, however, don't recognize that an inner limit can exist, and they get stricter and make the bubble smaller and smaller until they condense into the Swartzchild radius of a black hole from which there is no escape unless, like me, you just come out the other side. (That is why they and Greek Orthodox wear black clothes to warn people that they represent a spiritual black hole.)

b)     Another approach is that tolerance is a virtue in itself and that God Himself has different standards for every person and that even God himself loves tolerance and allows a person a wide range of opportunity to choose his own behavior within certain limits that apply that person's soul.

 

However, I think there really is not one border-line but two. There is an outer and an inner limit different for every person, but they fall into a binomial pattern so that the Torah can state certain basic behavior patterns that are acceptable.

 

And, besides this, there is a great interval between the limits where free will and opportunity exist for growth. The difference between the areas is the gray area is where tolerance applies, and the white area is simply permitted.

 

·

 

The rule is that teachers of morality can't be moral in people's eyes. God will always cause a situation to arise where they will seem not moral. This is for the sake of free-will. Also, it makes it indistinguishable between hypocrites and sincere teachers which also is necessary for free will.

 

·

 

There is a very basic difference between the Rambam's idea of morality and ethics and the general religious view. To the general view it is doing what the Torah says. This view I have ascribed to in much of this book. But, to the Rambam the criteria is Reason.

 

The Torah is only to teach us what reason requires. I think ethics is this principle: doing those actions [or words or thoughts] that are in accord with reason and the heart. [I think this way was also the Rambam’s intent though he didn't express it as such.] Thus, there is a certain criteria of reason that if the heart disagrees it means that one's reason is wrong. There is here a basic question for the nature of the standards is different.

 

The traditional way of looking at the laws of the Torah or morality in general is that it is some standard rule of conduct, and that theoretically there is some infinite or finite set of rules for all situations. The Rambam's way is that there is no external set of rules, only internal rules within each person's heart and mind that we may be unaware of because of the physicality of the body that causes us not to hear our minds or heart.

 

Thus, there comes a sign to know if someone actually is going to Gan Eden after they pass away or not. If they have no conscience, i.e., no pangs of guilt when they cause some type of emotional pain or otherwise to another person, that is a sign they are completely out of touch with their heart and mind or that their inner heart and mind have left them and thus they will not go to the light afterwards. This is the rational explanation of the Ari who said that by anger one loses his soul [i.e., heart and mind]. If they actually have a tendency to hurt others when the opportunity presents itself, and there is no external constraint, they are evil and go to hell. The reason they do this is because they assert only their rights, not others, and thus come from the breaking of the vessels from which the kelipot came. In Correction all the vessels are together but retain their individual characteristics. By means of that, the higher light is drawn on them. Good people come from that world.

 

Now we also see that there are different levels of the soul [heart-mind] that react to different types of sin or lack of good deeds or right knowledge. But we can't differentiate by the five levels of the Kabbalah since they are horizontal levels, rather we have to differentiate vertically as Rabbi Sar Shalom Sharabi did. So, the nefesh of each level [i.e., nefesh of nefesh or nefesh of ruach etc...] reacts to bad deeds by guilty feelings or feels an inner emptiness when there is a lack of good deeds. The foundation of  nefesh reacts to sexual sin. Kindness of nefesh reacts to kindness, i.e., giving or not giving - but judgment of nefesh reacts to cruel deeds.

 

It is a different subject to the soul. The nefesh of ruach reacts to the inner spiritual levels of the physical deed. Ruach of each level reacts to bad words in the above manner. Neshamah of each level reacts to emotion, i.e., feeling good about feeling love [i.e., the Strange Loop again or what I call the Strange Spiral that goes to infinity], and feeling guilty about feelings of anger. Chaya is for the mind [feeling good about gaining knowledge] and Yechidah is for the soul of the soul, the archetype soul.

 

[TO THE RASHASH THE MITZVOT ARE THE INNER GARMENTS OF LIGHT, THE CHARACTER IS THE GARMENTS OF SKIN OF THE SOUL. HE ALSO DIVIDES THE CHARACTER INTO FOUR MAIN PARTS.

 

From bottom to top it is humility, silence, despising pleasures of the body, constant happiness in one’s portion. The evil traits are: pride, talking for no purpose, desire, depression...

 

The reason desire is evil is two things. One this is only talking about kelipat noga so it is only evil if one's intention isn't toward God.
