The other reason is that sexual desire in itself is directed towards all females and thus is a manifestation of the spirit of the species as to increasing the quantity of the species, not the quality. [This idea is from Schopenhauer]. The reason that is evil is that simple continuation is kelipat noga, only going up and improvement relative to one's present position is good.

 

·

 

For mitzvot that you don't feel light from you will not get any reward in the next world therefrom. There really is not all that much difference between here and there. So, if you don’t feel any light then believe me, there isn't any. This is why the Torah only promises good in this world for doing the mitzvot. Since the next world is not dependent on mitzvoth, only this world is. However, if you feel the light then in all likelihood you are on the right track for there too. However, since getting there is such a fragile thing it is worth it to have a guarantee. So, this is why it is worth it to get to the grave of Rabbi Nachman, say the ten psalms and give a penny for charity, in which case he promised he would take that person that does this out of hell, an unpleasant place by all accounts.

 

·

 

It is forbidden to change one’s religion since it is impossible to get the spiritual blessing except from the root one was born from as already mentioned by the kabbalists from the Middle Ages. But there is another reason, i.e., that religion is the images and stories embedded into one's consciousness when he is young. One can never change that, nor is it desirable to. One can always stick with his own religion and just take out the things that are forbidden. True religion isn't a bunch of rules, it is a way to approach God. And that can only be done with the totality of one's consciousness.

 

·

 

Fear of God is being aware of the presence of God and fearing Him. It is not the same thing as faith. Faith is Royalty and fear is Judgment [and the higher fear {awe} is Wisdom]. Fear is not the same thing as being strict in observing commandments. In fact, the original idea of Chasidut was that there is nothing besides God, and that therefore it is possible to serve God with everything and through everything as long as serving God is one's intention. It was the first 1960's, where sex and fun and spirituality was all possible in one package. There is no question that there was much illicit sex at the beginning of Chasidut [as the affidavits signed in Vilna testify to], and for this reason the Gra went against the idea that there is nothing but God until Reb Chayim of Voloshin [his disciple] came and agreed with it, but explained it in a way that would not contradict the law and thus this idea came part of the body of accepted doctrine of the Torah. However, to be fair the original doctrine of Chasidut was not to go against Halacha but rather to be as lenient as possible since fear of God has nothing to do with being strict.

 

The idea of chassidus as taken by people in general was do what you want and intend it for God and that is accepted by God as Divine service [as long as you don't do evil] since there is nothing besides God and everything is God. It was “Serve God by having fun,” [i.e., serve God with joy/fun].

 

This wasn't appreciated by the Gra and most rabbis. When they would go on the street and ask the youth why are you behaving so wildly the answer wasn't ‘Go to hell,’ but rather, “This is our Divine service.” Giving a spiritual motive to have fun was unappreciated by the Gra. To a degree this was rightly so since just like the Flower Children of the 60s’ deteriorated into the Yuppies of the 70s’, so the movement of chassidus reversed its polarity from super spiritual to super material until today it is the worship of money and power.

 

·

 

One of the benefits of there being religious people even though they are jerks is that the gate into holiness would be closed by the klipot completely if they weren't standing in the door. So even though the religious are themselves an obstacle to the service of God still they benefit us by keeping the door open.

 

·

 

There is a normal distribution of how many people [Jewish, Christian, etc] can or should be religious. This is because there are ten sephirot and the sepherah of piety is Judgement. The orthodox are Judgement, which is 10% of all Jews [However, a recent study shows the orthodox are about 7% of American Jews.] The Rashi that explains that people should not try to keep all the mitzvot [because if they would, then no one would merit to the next world] was written for those people who are not allowed to be religious, for being religious isn't their root and it is forbidden for them to try to be religious and it would hurt them spiritually if they would try.

 

·

 

The Gemara in Macot 24A says, ‘Rabbi Simlai expounded:

613 commandments were said to Moses...

·      [King] David came and established them on 11...

·      Isaiah came and established them on 6...

·      Micah came and established them on 3....

·      Isaiah then established them on 2...

·      Amos came and established them on 1…

 

Rashi writes, “[…] Established them on 11.” For, at first people were righteous and could bear the yoke of many commandments, but the later generations were not so righteous and if they would try to keep them all no one would merit. So, David came and established them on 11.”

 

Rashi is clear. However, the other first authorities explain this Gemarah differently. Now, to show you that I am not making up my own explanation of Rashi, look at the Marsha who says on this Rashi, “the question is famous,” and then he brings the explanation of another first authority. However, this doesn't detract from the fact that Rashi wrote what he wrote. This does show however that even the Marsha understood Rashi as saying what it is obvious what he is saying.

 

Isn't it clear that Rashi knew the verses of the Torah that say the Mitzvot are forever? Obviously, yes. So, we must say that Rashi held those verses apply only to the specific commandment that the verse is referring to there, e.g., if the Torah says the two loaves or the Shabbat are forever then we know that those mitzvot are eternal. But why doesn't it say this by other mitzvot? It must be that the other mitzvot are not eternal. [Otherwise, why say it by some and not others? And the verse in Haazinu [Deut. 29:28] says to do all the words of the Torah forever, but not to do mitzvot that were given only for a certain time period forever. For instance, if a person would sit in a sukkah on chanukah, he would not have a mitzvah. If you do a mitzvah after its time period is over, you also have no mitzvah. So, in Rashi's explanation, King David said the time to keep the mitzvot that were not eternal is over. But he was not referring to mitzvot like the Shabbat, which are. It seems to me that the Mitzvot mentioned in connection with the land of Israel are eternal since the Torah gives them in order that we should inherit the land of Israel forever.

 

Now there is a difference of opinion if the commandments are a goal in themselves. If we take the Baal HaTanya's point of view, then one way to resolve that Rashi, except to say that the Baal HaTanya must hold like the other Rishonim that explain that Gemara differently. However, the perush on the Rambam explains that lower fear of God [fear of punishment] is to bring one to the mitzvot and the mitzvot are to bring one to the higher fear [awe of God]. According to this Rashi it comes out well. For since the commandments are specifically to bring one to awe of God and King David [and the later prophets] saw that in their generation the mitzvot did not cause awe of God. Perhaps that caused him to realize the time period was over.

 

·

 

The Baal Shem Tov was given by the Messiah three things to do, and three unifications - that if people would do them, the Messiah would come. I would like to take a guess as to what they might be based on the things that the Baal Shem Tov himself was careful in, i.e.:

1)     Mikvah

2)     Praying at sunrise

3)     Learning in the way of just saying the words quickly and without repeating anything.

 

I would guess the things to learn would be the four categories that the Arizal said to learn every day, i.e., the Bible, Halacha, Gemara, Kabbalah. (The Rambam held that science is in the category of Gemara. So, this turns out to be the Bible, Halacha, Science, Kabbalah.

 

The three unifications I would guess are the names 72,42 and 12.

 

 

Chapter 5 - Happiness

“Life without pleasure is impossible.” – Thomas Aquinas

 

·

 

Happiness is the result of motion upward or inward, which depends on one's upward or inward energy. Some people have only upward energy, and some have energy that drives them inward. But there is a law of conservation of energy which results in the law of conservation of happiness. Only a certain amount of happiness is granted to one. But by association with others, one reaches a state of equilibrium with them. If they are unhappy then eventually one’s happiness gets dissipated by them. But by prayer, learning Torah and Wisdom, and kindness you can draw more from God (but you can't create it yourself). Each of these (or any service connected with the ten Divine sephirot), draws with it, when done in connection with God, a certain light and happiness related to its own sepherah and also brings with it a special physical blessing, e.g., kindness brings love into one's life, sexual purity brings sex (i.e. not to have sex in a wrong way tends to bring sex in the right way). A result of this law is that great pleasure and great pain always come together so that the equilibrium will be preserved. An example of this is the Kennedy family.

 

·

 

There is another conservation law of spiritual energy, that if you spend it on one thing you won't have it for something else; so, choose wisely. Try to spend it on things that will draw further energy from the Source, i.e., good deeds. [Using one's spiritual energy is what Rabbi Nachman means by praying with strength. Yet, because of the law of conservation of spiritual energy, one should be careful how he uses it and conserve it for important things and not use it all up on small things].

 

·

 

Rabbi Nachman says that it is always an important commandment to be happy [in God]. So, if you have a doubt about if you should do something or not, i.e., if it's God's will or not, then look at the happiness factor. If it's there, then it's God's will. [I think that the translation from Rabbi Nachman's Yiddish into the Hebrew aphorism that “It is a great mitzvah to be happy always”, is a mistranslation for there is no such mitzvah. Rather he meant, “It is always a great mitzvah to be happy”- i.e., to be happy and rejoice in the Lord.

 

The Gemarah in Avoda Zara asks on the contradiction between the verses in Kohelet, where King Solomon praises happiness in one and puts it down in the other… It answers that happiness in God is a good thing, happiness not in God is not. The reason for this is that happiness is klipat noga [the tree of knowledge of good and evil], so when it is in God it becomes included in holiness and the bad in it falls away. But depression is from the three totally evil klipot. Therefore any depression is evil.

 

·

 

Now you could ask about Mozart and Beethoven or artists in general where it seems a bit of unhappiness stirred and inspired their best creations. On one level you can answer that their experiences were unhappy, not their attitude. Also, Rabbi Shneur Zalman explained that judgements come from a higher source than blessings so when one stays attached to God in the long run the judgements turn into the highest blessings.

 

“Nothing that is vast enters into the life of mortals without a curse.” -Sophocles.

 

Heisenberg was embarrassed at his oral exam for his P.H.D. when he didn't know how to work out the resolution of a microscope, and he had to go and re-learn it. When the next year he developed Matrix Mechanics [or quantum mechanics] the subject of resolution became a powerful tool to show the truth of the uncertainty principle.

 

There was a young woman accused of communists ties and her reputation ruined and almost lost her job. She went to the president of the company to ask him to stick up for her. He took an interest in her and besides helping her keep her job he married her. She became the first lady of the USA, the wife of President George Bush.

 

·

 

Aristotle had a basic philosophy of happiness that I would like to write down in summary form in order to show the logical basis for why it is important to keep the mitzvot.

 

Socrates said, “An unexamined life is not worth living.” Aristotle said, “An unplanned life is not worth examining”. He held that one has to have a plan. But not any plan will do. He held that there is only one right plan. If one lives by the wrong plan, he will not have a good life. Now there are things we do just to live. But there are other things we do in order to live well, i.e., achieve happiness and enrich our lives. But we live in order to live well, i.e., to have happiness. Who could say that they don't want happiness? Happiness is the highest goal. People are happy because they have what they want. Yet we all have different wants. But in truth though we want different things, living well is really the same for us all.

 

There are things that we want and things that we need. The need for food and the need for knowledge are human needs. Some things we want aren't good for us but things we need are always good for us. The need for food we feel but there are other needs that we don't feel so readily. The one right plan for living is to seek and acquire the things that are really good for us, the things we need to live and the things we need to live well. Thus, happiness is really the same for everybody. It is to acquire the things that are really good for us to have.

 

These are external needs of the body and internal needs of the mind. The mind by reason of its nature needs to know. Thus there are the goods of the mind such as knowledge and skills and especially the skill of thinking.

 

There is also the need of the heart to love and be loved. Also there is the need for self-esteem and honor if it is honor for the right reasons. [I believe there is also a human need for freedom.]

 

There is also another kind of need, the need of the soul for good habits or virtues, i.e., the habit of choosing the virtuous thing without having to go through a difficult process every time a situation comes up: as in temperance and courage.

 

The reason God gave us the Torah is to teach us the virtues of the mind [right opinions] and of the soul and good habits, i.e., to receive the needs of the body and soul.

 

Now there is another need that Aristotle didn't mention and that is the need to work for a goal. Every human being has this, as Victor Frankel said [I think from Nietzsche], “Give a man a reason to live and he will find the how to live.”

 

But this is, in a sense, included in Aristotle since happiness is a constant process of acquiring more things than one needs. The needs of the body are finite, but the need of the soul is infinite, since the soul needs God — and acquiring more knowledge of God or his works is an infinite process. At any rate, happiness is the feeling one gets from movement upwards or inward as I wrote before.

 

But just any goal isn't enough. It has to be the right goal. The right goal — Aristotle has already explained — is to get our needs met. Thus, it seems we have circular reasoning [The Strange Loop].

 

The answer to this, however, is that Man [as a society and also individual men] need to work as an upward spiral [The Strange Spiral].

 

First getting the physical needs met, then the emotional, then the mental and then spiritual. But each individual may have a particular need which he feels more strongly than the others — and thus some people work on the spiritual at the expense of the physical. The reason for this is that this spiral is usually for the community as a whole. Some people work on one need and others on another but in the whole society everyone benefits.

 

Free-will is when a person has the choice of determining whether he wants to work on a higher or lower need. Thus, a need can be evil if a person can work on a higher need and instead chooses the lower one, or it can be neither good nor evil if one is only able to work on it alone, or it can be good if a person has to choose between it and a lower need.

 

The idea of the Strange Loop is that a system that refers to itself must be incomplete, like the electron that acts on itself. The whole creation on every level is filled with the strange. The reason is, I think, like Hegel saw, they drive us toward a higher level. So, the puzzle of Quantum Mechanics that physicists to this day cannot figure out is not an isolated phenomenon, but part of the mathematical reality of Creation.

 

Gödel's theorem shows there is a fundamental limitation to any formal self-consistent system that refers to itself. In fact, Hofstadter pointed out that any understanding of the human mind will force us to accept “causes that propagate both upwards and downwards in the Tangled Hierarchy of mentality....”

 

Incidentally the Lekutai Moharan of Rabbi Nachman is also filled with these loops as Rabbi Nathan pointed out, like sexual purity and prayer depending one on the other, etc. There is a way to get the infinite spirals of logic to converge by means of the idea of the improper integral that converges, i.e., if we could find the formula for any one of these spirals we could see if they can converge to a definite sum by integrating them.

 

Now this is related to politics in the following way: Living in a good society is necessary for happiness because the plan and organization of a society can be helpful to attain this happiness (or a hindrance, as I have mentioned). Not all forms of government are good for this goal. The type of government necessary for happiness is a democracy, since the government that is good helps the people achieve happiness.

 

Thus, the Torah gives the people the prerogative to appoint a King. A government that serves the bureaucracy is not a good government. Since people are created with equality, all should have an equal chance to advance themselves - not just those that are part of the government. A government is not good that treats equals as unequal's and gives unfair advantage to one person over another by free hand outs to one group or another. The real goods that we need, like virtue and courage, are largely dependent on our individual decisions. The government should not tax one group to give to another, for that is not treating people equally. Only in the case of deprivation, that some people suffer because of some misfortune not in their power to control, should the government help. The State can only supply the conditions of peace necessary for happiness, but it can't make people happy, or even be sure that the people will make the right decisions. To expect the government to do more is to invite tyranny. However, there must be a body of judges to counterbalance the effect of the democracy since in any free society there is a class of unskilled labor that are going to feel disenfranchised financially and in other ways by the establishment and who feel they have nothing to lose by disrupting the system, so they become anti­-morality since they feel morality is simply to serve the rich. They feel they have a right to other people's money. This class can become powerful enough to destroy the society and thus the Torah supports a balanced system.

 

This disagrees with Hegel in that the study of history isn't just a way of coming to the right government or coming to freedom. However, Hegel’s idea is rooted in Kabbalah and especially that of Rabbi Shneur Zalman that the combining of Tohu and Tikun leads to them coming up to and being included in the Name 63 which is the root of Freedom. Thus, the plan of the Torah is to create a space for each individual where they can grow and keep the mitzvot and not be infringed upon by society at large, and yet still be a part of the whole. I think the level after that is to come to the name 72 which is happiness or attachment with God which is higher than freedom. [The fact that the human being has needs of the spirit not just of the body is one reason Marx's material dialectics is mistaken. Hegel at least had the intelligence to see the motivating force of history is the quest of the Spirit for freedom [the name 63] but I believe that there is a level after that of Attachment with God [the name 72] which is a need of the soul.

 

·

                                                                        

The Baal Shem Tov Quoted Rav Saadiyah Gaon as saying, “It is proper for a person to desire all physical things for from thence he will come to desire Torah and the service of God.” This goes along with the Rambam in Moreh Nevuchim that one who is feeling down should sit among the “Lovely forms” and listen to music. [This gave some people at the beginning of the movement of Chasidut to be somewhat promiscuous.] But this is clearly the idea of serving God by everything since there is nothing besides God and everything is God, and there is no evil in the world at all.

 

 

 

 

Chapter 6 – Reward and Punishment

 

·

 

Doing the mitzvot physically only brings physical blessing as the Torah says, “I will give rain in its season”. Only doing the spiritual essence of the mitzvot brings spiritual blessing and enlightenment.

 

·

 

“Blest are they whose days have not tasted of evil. For when a house hath once been shaken from heave, there the curse fails nevermore, passing from life to life… by folly in speech, and frenzy at the heart. Evil seems good to him whose mind the God draws to mischief; and but for the briefest space doth he fare free of woe.” - Sophocles in Antigone (i.e., any person with judgements upon them tends to do evil things almost against their will just so that the evil judgements will have something to come upon.)

 

·

 

Rabbi Issac Luria says that the generations from Adam to Noah who were evil were reborn at the time of the flood to receive their punishment in this world. They were 600,000 root souls. The generations before the dispersion and the tower of Babylon were those same souls and had sinned during that ten-generation period. Similarly, the generations before the destruction of the 1st Temple. And similarly, the generations before the Holocaust. And in the opinion of Rabbi Luria even if one was sinful in a prior life, once born again, he won't suffer for those sins if he lives properly. As the Zohar says about Job -- he wouldn't have suffered if he had brought peace offerings (parts of which are divided amongst the poor) instead of burnt offerings. This is even though he was Terach (who was an idolator) in a previous life. And that is why Rabbi Luria also says that he wouldn't have suffered if he had gone to Abraham to learn the ways of loving kindness. If we go by the opinion of Rabbi Luria, we will have to conclude that being religious isn't the same as being righteous for Job was religious, but he wasn't concerned enough about the poor to be righteous. In Hebrew, this is the difference between being righteous and being a saint.

 

·

 

If you knew all that you need then you wouldn't have free will. So, God makes sure you don't. Your true character can be revealed only when you don't know all the facts about your situation and how your actions affect events, and you must decide anyway how to act. But when one correctly knows the situation then he has no free will, and thus no reward and punishment and is just a clay in the hands of the artisan. But still the revealing of the traits doesn't happen in his way. And the free will was made for there to be the revealing of one's character traits. However even those totally in Yiddishkeit or Jesus or science, God seems to make sure that many things ever that are not known which can easily be seen by others so that there should still be free will in these things.

 

·

 

People's impression that big things happen in their lives because of very small things is true as the formula:

 

 tells us, i.e., that a small variation between certain numbers can cause substantial changes. But eventually one comes down from the world of chaos into the world of probability where things average out into a nice binomial function - farther from the light but closer to the vessels that can hold whatever light one may have.

 

·

 

The reason there is suffering before each new level of wisdom is that the sephirot of Akudim before they reach a higher level must turn their backs to face upward, so the higher light comes through their backs. Then, as they reach the higher level, they turn around again to face forward to us and there is a higher revelation of light but during the time they were rising there was only the backward light (red shifted).

 

·

 

There have been people that accomplished great good in the world yet suffered enormously as a result of it. This is because the higher light comes dressed in judgements.

 

·

 

Nietzsche held that according to the Bible, God saves the righteous, period. No ‘ifs’, ‘ands’ or ‘buts’. Yet I have a way of answering for the Sages. [The opinion of the Sages is that God rewards those who have a majority [in quality] of sin with good things in this world and punishes their sins in the next. This is to reward them for their good deeds in a temporary world. The reason is because if they are mainly sinful God gives them their main reward in the world which is the main and most important, i.e., the next world. Those that have a majority of good deeds God rewards them in the next world for their good deeds and punishes them here for their bad deeds. Thus, one who is mainly good will suffer unless he has no sin at all. Now this is certainly in accord with Genesis - but I would like to say that it also goes along with the rest of the Torah. For, the places in the Torah where it guarantees reward for good deeds is always in plural and referring to the Jewish people as a whole. So, it only is saying if the 51% of the people are good, then 51% will have good. They might be 49% of the bad and 2% of the good who will have good. At any rate in this world the evil people succeed and have money, children, and happiness. Yet, God gives good to the righteous eventually by preserving them, even if it is in a lowly way and by raising their horn [honor and happiness in the end.]

 

·

 

If the majority of one's deeds are good, he is rewarded in the Gan Eden of Earth by the light of God shining upon him here and punished for his bad deeds in this life by bad events. If the majority of one's deeds are evil, he will be punished in hell and here on Earth have physical comfort. However, for good words one is rewarded in the lower Gan Eden and punished for his bad words in this world if the majority of his words are good in quantity and quality. If the majority are lies or evil talk, he is punished in hell and rewarded for his good words here. If the majority of his thoughts and feelings are good, then he is rewarded for them in the higher Gan Eden.

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 7 – Eras of Man

 

“Not only the body, but also the soul whose habits, tempers, opinions, desires, pleasures, fears never remain the same… and this is equally true of knowledge… not only do the sciences in general spring up and decay… but each of them individually experiences a like change.”

-Plato Symposium

 

·

 

MANKIND PROGRESSED DOWNWARD THROUGH TIME. UNTIL JESUS WAS HIT AT THE ORIGIN. Then we came out to the other side continuing in the same direction but now progressing towards the light instead of away.

 

·

 

“At the time of dusk there will be light.” The Zohar explained that this refers to the 272 years before the 6th millennium of the Hebrew calendar which comes out to be the year 1968.

 

·

 

During the 6th 1000-year period there was a flow on the level of Foundation which is from 1240 until 2240. (3760 B.C. is the beginning of the 1st thousand.) This would explain the flow of wisdom since then. And the Rambam's saying in the letter to Yemen that prophesy would start then.

 

·

 

This is leading up to the 7th thousand-year period starting 2240. This is similar to the 1st thousand were to draw from the previous “Sabbath” on thousand years while our period is to draw from the coming thousand-year period.

 

•

 

Every hundred years is a blessing in a different field as a part of the process of the redemption of mankind.

●       1400-1500 was art.

●       From 1500 to 1600 was the Reformation.

●       From 1600 to 1700 was Mathematics Philosophy.

●       From 1700 - 1800 was Music.

●       From 1850 - 1950 was invention.

●       1900 - 2000 was Physics.

 

[an art-religion-science -philosophy cycle.]

 

This doesn't mean that at the end of the period the blessing has to stop. It can continue but not in the same way as a massive overflowing. This refers to the circular sephirot of the non-Jews whose spiritual redemption started from Jesus. But the Jewish hundred-year periods start on the forty-year mark.

 

Thus:

·      1240-1340 - Royalty - [the writings of Abulafia and the other Kabbalists].

·      1340-1440 - Foundation.

·      1440-1540 - Splendor - which is a time of judgement and thus was the expulsion from Spain.

·      1540-1640 – Victory – Kabbalah - Rabbi Issac Ashkenazi and Spinoza who proved God and discovered the logical proofs of the system of the Torah. (However, since he was excommunicated, it hasn't been used as such).

·      1640-1740 Torah-Beauty - The Ramchal, the Gra and the Baal Shem Tov, Rabbi Yaakov Abuchatzera and Rabbi Shalom Sharabi - all the sages of Torah that all Torah (learning and keeping) until today is based on.

·      1740-1840 – Judgement - the fall of the Jewish people away from the Torah yet still there was the counter force of Rabbi Nachman and the other great sages that continued the different movements mentioned above.

·      1840-1940 – Kindness - return to Israel (Royalty) and emigration to America (Foundation).

·      1940-2040 - Understanding - This implies the awakening of judgements (the Holocaust), freedom [i.e., the 1960s], and Understanding itself.

·      2040-3040 - Wisdom.

·      3040-4040 - Crown. [The implication of all this is that World War III should start around 2010 which is Understanding of Understanding.] 

·       

 

·

 

In the 1960's there existed the wisdom to understand that the establishment needed to be either reformed or thrown out (that's the disagreement between “The Greening of America” and Ayn Rand. But there was also in the air the rebellion against parents. This danger doesn't exist now because in the air there is all the talk about strengthening the family. But this talk didn't exist then. The children of today's children will have the same test since time is circular. How can we make sure the coming 1960s will not decay into the yuppie 1970's? and not be a rebellion against all moral values, rather than just against false ones. The answer is the basis (religion) must be strong- but not fanatical; just solid. We need a religious and philosophic basis for the world. That is knowledge of the Bible and the Talmud and the great philosophers, and religious giants of history like Buddha, the Gita, Jesus, Rabbi Nachman, etc. We need to bring the Bible back to the world.

 

·

 

The problem with the hippies was that they needed to provide a viable alternative to the establishment, which really doesn't exist. Their economic ideal of communism has shown itself to be a non-workable option. Their major benefit was to shake things up so that reform within the system could take place, which wouldn't have happened without them. They made the reduction of the cold war to be the goal. Although President Reagan accomplished it in a way they would not have agreed with; but at least it stopped. Without that the world would at some point been destroyed a couple times over. They accomplished reform in education so that the education of the 60s was individually oriented.

 

·

 

At the time of the destruction of the first Temple, the secrets of the Torah went into exile and were scattered all over the world. That is why Pythagoras, Buddha, Plato, Socrates and so many other spiritual and intellectual giants appeared on the scene at that point.

 

·

 

There have to be two protagonists in every generation, each correct and true - but from the opposing worlds of Chaos and Correction, and therefore in conflict with each other:

●       Einstein and Heisenberg

●       The Baal Shem Tov and the Gra

●       Dr. Spock and Dr Vincent Peal (The Power of positive Thinking), Plato and Aristotle, Hillel and Shamai. But this is only after the house of King David was split for before that there was power in the righteous[tikun the sephirot of correction] to contain the two opposites [i.e., the light of correction and of chaos, freedom].

 

·

 

The Talmud says that in the year 6000 (2240 in the English calendar) God will destroy the world, people will fly on wings 1000 years and then in the year 7000 there will be the revival of the dead and a renewal of this world. Perhaps the wings the Talmud refers to are spacecraft? [Is it possible we will live on other planets? I have heard that perhaps travel faster than light is possible if done like the traveling of energy in a rope that isn’t shaken up and down so that the energy travels in waves but rather pulled so that the energy travels in a faster way.]

 

·

 

People haven't traveled back to us in time yet because to the Shemita opinion time comes in layers and the future layers haven't come yet into existence (the future doesn't yet exist.)

 

·

 

Mankind goes through harmonic motion (something like ). Similarly, each nation and individual. That is why this century has had accelerated harmonic motion with the progress of democracy and freedom; yet also world wars and depressions. I would suggest that A isn't a constant but gets smaller with time, so the harmonic motion gets more accentuated.

 

I don't think accepting Jesus would have saved the Jewish nation at the second Temple period because if so, it should have done so for the Roman empire 300 years later. Yet we see the Roman Empire disintegrated into nothing starting immediately after they accepted Jesus. Thus, it seems to me that the events surrounding Jesus were as planned. According to the translation of Wise and Eisen that is in fact exactly what the prophet Isaiah if fact predicted. But it is likely that the destruction would have taken a less violent turn - as with the Romans the destruction of the nation meant dissolving the political unity, not the mass destruction of the people as it did for the Jewish people at the time of the destruction of the Temple.

 

·

 

If we go by Hegel’s idea of religion and philosophy, I think we should be entering on a new age of religion that will be an improvement from the last ages for this coming one will include each religion retaining its identity yet integrating the good aspects of others.

 

·

 

Abraham gave to his seven children from the later wives “presents” and sent them to the East. I think this is the Vedic knowledge.

 

The Indus-Saraswati civilization had undergone decay from natural disasters. The arrival of the Vedic people around 1700-1500 BC right after the life of Abraham [which was at the beginning of the second millennium BC] was a rejuvenation — for they brought with them the teachings of Abraham.

 

This explains to me the fact of their strong monotheistic traditions though they still have idolatry and other dualistic traditions. I think this may explain from where they got the idea of meditation which I think is a well-established principle in all religious thought, yet clearly the East got it much before the West.

 

If it wasn't from Abraham, then clearly it must have been from some spiritual giant.

 

Even Judaism today doesn't compare with it, for Judaism has become an anti­spiritual religion by its strictest adherents and obviously it must at least be able to lend itself to an anti-spiritual interpretation. While the Vedas are the most spiritual books that exist in terms of their search for enlightenment and not being able to take anything less as a substitute, even prayer, good deeds, study or even meditation. The Vedas can lend themselves to idolatry but certainly not to anti­spirituality.

 

·

 

One's place in the world is largely determined by the place one has in the large events of each of the ten sephirot. For, like in Math there is a constant progression upward and it is the job of the mathematician to add more bricks to the building of knowledge, not just to understand it, thus it is with all the ten sephirot. Thus

 

Torah [Beauty]

Music [Judgment]

Mathematics

Philosophy

Politics

 

 

Advanced Math

 

Democracy

Kabbalah

Romantic

Calculus

Rational

The State 

Gemarah

Classical

Trigonometry

Aristotle

Feudalism

Mishna

Renaissance

Algebra

Plato

Empire

Bible

Medieval

Geometry

Socrates

Monarchy

 

 

There are in each group [and there are many more groups] periods of blackholes when no progress is made. Sometimes progress is horizontal and sometimes it is vertical. Horizontal progress is also important since it adds to the base.

 

Chapter 8 – The Redemption

 

      “Is there any point to which you would wish to draw my attention?”

      “To the curious incident of the dog in the night-time.”

      “The dog did nothing in the night-time.”

      “That was the curious incident,” remarked Sherlock Holmes.

 

“Everything is dependent on Kabbalah. Our lack of involvement with it causes the delay of the building of the Temple.” “…and when we will repent on this and occupy ourselves with this wisdom (Kabbalah), the Jewish people will be redeemed.” (-Rabbi Chayim Vital in Introduction of the Eitz Chayim.) Rabbi Moshe Chayim Lutzato writes along the same lines in the Pri Eitz Chayim.

 

INTRODUCTION

 

The redemption is one of the most painful subjects. All Israel expected the Messiah to come at the end of the second Temple period and deliver them from the Romans. This was correct to expect, since the prophets that predicted the destruction of the First Temple clearly imply that when the Second would be built that the Messiah would then come then, and that it would last forever. Well — that prediction proved wrong.

 

Then, after its destruction they were expecting Bar Kochba to deliver them — that also didn't work. Then there were predictions in the Gemara that proposed some dates within a hundred years. Then the First Authorities placed their predictions for a hundred years after their time. Then, we got an assortment of saints that tried to bring the Geulah themselves and all failed. Then, Chabad got into the Messiah business and in fact made a lot of money doing so.

 

·

 

The Messiah revealed the same idea to the Baal Shem Tov in his vision on Rosh HaShanah when the Baal Shem Tov asked “when will you come?” He answered “By this you will know: when your wells will overflow and they will be able to do unifications and rise to higher worlds like you, then will be a time of grace and salvation. “The teachings of the Baal Shem Tov to a large degree are contained in the books of his disciples. Rabbi Nachman never claimed that his teachings stemmed from them but in fact Rabbi Nachman gives the handles by which it is possible for every person to hold on to the lessons of the Baal Shem Tov.

 

The Baal HaTanya created a different path which I consider to be valid but certainly not related to Chasidut. For example, the Baal HaTanya deemphasized the importance of the “rebbi” which the Besht held was essential. Also, the Besht gave the path of when one sees a beautiful girl to raise the trait of Beauty to its higher root, which the Baal Hatanya dismissed for people in general. The idea of “There is nothing besides God” of the Baal Hatanya is also different from the Besht. To the Besht it is like Shankara, i.e., literally nothing but God. Everything is God. There is nothing but his infinite Light. But to the Baal Hatanya everything is “as if it is nothing and nullified like a ray of light in the sun.” There is a whole book in the Yeshivat HaKotel which goes further into the discrepancy between the idea of the Oneness of God of the Besht and the Baal Hatanya which I just skimmed over. What I wrote is from my own understanding of this, but that book went much deeper. The other things I mentioned are in some article in the Library of Hebrew University.]

 

·

 

 

Doing the unifications of the Ari means to go to a quiet place and to concentrate on God and his Divine names. It is the same idea as the meditation of the Bhagavad Gita except that the Gita just talks about concentrating on the Oneness of God while the unifications of the Ari give vessels to contain the light in.

 

·

 

However, you may ask, doesn't this apply only to higher souls and people who have filled themselves with the Talmud and legal authorities? Rabbi Chayim Vital writes in the introduction to the Eitz Chayim, “The dull person who can't understand the Talmud after having tried it should leave it and learn only Kabbalah,  however a smart person is required for one or two hours a day to the study of Halacha and to intend to answer the questions that fall upon the Halacha, and afterwards he should intend to dress the bride - which is the Wisdom of the Kabbalah.” The Ramchal writes along the same lines in his books. The age of forty for Kabbalah isn't mentioned by any major authorities and only brought as an anonymous “some people say” in the Shach. However, the Rambam does say to be filled with Talmudic learning before learning Kabbalah which, the Shelah HaKadosh says, means to fill yourself with Talmudic learning “that day”, before you learn Kabbalah.

 

·

 

According to Rabbi Chayim Vital, the redemption depends on Kabbalah (the secrets of the Torah), not chasidut, not Musar, not Halacha, not Gemara, etc. Others have different answers to bring the redemption. Nothing has helped and still the redemption isn't here and still the sole and single advice of Rabbi Chayim Vital isn't done. He wrote that 500 years ago and it's still not done. All the Musar and Chassidus and Halacha haven't helped. Maybe Kabbalah is dangerous but nothing else has done better. And still the one simple piece of advice of Rabbi Chayim Vital isn't done - learn Kabbalah all day and the redemption will come. If we don’t it’s clear that the redemption won't come (this section refers to the spiritual redemption not the political one even though they are in fact closely related for no matter how much political progress is made if it isn't coupled with God, it has little worth as America is proving so well nowadays as it rapidly sinks into totalitarianism).

 

As to the idea of drawing the light of that coming period closer which problem is on the mind of many, I have a few suggestions:

1.)   In the book Heichal HaBracha it says the author heard from a great Kabbalist that finding the Ark of the Covenant and putting it in its proper place on the temple mount would bring the final redemption immediately. The Ark is buried somewhere deep beneath the surface.

2.)   Rav Acha son of Rava said God will renew this world after the year 5000 (in the Hebrew calendar), i.e., 1240 A.D. (Sanhedrin 97b). (Rabbi A. Abulafia was born Rosh HaShanah of that year) (Khan took Kiev that year and was well on his way to severely shake up all Christendom and the Islamic empires and China. His progress was halted in (of all places) the land of Israel! It is interesting to note that the Rambam writes that prophecy would be restored to Israel at that time. It seems to me that Rav Acha was referring to the emergence of the Renaissance and the Kabbalah at that period.

3.)   Rabbi Eliezer said the days of the Messiah will be 40 years (Sanhedrin 99a). If we go by the 6000 year opinion that means Messiah will come in the year 2200 AD., [about 200 years from now].

4.)   Rabbi Chiya son of Aba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan, “all the prophets prophesied only for the days of the Messiah, but as for the next world no ‘eye has seen it’, and this disagrees with Shmuel for Shmuel said, “there is no difference between this world and the days of the messiah except for enslavement of Israel to the nations.” Shmuel is saying that all the prophecies of the Bible about the days of the Messiah are referring to the time of the revival of the dead and don’t refer to this world at all at any point. [That is the same spiritual realm where the stories of Rabbah Bar Bar Chanah took place.]

This is clearly the intention of the Gemara which says that Rabbi Yochanan and Shmuel disagree. This would mean that the Temple and the gathering of the exiles all refer to the higher realm. This would correspond the prophecies of Yechezkeil that the return from the Babylonian exile was the final redemption and that in the higher spiritual plane there already exists the Temple and all the souls of Israel are in the higher land of Israel. This would answer the question on Rav Hillel for the prophecies that took place after Hezkia the King were referring to the higher world. This would explain the Zohar that the Gates of the Higher and Lower Wisdom would be opened up in the year 5600 (about 1840) by which time all the major saints of the Jewish people were gone, e.g., Rabbi Nachman, the Baal Hatanya, Rabbi Yaakov Abuchatzaira etc. Rather the intention is that in this lower world the Gates of the Lower Wisdom and in the higher world the gates of the Higher Wisdom would be opened up.

5.)   Rabbi Dosa said the days of the Messiah would be 400 years which puts it at the year 1840, which is the beginning of the Age of Invention.

6.)   Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said, 365 years, which puts it around the birth of Albert Einstein and Rabbi Israel Abuchatzera.

7.)   Rav Hillel says, “There will be no Messiah for Israel, for they already enjoyed it [that period] in the days of Chezkia” (Sanhedrin 99-A).

8.)   “The redemption of Israel will be like the rising of the sun” [Midrash], i.e., slowly but surely, and during that period it gets so light that you think the sun will rise in a minute when in reality it is still very far away. And by the time the sun really is ready to rise it is already so bright that it is almost irrelevant if you can see the sun or not. When the whole world will be filled with the brightness and glory of God then I will know that messiah is near. Until then I will just have to wait.

 

·

                   

Since in every level of creation there are two Strange Loops: one that takes one up and the other that takes one down to the lower level [like the double helix of the DNA], thus, to come to the redemption one needs to find the Strange Loop for the present level. But the present level consists of ten sephirot.

 

For instance, the religious level has this strange loop that the more you get into it the more you find it implies Jesus, but Jesus in the New Testament said things contradictory to the Torah, at least on the face of it. But then again, he said keep the whole Torah with exactitude. This works for all saints also. Like getting involved with the Gra or Rabbi Nachman will inevitably lead to self-contradictions. This may seem to lead in circles but in fact they lead to the next higher level.

 

 

Chapter 9 – On Learning Torah

 

·

 

It is clear that the Torah puts learning on a higher level than doing good deeds. The actual idea is that deeds create the vessels to receive the light. Since all Israel in their higher root are one, if someone whose root is from the world of Action is available to do the good deed and create the vessel, it's better for one whose root is in learning to sit and learn and to draw the light. The philosophy of the Torah puts learning Torah above prayer. The way to explain Rabbi Nachman is that speaking with God in a personal way isn't the same thing as prayer, rather it is fulfilling the command of being attached to God which is higher than Torah, prayer and good deeds and it is the light of the name 72.

 

·

 

In learning Torah, or all learning in general, it's best to speak out the words quickly and to say them in order with no repeats or interruptions. Only when one has finished the whole book should he then to go back and review it (as Rabbi Nachman said). It's also helpful to say the words forward and backwards [i.e., to go to the end of the page and then to go backwards] as is clear in the Annulment of Judgements of the Baal Shem Tov HaKadosh and in the unifications of Rabbi Luria to remove bad spirits in the Shaar Ruach Hakodesh and in the corrections of Rabbi Yehudah HaCHasid and the reason this helps is stated in the Tikunim HaChadashim of the Ramchal and the Eitz Chayim of Rabbi Luria.

 

[I have also found it useful for me to learn lying down on my back for light books and on my stomach with the book on a lower surface for heavy books]. Rabbi Nachman noticed an important part of human intelligence: its unique ability to see over-all patterns. This is largely a subconscious process — and thus Rabbi Nachman knew that the main absorption of learning is simply by reading — whether one is aware of his understanding or not.

 

This is dependent however on the type of light contained in what one is learning. For Hebrew only contains inner light. The outer surrounding-light of Hebrew was lost and has gone into other languages. Thus, for instance, only people that learn the Bible in English get a feeling of the story line and the inner ideas contained in the outer light. Another example is for instance the simple meaning of the words “love your neighbor like yourself,” which has an impact in English of actual love while in Hebrew the feeling of it is more like a slogan. Fearing God or loving God are the same, for in Hebrew the connotation is more like going to the minyan or not turning on a light on Shabbat, while in English it means loving God. 

 

·

 

Rabbi Lutzato hints to the idea that Torah only has power when said forwards and backwards. The Baal Hatanya explains the root in holiness of non-Hebrew letters in Torah Or (and a hint to this is found in Rabbi Abulafia) and therefore the same principle applies when learning whether in Hebrew or not.

 

·

 

The true value of learning Torah is only when the intention is to serve God, not to become a rabbi or use it make a living. When it is learned with the wrong intention, it of necessity leads one to the wrong conclusions. Rabbis nowadays can only be rabbis if they have learned the laws of how to kill animals and taken tests to show that they know that subject well. Therefore, they have used their Torah knowledge to get a piece of paper that would qualify them for a position to make money. Therefore, they have learned at least some Torah for the intent of making money. Therefore, in general it is forbidden to ask a rabbi for guidance since that guidance will be incorrect. [This fact is hinted to in the Talmud (Shabbat 139a), that all the troubles of the world come only because of the judges of Israel).

 

·

 

8: is the Kabbalah the Zohar. The continuation downward would be the later kabbalists.

 

13: In the the Rambam's system this would be Philosophy. [The Ramchal would not agree this, and he in fact disagrees with this whole system anyway which only holds according to the Rashash's interpretation of the Ari.] 

 

14: Biology of animals and plants.

 

15: Chemistry.

 

16: Physics.

 

17: Mathematics.

 

18: Talmud. [the light of the Talmud is continues vertically downward by the commentators]

 

24: Mishna [the continuation is by the legal authorities: the Rif, the Rambam, the Rosh, the Tur, Shulchan Aruch.

 

[I don't know what the other parts represent. We can't add them later because we are on a different level. They can’t be the Tosephta since it is an “outside” writing from the circular sephirot. The lost masechtot would seem to be logical].

 

27: Bible.

 

28: Targum.

 

 

One class from each one of the main four categories should be learned each day. For instance: learn the Bible, then a class in halachah, then one in Talmud or science, and then one in Kabbalah.

 

The Books which come from Beauty of Atzilut are Sipurai Maasiot [Crown], Tanya [Wisdom], Noam Elimelech [Understanding], Likutai Moharan, Sefer HaMidot [six middle sephirot] [Malchut]. [This is only to the Rambam and Chovot Halevavot ]

 

This next diagram is a close up of physicality of beauty (zeir anpin):

†

 

 

 

c: Crown. There is the root of the five books of Moses

w: Wisdom

k: Kindness.

v: Victory.

u: Understanding.

p: Power.

s: Splendor.

 

In these right and left hand sephirot are located the roots of the prophets.

 

k: knowledge

b: beauty

f: foundation

 

In those middle three sephirot are located the roots of the sacred writings [like the psalms proverbs, etc]. The next diagram is a closeup of Formation of Royalty

 

 

The middle three “pbk” [power, beauty, kindness] are the root of the three parts of the Mishna Seeds, Times and Women. The lower three are the roots of the three other parts Damages, Sacrifices, and Purity. By learning the mishnayot Seeds one draws the light of the name mlp la pla from the top four vessels into the vessel of kindness. By learning tractate Times, one draws from the light of the name myhla into the vessel of Power. The tractate Women draw the light of the name tvabe into the vessels of Beauty. By learning Damages, one draws the light of the name laa into the vessel of Victory. Learning the tractate Sacrifices one draws the light of the name myhla yhla hla laa into the vessel of Splendor.

 

Purity draws the light of yds into the vessel of Foundation.

 

 

 

So, the entire Talmud is only the Talmud of the Nefesh [lowest level of the soul], not the spirit or the soul

 

The reason the Talmud is incomplete is that the souls of the Amoraim [rabbis of the Talmud] were from Beauty of Emanation, from the time before Zeir Anpin was completed – i.e., the Anshei Keneset Hagedola were from knowledge of Father coming down and the kabbalists of that period were from the same level but going up… the Tanaim were from the six lower sephirot of Zeir Anpin coming down and the kabalists among them were from the same level but going up.

 

All the above is on the level of Emanation but for the generality of the four worlds it is thus;            

 

 

Kabbalah

Talmud

Mishnah

Bible

Kabbalah [Emanation]

Kabbalah of Kabbalah

Talmud of Kabbalah

Mishnah of Kabbalah

Bible of Kabbalah

Talmud [Creation]

Kabbala of Talmud

Talmud of Talmud

Mishnah of Talmud

Bible of Talmud

Mishnah [Formation]

Kabbalah o Mishnah

Talmud of Mishnah

Mishnah of Mishnah

Bible of Mishnah

Bible [Space-Time]

Kabbalah of the Bible

Talmud of the Bible

Mishnah of the Bible

Bible of Bible

 

 

as it says in the beginning of Shaar Ruach HaKodesh. Here again [as I noted in the chapter Ideas in Science], we have the diagonal such that we only have the trace the things from the top left to the bottom right.

 

 

·

 

Every level of Torah has a different inner light and meaning. Kabbalah is only the inner meaning of Torah horizontally, not vertically. This is obvious from books like the Nefesh HaChayim which says that the innerness of the words of prayer is in the letters themselves not in the kabalistic intentions. Also, the fact that the Torah says only a third verse can explain contradictions and not any outside explanation means that the Torah is postulating an inner meaning to itself in itself, not in the Oral law (since no outside explanations are permitted). Soloke in number theory if it is consistent, it must be incomplete. So, inside the Torah there must be a super-Torah. So, I postulate that the system of Torah in the above diagram from the Rashash continues downwards [and upwards.]    

 

 

·

 

“To come to the truth of science and Kabbalah is possible by prayer. One should especially concentrate in the blessing Ahavah Raba before the Shema and in the blessing ‘give knowledge’, in Shemone Esre.” -from Reb Shemelke of Nickolsburg.

 

 

·

 

My theory of learning is thus: When one gets up in the morning he is in a relaxed state of mind. In my opinion this state is the only time any real learning can be done. Talking with anyone or even saying ‘hello’ causes a break in the neuron connection that causes any learning done after that to not be absorbed — for we see that some things we learn and forget after some time. Yet other things stick inside one permanently. Therefore, all real learning has to be done in the morning.

 

[The Baal Shem Tov hinted to this, for he had a tradition from Achia HaShiloni that the day one has anger in the morning he won't be able to learn anything after that.]

 

·

 

There are many things in the yidishkeit [the practice of the Torah that theoretically prescribe one way but in practice is otherwise. Sometimes, the reason is that a person was created in a certain way such that the theory doesn't apply to him. For instance; theoretically, I think it is clear from the Zohar that Tikun Chatzot is more important than vesikin. However, I believe for many people the need for Vesikin outweighs that of Chatzot because of their particular type of soul.

 

This may apply also to living in Israel where clearly it it a great thing to all opinions even to the Rambam; however, there are hidden things that cause it not to be a mitzva.

 

In fact, nothing in the Torah can you really know is a mitzva until you really know what is going on in the hidden things. Just judging based on knowledge of the halacha is worse than not knowing at all — for when one knows nothing then he may follow his heart. If you ask then, why was the Torah given. The answer is to teach us to go into our hearts to find God and give us the basic principles that are really in our hearts and minds but from which we have become estranged.

 

This is the Rambam's opinion that all the commandments are really based on reason and their force comes from the fact that they are already in our heart, not because they are written. This applies to learning. For, in theory one should learn slowly and review and not go further until he gets what he is learning now. But in fact, in practice, it is better not to do it in that way. The reason is that is the climbing way from the lower sepherah to the higher one step by step. But since faith is connected to the crown, if one simply has faith and learns simply, he comes to the highest knowledge, the knowledge that is higher than knowledge the crown. This is signified by the way books are set up. For as one reads from the top of the page to the bottom, he is going through the sephirot that are containing in the inner logic of the book. Then as he returns, he has effectively gone from crown to faith and back and this is absorbed into his soul. [I think one should each day learn only the amount he has set for himself to learn day by day, no more and no less].

 

·

 

Learning doesn't make one spiritual. All the above mentioned spiritual levels are only on the level of the spirit not the soul. Developing of one's spiritual self is by prayer and meditation. One needs learning to provide the vessels to contain the light of prayer and meditation, and one needs good deeds to contain the light of learning. However, the drawing of the light is specifically by silent thought. Action draws the nefesh; words of Torah draw the spirit, and quiet thought draws the soul. This is something the Ari alluded to when he said that unifications are higher than Torah [Saint Frances of Assisi also mentioned this fact].

                                                                  

·

 

Rabbi Nachman's way of learning is just to read the words out loud, and to do a little bit every day of each book one needs to learn — and if you do it in order and over the course of many years you will have completed at least once all of the books of Science, Math, Kabbalah, Halacha, etc. And in the end, you will understand much better than if you had labored over every point. But you can only succeed in this if you have faith in Rabbi Nachman, since only by faith will you have the stubbornness to continue this for many years before seeing results.] 

 

There is a hint in the Torah that just by wanting to learn and understand one does merit to it. For the work of the Tabernacle could be done only by the wise in heart as it says several places in Exodus. And in Exodus 36:2 it says, “every person wise in heart whom the Lord put wisdom in his heart, everyone whose heart stirred him up to come close to the work to do it.” Thus, we see that God put wisdom into the hearts of those who wanted to do the work.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 10 – Gemarah – The Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmud’s

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

·

 

There are different ways to understand the Talmud. There is the looking-to-be strict way and there is the looking-to-be lenient way. Both are valid (i.e., some people learn to find ways of being stricter and some to be less strict — and both are valid because as the Talmud says, “God said to do, so no matter how we do it, it’s ok with Him.” — as long as one is trying to do the right thing.

 

·

 

I would like to add that actually there are millions of valid ways to learn the Talmud. To give some examples there is the going deeper and deeper into its infinite logic, and there is doing the same with Rashi and Tosphot. But there is also going into the length and breath as the commentaries tend to do. Then there is the Kabbalistic way and the Halachic way. The halachic way is divided between the Rambam who didn't assume all the Talmud has to have one parallel line of thought and the other authorities who held that it did. (They held one place can't disagree with another based on the “stame de gemara” — but the Rambam didn't agree, because that is for the original compilation of Rav Nachman Bar Issac, not the final version of Rav Ashi and Ravina who collected all the pieces). There is also the way of Reb Chaim to find the deeper principles. I had my own way for a while to find all the conflicting principles in every subject and reduce them down to one final principle, but I never finished it.

 

·

 

My model of the Gemarah is not open from the outside (like the non-religious), but open from the inside, — i.e., to go into the deeper dimensions. So instead of the flat way, I want to open up the 4th dimension of the Talmud so that everything it says should be invariant only if you look at it from the spiritual way, not the flat way.

 

·

 

The Oral Law was written down during the second Temple period in documents of the Scribes (professional rabbis), the ultra-orthodox (the Prushim) and the Essenes. After the destruction of the Temple, the long arduous process of collecting, sorting out and arranging the discussions and decisions in the countless documents and oral traditions before the Yeshivot in Babylon and Israel began. The Talmud is a work of the genius of many generations after the destruction, compiling and evaluating the laws handed down by those groups. Therefore, the Talmud itself doesn't present a question on Jesus since it was meant to collect the traditions at the time of its writing and not as Divine knowledge. It is a work of genius, but it is still influenced by the time period it was created which was extremely isolationist in its point of view because of the Bar Kochba incident. The purpose in the stories is, as all the history written at that time, meant to instruct values and morals, not as historical facts.

 

·

 

The Oral Law Torah existed as documents that the Pharisees, Scribes, and Essences had in written form [as seen in the tractates of the scribes and in the Dead Sea scrolls, which represent a body of writings from all the Jewish groups that lived then including the Jews that believed in Jesus. However, those writings have been suppressed by the Catholic Church since they contradict their ideas which are based on Paul].

 

·

 

The Rambam held openly that the only part of the Talmud that is actually a direct tradition from Mount Sinai are the parts where the Gemarah says or assumes that something is Biblical law. The Kabbalah says the Gemarah is from Royalty of Emanation which means it came from a flow of wisdom from that sepherah like Newton received a flow of wisdom from the realm of Math and Physics -- That doesn't imply infallibility. History bears this out for we find many sources of the Braitot are actually from the Essenes who had a totally different world view from the Pharisees (the orthodox at time of the second Temple) and later from the Talmud itself. The dead sea scrolls clearly bear out the fact that the Gemarah is exactly what it claims to be, a compilation and evaluation of the millions of Braitot floating around during the Second Temple period. Evaluating the Talmud from the historical context it came in tends to take out its mythical dimensions but if done with care and respect it shows its true greatness.

 

·

 

There is no question that you can take any statement of the Talmud or it's commentators and argue it pro and con ad infinitum. The question is as to the fruitfulness of this. The point is, no matter how far you go its only horizontal depth.    

 

·

 

The formulas of halacha result in an infinity of variations because of the slight variations of the parameters of each person's individual soul and world-line. When we don't know how to keep the commandments we are to go to the Jewish Sages (Deuteronomy 17:8-13); and that is the Talmud, which is the generality of the Oral law. However, the laws which they made to guard Biblical laws because of a specific situation which existed at that time or place, those laws don't apply in the opinion of the Rashbam and Raavad — when the reason for the law disappears so does the law. To the Rosh even, if the reason applies, if it's not in the same place where the law was originally made it doesn't apply. (See the beginning of the halachot of non-Jewish wine in the Shach and Taz. See the Rambam on putting ornaments on the streets of Jerusalem on the festival after the destruction of the Temple. — and the Raavad there, and the Rosh at the beginning of Masechet Avoda Zarah.) [The importance of not adding on any restrictions is to keep the patterns of chaos of each person's soul which comes from the circular sephirot and provides the energy of serving God.]

Without the ideas of the science of Chaos, it is hard to understand why the Torah commands us not to add to the commandments.

 

·

 

The laws of the written Torah are invariant. But the Jewish people are in an inertial frame of reference as compared to Mount Sinai, so all explanations which are direct traditions from Sinai always apply to them but not to non-Jews who are in an accelerating frame revolving around the empty space. Different formulations apply to them. Now even in the written Torah many laws are given that apply only in Israel like a gas that obeys the gas laws when it is in a state of equilibrium. When not in that state the only way to describe [until now] is by statistical methods. That is why since the  the laws of the Torah are statistically valid, but in cases keeping the law would invalidate its purpose to Rabbi Shimon, the law doesn't apply. Perhaps Solomon’s mistake was that there was a state of equilibrium in his days.

 

·

 

Many of the laws of the Torah are based on probability, e.g., the majority of judges in civil cases, and majority opinion in religious cases. It's OK if the Torah has statistical laws because probability is part of the fabric of the spiritual and physical universe. Before the case comes to court it's a wave pattern where all the facts co-exist in mathematical wave form. But once it's in court the facts are observed and reduced to particle form. [The majority of Rabbi Nachman's advice is in fact statistical, not absolute. He simply describes the forces at work in each mitzvah but the actual effects in each person's life will be based on many factors. Like wearing tzitzis saving one from bad advice. It can cause one to get bad advice also by getting involved with religious hypocrites. However, Rabbi Nachman is referring to some degree of a spiritual effect that the tzitzis do have.]

 

·

 

Not every Kal Vechomer (a conclusion from a minority) is a law to Moses on Mount Sinai, but it is from heaven as is everything which comes from the 13 ways to explain the Torah, (as the Rambam says in Moreh Nevuchim), for there are many places in the Talmud where how to apply any one of the 13-principles is a subject of debate (i.e. if you can prove a law from one of the 13 principles then it is Biblical).

 

·

 

The Gemarah in Sanhedrin (99a) says, “Even if one says the whole Torah is from Heaven except for one verse that God didn't say rather Moses said it himself is in the category of “he has despised the word of the Lord”, and even if he says the whole Torah is from heaven except for some derivation or some a conclusion a minority or some derivation from similar expressions is in the category of “he has despised the Word of the Lord”. If this would mean every time a derivation is said in the Gemarah that it was said to Moses at Mount Sinai then all the Talmudic sages would be in that category, for the Talmud is full of arguments on the application of the 13 principles. Rather this means that anything proven by the 13 principles is from heaven, not that it's a tradition from Moses on Mount Sinai. [On Biblical verses the Gemarah says God said them to Moses, but on derivations it says they are from heaven.] (Also, the laws brought back by the derivations, not the recollections of Yonasan Ben Kenaz would have been rabbinical, not biblical.) Rashi is clear in Brachot 5b that the mishna was not given on Mount Sinai, rather that Israel should learn the teachings of the law as they were handed down. This is clear in many Rashis and Rambams throughout Shas.

 

·

 

There was disagreement between the halachic authorities and the kabbalists that was very strong in the Middle Ages. This continues in every generation for the rabbis continue to disagree with the cabalists of their generation while only agreeing with the ones that have gone, like the war the rabbis made against Rabbi Chayim Lutzato and against the Baal Shem Tov and Rabbi Nachman and Rabbi Abulafia. This was a continuation of the disagreements in philosophy between the ultra-orthodox Pharisees and the esoteric Essences. The root of this starts from Joseph (who was on the level of the inner truth) and his brothers. The outer truth is the halacha. The inner truth is the Kabbalah. Only afterwards the rabbis incorporated the Braitot of the Essences in the Mishna and Talmud and accepted all the later Kabbalists while finding new ones to make war on.

 

·

 

Every mitzvah has a mathematical function determining how much Divine light it draws. And that differs according to the parameters of the persons soul (vessel). So, it is conceivable for a mitzvah to contain no light unless the basic initial conditions are met, like having good character traits.

 

·

 

Torah is only a reflection of the higher spiritual reality of Wisdom as the Zohar says, “Torah is the fallen leaves of Wisdom.” Wisdom in turn is only a reflection of the true spiritual reality of the Crown. And all this applies on each level of the ten sephirot. For instance, the Spiritual reality of Formation is reflected in the Mishna but the higher reality there is in the Sefer Haichalot (if you have the right version of that book). The light there is even a higher level but still isn't to be compared to the vessels of Creation, which is Gemarah (which explains the great light that many feel when they learn Gemarah…)

   

·

 

The idea of tolerance is contained in the Torah in the way of a hint for there is an argument about the application of many laws of the Torah in many different situations. The traditional way of looking at this is deterministic, i.e., that rabbis disagree about it until it is brought to the Sanhedrin for a vote to decide the absolute truth. This implies the laws are deterministic but not the application. It is possible that the idea of the Sanhedrin itself is statistical and not deterministic since we find that the Torah itself says if an individual knows that the Sanhedrin has made a mistake, he is not allowed to follow it. Even though the aspect of the Torah of “forbidden, permitted, unclean, clean, innocent, guilty” was given from the aspect of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil, it has an aspect of holiness that will be included in holiness in the future. Perhaps from this we can derive tolerance as a principle that exists in that No Man's Land between the opinions that permit and those that forbid.

 

·

 

The sages of the Talmud say that the evil inclination leaves the rest of the world and rests only on Israel. Then it leaves Israel and rests only on the Torah scholars. That is the imp of the perverse that doesn't care if something is pleasurable or not. All that matters is that it should be against the Torah. It's the evil angel that wrestled with Jacob that appeared to him as a Torah sage because that particular evil angel knows the law very well and put pleasure into things that would have no physical or emotional satisfaction except for the fact that this imp knows it is forbidden.

 

·

 

The oral law is like a brick of gold that stretches from Moses until the center of the empty space [vertically]. [Prayer is going back up]. The Oral Law as contained in the Talmud is only one small horizontal slice. Since the Talmud stretches vertically this would apply also to the written law or prophecy and Kabbalah etc. Thus, we find a continuation after the Talmud of the light of the Talmud in the Geonim and later authorities.

 

 

 

 

Chapter 11 – On Science

 

 

 

 

“Investigation of the wisdom of the Creator that is seen from the creations is the closest path to clarity of knowledge of His existence.” —Chovot Halevavot, Section 2, Introduction

 

“Since the creation of the world, God's invisible qualities - his eternal power and Divine nature -- have been clearly seen, being understood from what has been made” — Romans 1:20.

 

This is the line that prompted Michal Faraday to try to understand electricity, and thus the connection between electricity and magnetism which is the source for modern electricity was discovered. “Know that proportional to one's knowledge of the Torah and the nature of the world, so the world is handed over to him and subjugated under him.” -Sefer HaMidot, Daat vol.2, Num 2.

 

·

 

In the first four chapters of Mishnah Torah the Rambam gives a brief account of the Kabbalah of the Torah and the science that was known in his days, and finishes by saying, “The ideas of these last four chapters are what the first authorities call the ‘Pardes’” Then in Chapter 1  (Laws of Torah Study, Halachah 11-12), he writes “One must divide the time of his study, a third in the written Torah, a third in the oral Torah and a third in understanding one thing from another… which is called Gemarah… The things called the “Pardes” (the fruit tree garden) is in the category of the Gemarah.” The Rambam thus openly says that learning science is in the category of the commandment to learn Torah and also on a higher level of Torah than the Talmud and legal authorities.

 

·

 

To the Rambam in the Guide [III:51] the division of people is (from highest to lowest):

 

a.      The prophets (the Crown).

b.      The philosophers (Wisdom) [of the schools of Aristotle and Plato, not the rival schools of Greek thought of Epicurus or the several other types that the Sages and the Rambam didn't go for].

c.      The scientists (Understanding) (Jewish or not).

d.      Those who keep the commandments and know the Talmud. (Knowledge-Glory with Royalty).

e.      Those who keep the commandments (Royalty).

f.       Those that don't keep the commandments.

 

The Rambam does stipulate that all should be facing towards the King [the Intellect-God] - otherwise they are evil.

 

Yet, this depends also on why they are turning from the King; if for pleasure then they are from the Klipa of Noga, if for sin they are from the three totally evil klippoth (this corresponds with Aristotle's division of people that believe the purpose of life is to have pleasure), then political people [those that do right for the sake of the right not honor], and those that love and live the contemplative life.

 

This also corresponds with the three worlds.

1.      The pleasure seekers have root-souls from the physical universe.

2.      The political people [people keeping and learning the laws of the Torah] from the world of Formation [on the level of good and evil].

3.      Scientists and philosophers are from Creation.

4.      The highest level of those attached to God are from Emanation and included in Aristotle's contemplative category.

 

[The religious divisions are horizontal and not vertical. Spiritual Judaism is on the inside to the left [God's right], Legal Judaism is on the inside to the right, Protestantism is just outside of Judaism on the left. Catholicism on the inside to the right. Islam is outside of both also to the right and left etc.

 

However, all this refers to the physical Jewish people or Christian people etc. But since the Torah is given for every level and all time and all generations it refers to the higher levels also. Thus, there is a spiritual Israel with souls that are of Israel though their bodies are not, and vice versa - and this is on the level of Formation, that is, political people or people involved with the separation of good from evil in society in general.

 

So, it is safe to assume that social minded people that are battling for the good of society, not for personal honor are from the spiritual Israel of Formation. On the next level up, those involved in contemplation of God and his works are from the spiritual Israel of Creation, people attached constantly to God are from the spiritual Israel of Emanation. But on all these levels everything depends on one's intent so if one is involved in contemplation of God with some ulterior motive he is not from the spiritual Israel, even though they are from Creation.

 

People however do differ in their tendencies based on their DNA structure so there definitely is an effect on people by being born Jewish, but it isn't the same as when the actual soul is Jewish - which is independent of how one was born.]

 

·

 

It's interesting to notice that the Rambam places philosophers and scientists on a higher spiritual plane than people who know the whole Talmud and keep all the commandments of the Torah. I however divide people according to their character traits:

 

v The Artist

v The Scientist-Philosopher

v The Religious Scholar

v The Business Man (normally religious)

v The Leach.

 

But in reality, this is the same as the Rambam as Bertrand Russell explained. The Artist is the Prophet. Each should have the same focal point -- the King.
