Those that face the opposite direction have negative of their absolute value. If facing sideways their value is (R)(Cosine of the angle between them and the King).

 

If they oscillate, they give out a wave pattern. The waves sometimes constructively interfere and sometimes not. But you can get an average value, which is the reason democracies work decently if at least they are facing the King While monarchies only work well if the monarch is facing the King. That's why the Torah stipulates that the prophet has to choose the King or at least the Sanhedrin, who should be hopefully somewhat intelligent and therefore should make a halfway decent choice. (The main job of the Torah King was mainly military, so his power was limited. But still it had a big effect on the people who their king was).

 

In conclusion, we can't divide people by religion because it is almost irrelevant to their character, which to all the major religions is the main thing, and the main path to God. Rather the main dividing line is the thinkers and the masses. However, this has nothing to do with intelligence for an unintelligent person can be a deep and profound thinker, while a brilliant mind can be shallow, trivial, and of no concern to anyone (i.e., non-fruitful).

 

·

 

(I would like to point out that this doesn't disagree with Rabbi Nachman whose tirade against the “philosophers” of the Enlightenment of the 1700s has little to do with philosophy. They assumed that by pure reason without revelation they could construct a utopia. They were a new class of what we would call intellectuals, or social critics and reformers. Rabbi Nachman was speaking about the group that in his days was called specifically the “philosophers”. That point of view is diametrically opposed to the view held generally in the 1800s of Romanticism which believes that moral passion and emotion count more than reason. This is closer to Rabbi Nachman’s point of view.

 

Rabbi Nachman also disagreed with the Sages of Israel who wanted to combine Reason and Revelation. I have gone with the latter point of view for several reasons. One, I have tried to take Rabbi Nachman in context of all the sages of Israel rather than the Breslover view which sees him alone.

 

Rabbi Nachman himself talks about the importance of believing in all the wise, and all the more so the wise of Israel, and all the more so the wise of the great authorities of halachah of the Middle Ages upon which all decisions in halachah must be based on.

 

·

 

“What is the way to His love and fear? When a man contemplates the wondrous and great deeds and creations of the Creator, and sees from them His infinite wisdom, immediately he will love and praise Him and desire to know Him with tremendous longing… And when he thinks about these things, he will become awestruck and know that he is a small creature before He who is perfect in knowledge. Therefore, I will explain important principles in the creations of the Creator in order that these things should be a key to understand and to love God.”

-­ Mishna Torah Laws of the Foundations of the Torah, Chapter 2, Halachah 2.

 

Then, the Rambam explains principles of Kabbalah and science. He does not say that learning the oral or written law brings love or fear. Rather science and kabbalah. “The fullness of the whole world is His glory.” — Psalms 24

 

·

 

The Oral Law places true scientific knowledge on a higher plane than Torah knowledge as it says in Mesechta Chagigah [Chapter 2] and as it says about Rabbi Yochanan Ben Zakai, that “He knew great and small things. What were the great things? The works of Creation and the Divine Chariot. What were the small things? The Talmudic discussions of Abbaye and Rava.” (This is the Talmudic source of the Rambam, Mishna Torah Book 1, Chapter 4).

 

·

 

It is interesting to note that the mother of all books of musar of Torah literature, the Duties of the Heart puts science, the study of logic, and ethics on a higher spiritual plane than Torah. It is even more shocking than the Rambam, because it says this in so many words in his introduction: “I have seen fit to conclude the introduction of this book with a story that will make you zealous to understand its subjects and awaken you to know the importance of this type of commandment [of the heart] above the other type [physical] and the importance of physical science and the science of ethics and the science of logic above the wisdom of the Torah.” This study in his days was confined to Aristotle and Plato and their commentaries, and in particular Averroes.

 

·

 

There was after the incident of Bar Kokhba a tremendous change on the Jewish personality. From nationalist dreams of an immediate savior of Israel and search for philosophical and scientific knowledge they became a fearful isolated religion and devoted all their energies toward the accumulation of the oral laws into the two Talmud's. However, the Rambam and other sages in the later Middle Ages realized that Science and philosophy were an integral part of the Torah. This trend was followed by the Christian thinkers and mystics from that time and during the Renaissance until the 1600's when there was the violent anti-Reformation which began the divorce of faith and reason in the Christian and followed by the Jewish world.

 

·

 

The Gra and Rabbi Moshe Chayim Luttzato don't hold that science is a part of Torah. The Gra however, says, “The degree that one lacks in any one of the seven wisdoms will cause him to lack in knowledge of the Torah a hundred-fold” (referring to the division of the natural sciences into seven groups by Aristotle) (Quoted in the introduction to the translation of Euclid into Hebrew by Rabbi Baruch of Shklov the disciple of the Gra). However, the Rambam holds that science is Torah, for in the 1st two chapters of the Mishne Torah he writes basic ideas of philosophy and kabbalah, and in the next two, he writes basic concepts of science (astronomy, chemistry, etc.). Then he concludes and says, “The subjects I have written about in these first four chapters are what the Sages call “the Orchard”. Then in the laws of learning the Torah he says the things called Orchard are considered learning Torah (on the highest level which he mentions there.)

 

To answer the contradiction to the Rambam I would say science is on the level of the worlds above Emanation, that if you learn it to bring yourself to God, it’s a part of Torah and included in the worlds of holiness. (See Lekutei Moharan Vol. 1, Chapt. 19, and Vol. 2, Chapt 78, and Chapt. 91, where Rabbi Nachman answers this himself in basically the same way.)

 

·

 

The knowledge of science which there is today wasn't known to the Gra or the Chasam Sofer who agreed with the Sefer HaBris which is actually just the science that was known then. A lot of that science is actually not correct. But still the Ramchal says that which is relevant to the outer aspects of the physical world isn't Torah. Only that which relates to the inner part of this world, or which relates to the inner or outer part of the higher worlds is Torah. The reason may be that as you rise pyramidally, the Torah includes whatever is in a time-like direction. The Rambam could answer this however by saying that science is the explanation of the inner-laws by which the physical universe works.

 

·

 

Rabbi Nachman said to learn science in the Sefer Hamidos. The places where he says not to are referring to the science of his day which was faulty. (The Rambam makes this same distinction in reference to what the sages say not to learn “outer wisdoms” which he said meant faulty wisdoms. (Many scientists then and now tend to be hard-headed sceptics.) However, many of the great ones tend to be spirituality oriented. For instance, Einstein, Kepler and Copernicus, who was a church man, Feynman who at the end of his life became interested in the New World ideas, John Grisham, the author of Omega Point, Oppenheimer (the Bhagavad Gita), Neumann who was baptized into (of all things) the Catholic faith!, and Paul Dirac who became interested in Jungian Psychology and the Kabbalah, Socrates and the quiet voice that advised him -- as he mentioned before his judges at his last trial. It seems these people got to the place where the mind and the spiritual meet and tried to cross the bridge.]

 

·

 

The Gra and the Chasam Sofer sided with “The Guide for the Perplexed” of the Rambam. Rabbi Nachman actually quotes from it, though he railed against it, in the part about the five differences between the intelligence of men and God.

 

Rabbi Nachman's quotes from Socrates that “the highest knowledge is to know that one does not know”. This statement is from the speech of Socrates who was told by the oracle at Delphi that he is the wisest of all men. Then he went to all the wise men and discovered that they knew nothing and thus he explained to the oracle that he was the wisest, because he knew that he knew nothing. Don't look for it in the Guide because it's not there.

 

Rabbi Nachman's war wasn't against philosophy, but the so called propagandists of France at that time known as the “philosophes”. And against subjugating revelation to reason, but he agreed that you need both, as we see in the Lekutai Moharan Vol 1 Chapt 1, Chapt 61 Vol 2, Chapt 91, and Sefer Hamidot, Daat vol. 2 num. 2

 

·

 

The struggle between reason and faith has had a long history in Judaism, Islam and Christianity. The regular scientists and clergy always seem to be at odds while the great geniuses of science and religion always point in the same direction to the essential fact that there is no true conflict, and that revelation and reason are both necessary and possible to achieve. This conflict and oscillation between these two poles are what spurns growth. This oscillation creates the spiritual waves that shape the existence of humankind.

 

·

 

The thing about physics and Math is that at least they don't claim to make people better, even though they in fact have a good effect, i.e., they don't make people righteous, just a little better than what they would have been otherwise - at least it trains one to think logically - and if this would translate into action the world might just be a better place.

 

Bertrand Russell said that there is a lot more virtue in intelligence than in virtue (the top three sephirot - Wisdom, Understanding and Knowledge, vs. the lower seven - which are on the level of good and evil, permitted and forbidden, pure and impure). This is like the Rambam, in that science is on a higher spiritual level than Torah and mitzvos.

 

·

 

Abraham Maslov said, “a soul not exposed to higher and beautiful things dries up and dies.” The Yerushalmi says, “All are prone to sickness if they lack music.” The Rambam says in the Eight Chapters that sometimes one needs to sit among the “beautiful figures” to revive his soul. Beauty is the middle sephirah and holds the node of the soul in place so the right and left sephirot can vibrate in resonance with the energy waves coming from the higher sephirot.

 

·

 

The root of Physics and Math is in the worlds which are above the world of Emanation, and thus at the time of the breaking of the vessels they fell into the lower worlds. But if one learns them with fear of God, they have the power to bring one up to his higher root (This is the reason the sciences have been emphasized by the non-Jews who are from the same world).

 

·

 

The idea of learning science and math is to be attached to the thoughts of God in the creation of this world. This is what the Sages of the Talmud call the Work of Creation. The idea of learning Kabbalah is to be attached to the thoughts of God in the creation of the higher spiritual worlds. So, one fulfills the commandment of being attached to God by learning science, math, and kabbalah. By learning Jewish law, one attaches his mind to the tree of knowledge of good and evil which was forbidden to Adam, and by doing so he fell from the world of formation into the world of action. However, for us here one is required to know the law. Rabbi Chayim Vital writes “for those who understand the Talmud very well they should learn it at the most two hours a day and the rest of the day learn Kabbalah. [In the days of Rabbi Chayim Vital there was no true science, so it wasn't mentioned by him.] But people who don't understand the Talmud shouldn't learn it at all, rather they should learn kabbalah all day.” The books of the disciples of the Baal Shem Tov are a commentary on the kabbalah and show how it applies in daily life.

 

·

 

Rabbi Chayim Vital is clear that the Talmud and authorities are on the level of The Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil, which was forbidden to Adam to eat from. This is actually from the Zohar, but since the Zohar can be interpreted differently, I have to bring this statement from Rabbi Chayim Vital. He says he who understands them well should learn them at the most 2 hours a day in order to break through the barriers and reach the core of good but everyone else should just learn kabbalah all day. I believe science and math in their higher root are higher than the world of emanation, and if one learns them with fear of God are an essential part of kabbalah, i.e., kabbalah is from the name 45, science from the name 63 and 52 and together can draw the light of the name 72.

 

·

 

To come to the truth of Science and Kabbalah is by fear of God, but too much fear of God isn't good as it says in proverbs, “Don't be righteous overly much.” For instance, there is the personality of the 'artist', whose whole personality can be ruined by fear of God if it isn't done in the right way with moderation. He needs his evil inclination alive and well to function as a creator. (What I mean by an artist is one who may be an artist in music or in science and kabbalah also. Creativity knows no bounds.) But he needs not to do sin also. But the scientist philosopher type isn't ruined by a lot of fear of God.

 

·

 

Even in holiness there are services to God one is prevented from Heaven from doing. Don't try to break the gates that God has made. Rabbi Nachman said not to be stubborn about anything. When one path is closed to someone, I think that it does no good to force down the door for its only result is to have that, and other doors, closed.

 

·

 

Science provides a garment for kabbalah so the klipos can't penetrate. Science tends to take out of the fight between good and evil.

 

·

 

The wisdom of the physical world has its’ root in the circular sephirot, so learning it draws that light upon one which provides an outer light that surrounds one and protects him. On the other hand, Kabbalah draws the inner light.

 

·

 

Math and Physics are the hidden light of the sealed statement of creation in which the holiness of God is hidden. Nothing exists besides God, and everything is just his Light in the vessels before our eyes, there is a great holiness in science and mathematics. In fact, not just some holiness but the holiness of the hidden Statement that caused the Creation, which is the highest holiness. But unless it's connected with God it falls.

 

·

 

The sephirah of Wisdom is the reality of the idea of Plato where the idea is the reality. Whereas the lower sephirot are guided by those ideas. This explains how the Rambam can equate philosophy with Kabbalah.

 

·

 

Every book has its own given tempo just like music. It is important to read every book at its given tempo and that takes precedence to understanding since if you read it at the right tempo, you'll enjoy it and come back and learn it again and again.

 

·

 

The commandments are on the level of Royalty and so one word of learning Torah is worth more than all the commandments together even if done with absolute perfection. Yet Science is on the level of Understanding and thus one word of science is worth more than all the words of Torah. Kabbalah is on the level of Wisdom and prayer on the level of the Crown, and thus worth more than all others. [This is true only in accord with the system of most of the later kabbalists, not to the Reshash who puts the written Law on the level of action of zeir anpin while the other kinds of learning in formation creation and emanation of nukbah.(but that is only in the vertical system after the correction anyway.)]

 

·

 

If we would apply Rabbi Nachman's principle of just saying the words in order and to have faith that eventually you will understand, to Mathematics, it would seem to me that we would have a way that even the dullest student could become a genius in Math. But if one does this because he thinks it makes sense, he will cease to do it. But if one does it because he has faith in the saint who said to do it, then he will continue and have success. However, I will say how it works. Fear of God, and good and strong character traits provide the vessels for the light. Then by being involved with it the light is drawn as an outer light, that surrounds the person. By doing the exercises it enters into the vessels.

 

·

 

There is a principle called the love force. This force is a physical force that changes reality. Therefore, the only real learning is by the love principle. For by loving a subject you'll be able to break down the door in front of it. That's one reason for Rabbi Nachman's idea of just saying the words in order and then to go on without review. For if you love it that's all you need to get inside the door.

 

·

 

My impression is that whatever people do to make themselves more happy results in their being more unhappy.

 

 

Chapter 12 - Decisions

 

The Greeks said know yourself. Perhaps meaning, “Know your lacks and your good traits. Then you can compensate. In place of lacks you can find friends that can do that part of your life that you can't take care of. In the good traits you will know what to concentrate upon.”



·

 

 

Trust in God and simplicity. If you don't know something, then it is because Vesikin Vesikin God doesn't want you to know. If He wants you to know, he knows how to let you know. So, trust means do nothing until God shows you clearly His will. To trust in God, you need to learn to live with doubt until God solves the problem. But this is not automatic. Rather one needs actively to put oneself in God's presence and then I believe that God will take care of him.



·

 

a.      Reconnaissance.

b.      Independent Confirmation, [from a source other than yourself].

c.      Be Prepared.

d.      Verify yourself if it really is like you heard or think.

e.      Bible.



·

 

In America, people pay a salary to what is called a personal coach or someone whose job it is to get your life to be the best that it can be. This is what used to be a friend [or rabbi], but nowadays with that gone one needs to pay a personal coach. If that is a bit expensive a true friend is good to have. [So apparently the idea of advice from a friend or mentor is not a totally negative concept as I write in note {6}.



·

 

Situational Awareness: This is something that fighter pilots need to stay alive. It is being aware of the whole situation around oneself, not just what is in front of us. This is the reason non-predators have their eyes on the side of their heads. [Predators have eyes in front of their head like people]. In life sometimes I am aware something is wrong in a certain place or situation, but I can't put my finger on it. So, to some degree I have this awareness but in general I have not acted on it, preferring to think everything is rosy and all people are loving. Well, they are not and if you sense something is wrong, head on out of there as fast as you can.



·

 

For Colonel Simons, the great principle was reconnaissance -- [check it out before you go in]. This was the difference between when he went in to rescue the hostages in Iran and being successful, while in a different rescue attempt by the army, it was unsuccessful.

 

But in the frum world you hear things like Rav Sonenfeld getting married on the first one offered to him whether she would be proper or not. Maybe this was OK for him, but this isn't the same thing as trusting in God. Trusting in God means you trust in God, but you act to the best of your ability in each situation while knowing that the final result is in any case only dependent upon God's will.

 

·

 

Is the “good” advice of some rabbis a trap to lead one to be their slave and give up on their free will? Or is it perhaps to lead one into an unproductive life? Why did all the frum/orthodox stay in Europe during the period of the Holocaust? Wasn't it because their rabbis who had generally given them good advice, advised them one time unwisely, i.e., not to flee when the Nazis rose to power?!

 

From 1933 until 1939 why did almost no religious Jews flee from Poland? It is only because rabbis gave them good advice at various times, so they assumed that this time also would be so. Is what we call the Divine spirit of some rabbis a trap? [To lose one's free will? Why is it that when faced with a life decision you don't know which way to jump? Isn't it that slowly you have allowed the rabbis to take over your consciousness and now I can't get it back?

 

·

 

So, life decisions I think must be made thus:

a.      Never ask advice from people or rabbis. For once you have heard it, it makes an effect even if you decide to reject it later - and every time you ask you give up a little bit of your free will.

b.      Never make a life decision under pressure emotional or sexual needs.

c.      Find a way to relax, like Winston Churchill who made most major decisions of World War II while lying in a bathtub.

d.      Like Barbara [a friend] said, “Find out.” Do the work necessary to find out the right course of action. Don't assume things.


·

 

But my question is does this apply to a rabbi who has always seems to be right? Perhaps he really is wise?

 

·

 

Israel of Koznitz said a mitzvah that comes suddenly is usually from the evil side.


·

 

In all these principles there are contradictions. So, I think the best thing is to make a hierarchy of advice principles. The first being if you know you are not capable of a correct decision then put it in God's hands.



·

 

The irony of it all is that every attempt to bring Utopia to humankind seems to result in increased chaos and suffering.


·

 

Why is it that the experts always seem to know the least and to be lacking common sense? This is not that people in general are all that much better. But the “experts” seem to have a knack for getting on the wrong track. When I was young, I was convinced that the reason for this was that experts are usually mediocre minds that have done the work to get where they are. Then, in their position of power, their inherent absence of talent manifests itself. This is probably correct.

 

But I must change this idea. For my original idea was that all intelligence is one. This may be true but nowadays I think talent tends to be very selective. Even Leonardo Da Vinci had art and invention but no other fields. I used to say this was from lack of time to go into everything. But now I think it simply may be talent is selective. Of course, even after one has talent nothing can replace that spark of inspiration one needs from God. For this reason, I believe fear of God is important for creativity.

·

 

To answer questions in life - no coin flips. No trying to get inspiration.

 

There is:

1.      First impression.

2.      Basic feeling.

3.      Doing the work to find out.

 

Not people's advice.

 

[There is enough in his Godliness for every creation. Be satisfied with what godliness he gives you.]

·

 

The is the problem of listening to rabbis even though they may not be wise, perhaps puts one on the wrong track - or just reinforces the already wrong track that one is on.

 

·

 

Learning to know who to trust among people also is an important skill.

For money management is a skill which is like any other skill. Some are good at it and others are not. For those who are not it is important to at least tell who you can trust in your monetary affairs.

 

Or in other personal decisions, many times the nearest and dearest to us advise things based on their own hatreds and prejudices without our own interest in mind. Someone close to me was advised by people he trusted to leave me and found himself in a whole lot of trouble for several years.

 

I myself trusted rabbis more than my parents and have found myself years later striped of my wife and children and no means of making an honest living except what I learnt from my parents.

 

·

 

Leonardo De Vinci thought people are meant to live balanced lives. It is true that each person has a special area of talent, but each person should try to be balanced by doing physical activity every day and learning different subjects. I think in the way that God made us that we can only do so much of any one thing and then we need to go on and the next day we can come back to it.

Thus, in values also. Though on the surface it might seem there are different duties a person must do, and they conflict, I think in fact there is no conflict for somehow only one of the options is the right one and the task is to choose the right one.

 

Leonardo himself developed different aspects of his personality in science and art and physical activity. They say he was so strong that he could crush nuts in his hand.

 

·

 

Here is something to bear in mind as you go through life from the author Herodotus: The exceeding good fortune of Polycrates did not escape the notice of Amasis, who was much disturbed thereat. When therefore his successes continued increasing, Amasis wrote him the following letter, and sent it to Samos. “Amasis to Polycrates thus sayeth: It is a pleasure to hear of a friend and ally prospering, but thy exceeding prosperity does not cause me joy, forasmuch as I know that the gods are envious. My wish for myself and for those whom I love is to be now successful, and now to meet with a check; thus, passing through life amid alternate good and ill, rather than with perpetual good fortune. For never yet did I hear tell of anyone succeeding in all his undertakings, who did not meet with calamity at last, and come to utter ruin. Now, therefore, give ear to my words, and meet thy good luck in this way: bethink thee which of all thy treasures thou valuest most and canst least bear to part with; take it, whatsoever it be, and throw it away, so that it may be sure never to come any more into the sight of man. Then, if thy good fortune be not thenceforth checkered with ill, save thyself from harm by again doing as I have counselled.”


·

 

Equilibrium is a major principle in life. What one does to improve his situation invariably changes the balance. One can't foresee the consequences of that change. But if the situation one is in is in any way livable, then to change it is probably a mistake. Moving from one place to another changes a balance and should never be done unless absolutely necessary. Also, in every person there is a balance of talent. If smart in one thing invariably he will be foolish in another. The most talented of people tend to lack simple common sense



·

 

I have become convinced that most people tend to be the exact opposite of what they appear.

 

·

 

Without a college education one is doomed to slavery. This is why the Jewish people when they came to America instinctively worked like dogs to make sure their children would get a college education. They had experienced enough slavery in Eastern Europe to want out.

 

Now we have all forgotten this and seek to be enslaved again to middle class boredom and looking for some religious or political answer to the world’s problems. But this is doomed to failure since every solution to one problem just brings another and who is to say if the new problem won't be worse?


·

 

When going to the Ukraine I asked a friend what to take with me. And they said, “Take as little as possible [in order to open yourself up to new things Hashem may want for you.” I then asked about the sleeping bag. She said, “You are going to the Ukraine. You MUST take a sleeping bag." [I see now how wise that was. For I thought I was going to a place that was heated. Then when I left and found myself here in another place, I needed to wear several shirts, a sweater, a jacket, then to go into the sleeping bag and then put two woolen blankets over myself. All this is indoors. And this winter is mild. I remember winters when one could literally not go outside for more than two minutes.]

 

My feeling is that this relates to the motto of the Boy Scouts, “Be Prepared.” For to be prepared for everything is impossible. And obviously I could not take everything I needed.

 

But the idea is first:

1.      Take as little as possible.

2.      In the extra space left take small things that don't take up room but may come in handy.

·

 

I think there are some people who give up too quickly and others who don't give up even when they should. You should try to know yourself and see which type you are so that you will know how to compensate. If you are the type who gives up on things too quickly you will know the next time you want to give up that you should stick it out.

 

·

 

The lacks in our character are precisely placed there so that we will refer all those areas to God and come to him in prayer asking for help. For even though we need His help in everything we do, those areas are made specially to remind us of our limitations and to run to God for help.

·

 

“In the course of regeneration, when man is being made spiritual, he is continually engaged in combat, for before regeneration cupidities have the dominion, because the whole man is composed of mere cupidities and the falsities thence derived. During regeneration these cupidities and falsities cannot be instantaneously abolished, for this would be to destroy the whole man, such being the only life which he has acquired; and therefore evil spirits are suffered to continue with him for a long time, that they may excite his cupidities, and that these may thus be loosened, in innumerable ways, even to such a degree that they can be inclined by the Lord to good, and the man be thus reformed. In the time of combat, the evil spirits, who bear the utmost hatred against all that is good and true, that is, against whatever is of love and faith toward the Lord-which things alone are good and true, because they have eternal life in them - leave the man nothing else for food but what is compared to the vegetable and the green of the herb; nevertheless the Lord gives him also a food which is compared to the herb bearing seed, and to the tree in which is fruit, which are states of tranquility and peace, with their joys and delights; and this food the Lord gives the man at intervals.” -- Swedenborg

 

·

 

“Unless the Lord defended man every moment, yea, even the smallest part of every moment, he would instantly perish, in consequence of the indescribably intense and mortal hatred which prevails in the world of spirits against the things relating to love and faith toward the Lord. The certainty of this fact I can affirm, having been now for some years (notwithstanding my remaining in the body) associated with spirits in the other life, even with the worst of them, and I have sometimes been surrounded by thousands, to whom it was permitted to spit forth their venom, and infest me by all possible methods, yet without their being able to hurt a single hair of my head, so secure was I under the Lord’s protection. From so many years' experience I have been thoroughly instructed concerning the world of spirits and its nature, as well as concerning the combat which those being regenerated must needs endure, in order to attain the happiness of eternal life. But as no one can be so well instructed in such subjects by a general description as to believe them with an undoubting faith, the particulars will of the Lord’s Divine mercy be related in the hi following pages.” -- Swedenborg

 

·

 

 

“In time of desolation never to make a change; but to be firm and constant in the resolutions and determination in which one was the day preceding such desolation, or in the determination in which he was in the preceding consolation. Because, as in consolation it is rather the good spirit who guides and counsels us, so in desolation it is the bad, with whose counsels we cannot take a course to decide rightly.” -- St. Ignatius of Loyola

 

·

 

 

Only when forced should one move his location. Like Peretz (a friend) said on moving: Most of the time for him it was from the frying pan into the fire.

·

 

In modern thought spontaneity is considered good. In the meditations of Marcus Aurelius, we find that one should not be careless. I figure that comes from the Stoic point of view.

·

 

Sometimes one finds himself attracted to a group of people considering them cool or with it in some way. Chekov has a story about one such person that fell in such a way. I figure this must be one of the tricks of the evil side to pull us away from our center of equilibrium. (Showing us other lifestyles and making them look attractive to us.

 

·

 

Don't do things contrary to your destiny, for those things can take you away from your destiny.

 

·

 

Don't get top heavy. Learning every day is good in balance with other things.

This applies to civilization also.

 

There needs to be a balance and equilibrium between the mind, heart and body. This is why Roman law became the basis for western society. It was meant to be natural law: just enough to provide for the need but not more.

 

This is the same reason why the human brain works. It is just large enough to work. If it got too big the balance would be thrown off and it would cease to work. This is the reason Dinosaurs with larger brains never developed.

 

·

 

Since the head and the heart are almost always in opposition, and heart is more in tune with the Divine, if you know what your head is saying but don't know what your heart says then do the opposite of the head. What makes sense -- don't do. The reason is if the heart and head were together then you would know what your heart says. Since you don't know there is therefore a conflict, and for sure your heart says something else and therefore it is not what the head says — but your head and logic are drowning out the message from your heart.

 

·

 

Sometimes the naive among us hears a friend promise us some type of favor. “Come live in our house and all your needs will be provided.” We know why people take care of all the needs of chickens. It is not any altruistic ideal of benefiting the chicken. But when we receive the same invitation, we can be fooled. Here is how Zeno reacted to such a proposal. “And when Demochares, the son of Laches, embraced him once, and said that he would tell Antigonus, or write to him of everything which he wanted, as he always did everything for him, Zeno, when he had heard him say this, avoided his company for the future.”

[]

 

Learning is a Jewish principle. The importance of this is because the essence of life is to create. But how can one create something new if one doesn't take in and incorporate within himself something new daily?

But not just anything new. The less one understands the better for as Swedenborg says, holiness dwells only in ignorance… This means, one should learn, not to know, but to fulfill he commandment of learning. Then, if knowledge does enter, it doesn't hurt since it is all on the level of ignorance — because one is serving God and attached to God to whom all knowledge is ignorance.

 

Also, the knowledge one learns should not be man-made. It must be some explanation of how God's creation works. Engineering is OK, so is politics. But not man made laws, except if with the direction of discovering the “natural law”.

 

Artificial sciences are called outer wisdoms by Rabbi Nachman and are harmful.

 

[]

 

Look at every obstacle as an opportunity in a different direction, i.e., instead of opposing the obstacle see if perhaps it is not just a subtle hint to do something different. It is not always a virtue to oppose evil. You have to know what you are up against.

 

See the attitude of an Athenian general after Athens learnt a hard lesson from the disaster in Sicily:

 

Accordingly, they resolved to relieve it the next morning. Meanwhile Phrynichus, the Athenian commander, had received precise intelligence of the fleet from Leros, and when his colleagues expressed a wish to keep the sea and fight it out, flatly refused either to stay himself or to let them or anyone else do so if he could help it. Where they could hereafter contend, after full and undisturbed preparation, with an exact knowledge of the number of the enemy’s fleet and of the force which they could oppose to him, he would never allow the reproach of disgrace to drive him into a risk that was unreasonable. It was no disgrace for an Athenian fleet to retreat when it suited them: put it as they would, it would be more disgraceful to be beaten, and to expose the city not only to disgrace, but to the most serious danger. After its late misfortunes it could hardly be justified in voluntarily taking the offensive even with the strongest force, except in a case of absolute necessity: much less than without compulsion could it rush upon peril of its own seeking. He told them to take up their wounded as quickly as they could and the troops and stores which they had brought with them and leaving behind what they had taken from the enemy's country, in order to lighten the ships, to sail off to Samos, and there concentrating all their ships to attack as opportunity served. As he spoke so he acted; and thus, not now more than afterwards, nor in this alone but in all that he had to do with, did Phrynichus show himself a man of sense. In this way that very evening the Athenians broke up from before Miletus, leaving their victory unfinished, and the Argives, mortified at their disaster, promptly sailed off home from Samos. — Pelopennesian War, Thucydides

 

 

·

 

The problems that occupy our minds are never the things we should be thinking about. They are like the world on the verge of the dark ages that was involved in trivial theological disputes not seeing the abyss they were hanging over. What really matters is to search God.

 

·

 

In my ideology, kindness is the highest virtue. But when I go to help someone, it always wastes time from other things that I do for myself, but incidentally help others also. I don't know the meaning of this: perhaps it is obstacles from the evil side trying to prevent me from being a good person. I am mystified by this so don't read this thinking I have any answer. For I firmly believe in helping others. But why is it that when I do it never works, and on the occasions that it works, it turns out it really was not needed in the first place. Could this be a hint that I should go about my own business and let God run the world?

 

·

 

If you see a person making it their business to convince others that their religion is incorrect, be assured that person is insane.

 

·

 

The more you hate someone, the more you need not say anything negative about them - for afterwards how will you ask them for forgiveness? For the sin of slander, one loses his entire portion in the Future World. So, without that forgiveness, one is in deep trouble.

 

This is besides the fact that all one's good deeds go to the one slandered. So, despite the fact that these motivations are selfish, it still is worthwhile not to lose your eternity.

 

The most powerful prayer you can say is to name those that have hurt you and release them from guilt.


·

 

I am afraid of the evil eye and try to avoid it. I am ultra-sensitive and hurt when people stare at me or give me ugly glances. But I believe that this in itself is sometimes a gift from God and a cause for blessing: but I don't treat every insult as a complement. Rather I try to see if perhaps there may be some element of truth in what the other person is saying. And despite the fact that they intend only to hurt me, I don't look at the intention but at what in me needs correcting.

·

 

I have heard that women are uniquely sensitive about their bodies. Because of this it is proper that sex should be as wild as possible, to relax the woman. There is a hierarchy of principles in the Torah. Kindness is the highest principle (to Rabeynu Yerucham of the Mir Yeshiva in Poland). I think attachment to God is the highest principle, but that kindness is the main way to come to that.

So, despite the fact that the Shulchan Aruch advises much restraint in sex, I think this was not meant in a case where the female needs to be encouraged to let go, in order that she should come to a state of relaxation and a feeling of well-being. The greatest kindness is to give to another person that which they need. Everyone needs to feel good about themselves.

I think even bad people need to feel good to repent. Bad people don’t repent usually just because they don't feel good. However, Rabbi Nachman says differently. He says at once when one decides to repent, it is a sin to be depressed, i.e., before that one should be depressed in order to come to repentance. But this doesn't mean what we call depression, rather it means a low spirit.

 

There is a problem being accepted as a well-liked member of a community or a leader: this brings down a person to the level of the people and tends to rid one of free will and free thought. So, it is necessary to have friends that will criticize you. Anyway, don't get semicha, and don't be a rabbi. The problems are pride, and lack of free will, after one is accepted. Also, it was taken for granted, in good yeshivot, that a rabbi never knew Torah - for if he really could learn why did he feel it necessary to get semicha?

 

·

 

There was an American hero that had a motto never to retreat from an enemy. I have noticed a similar characteristic in Israelis. In fact, I heard of two fellows, one American and the other an Israeli who somehow their wives had been complaining about them to some rabbis. The first group called in the American on some pretext and corned him with the divorce documents. He thought if he were a nice guy his wife would return. He signed the documents and that was the end of him and his family.  The Israeli was called in on a similar pretext and faced with the same situation. He walked up to the table and tore up the documents. He is still happily married, and his children are all going to religious schools. [He himself is totally secular which was the reason his wife wanted the divorce. He is still totally secular.]



·

 

The worst enemy is dissipation. I know there are lots of good things to do. If one doesn't watch out, this enemy will get him. It is good for this reason to do your stuff in the morning. Later in the day you need to relax. I think that as soon as one wants to do something good there arises a conspiracy, not to stop him but to waste his time.

 

·

 

The sages say when one accepts the yoke of torah the other yokes of mundane things are taken from him. I heard from David Bronson that he actually experienced this.

 

·

 

The problem with doing everything perfectly is getting nothing right. It is the same with being too smart. The sages tell us that the mother of Shmuel the prophet prayed that her son would be of average intelligence.

 

I always noticed that the really smart kids in high school just never seemed to see the simplest common sense things, and this is in fact the reason why I have spent time explaining a system of learning of just saying each page or paragraph twice and going on. Because people I think are all very close in intelligence. Those who excel probably just have better study habits.

 

·

 

I noticed my friend Barbara never minded confronting evil head on. She would confront her own teachers if she felt they were acting wrong. She told me instead of not saying anything to warn someone from a bad group rather go into detail: for that person joined the group for a reason.

 

All you can do is to go into detail in order to help person be careful if and when the warning signs do arrive. She went to gehinom to sing praises to God.

 

As for myself, I have avoided evil. This is based a lot on the sages that say not to start up with evil people. I admire Barbara’s approach, but she always suffered afterwards. After she had been through some confrontation I would go to her apartment and let me tell you — she was so wiped out she literally couldn't move to clean a thing, this is a person who is usually clean to the nth degree.

 

·

 

The stoics held that there is nothing between good and evil, virtue and sin. Either one is totally good or totally evil.

This point of view is helpful in considering whether to marry someone. Instead of the customary point of view of looking at everyone as having some good and some bad, consider that they are one or the other and try to decide.

 

This is in fact the Torah point-of-view since to the Rambam, when one is mostly good the evil is nullified. So, you really only end up with people that are totally one or the other.

 

Now one problem in the religious world is that objective good and evil get mixed up with ritual. Religious people tend to judge virtue based on how one is in some rituals. But on the other hand, the good thing about torah is that it teaches that there is an objective good and evil. This, however, in recent years, has ceased to be so — in that the religious now tend to believe in moral relativism but still hide in religious looking clothing.

 

·

 

There is such a thing as putting oneself in God's hands. It is not the same as doing nothing. Nor is it seeking advice from dreams, angels, saints or even one's own intuition. It is actively doing nothing until that very second that God makes one know.

 

·

 

The advice that occurs to one when he has gone out into a field to ask God advice is many times different than what he thinks to himself in his usual environment [even when he prays in his normal environment]. The question is which of these to follow. It seems to me that neither is wrong but that that which is received outdoors in seclusion is better.

 

·

 

The subject of advice which comes to one suddenly is subject to a debate between Rav Nachman and Rabbi Yisrael of Koznitz. Rabbi Yisrael said, a mitzvah that comes suddenly is usually from the evil side. Rabbi Nachman, in the story of the Simpleton, has the simple one getting a message from heaven and immediately dropping everything to follow it.

 

·

 

Avoid court-holders [the type you find at every party]. Everyone gathers around them clinging to their every word of “wisdom”. They are invariably those who know nothing — this includes this includes rabbis.



 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Section II - Halachah

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 1 - Principles of Halacha

 

·

 

The commandments of the Bible are forever (as it says in Deuteronomy 29:29). You will find by hundreds of commandments that it says openly that they are forever e.g., the Sabbath. The Talmud is meant to be the code of Jewish law. Therefore, one is allowed to depend on any opinion there within the limits of what the Talmud itself defines as law. For instance, if one is allowed to kiss his sister or any relative, we find a disagreement. The authorities decide one way but since the Talmud itself doesn't decide there is some possibility to be lenient.

 

·

 

The Rambam says we go by the majority only at the time of the Sanhedrin, but in a time that there is no Sanhedrin, concerning biblical law we go by the stricter opinion and concerning rabbinical law we go by the lenient opinion - even against a majority opinion (this is against the Shach in Yore Dea, however one can depend on the Rambam.) We see however that the Rambam didn't use this principle in Mishna Torah. I think perhaps this is because he held the Gemarah has the category of the Sanhedrin. Only in issues which come up after the Gemarah is this principle used, or when there is a disagreement as to what the Gemarah's actual conclusions were.

 

·

 

The way of judging an issue by majority of authorities is a statistical way coming from the world of chaos and probability, while the way of revelation is from the world of correction. So even if you have a tzadik like Rabbi Nachman who reveals things based on his own revelation you still need to judge the issues based on probability and statistics which is from world of chaos since the goal is to put chaos and correction together.

 

·

 

Rabbi Chayim Vital says one who makes a legal decision without the knowledge of the mysteries of the Kabbalah can't make a correct legal decision. This doesn't cancel the Talmud or Maimonides, but it limits their decisions to be in accordance with prophets and kabbalists of Israel.

 

·

 

There are things that God is strict about that the halacha permits and things which He allows that the law prohibits. [It may take a bit of time and talent for the earthly courts to get the law correctly for the general public, but even if they would have it right, they still wouldn't have the law as it applies to each individual correctly.] For instance, the law that a prophet who transgresses the words of his own prophecy gets the death penalty applies to each individual. One has what he knows in his heart to be the right intuition but disobeys it because of advice from friend or even rabbis. Or for instance resting on Shabbat: there are the 39 types of labor forbidden to everyone, however the idea and enjoyment of Shabbat is a highly individual thing.

 

·

 

A possible reason the Torah says a woman can't be a judge is that she will tend to go against the male in a case involving a man and a woman while a male judge will tend to be more impartial since men have a natural sexual attraction to women but also a natural sympathy towards men since they are their own kind. But women have no natural attraction to men in general (they simply aren't turned on by the sight of a male), so they are automatically biased. (i.e., with men the two biases cancel out, but the women are left with only one bias).

 

·

 

Whether or not the rabbis of the Talmud had the authority to make any laws at all is the subject of a debate in Avot DeRabbi Nathan: “Make a fence around the Torah. Make a fence around your words like God made a fence around his words, and Adam made a fence around his words, and the Torah made a fence around its words etc... What caused the woman to touch the tree? The fence that Adam made around his words. Because of this The Rabbis said: ‘If a man makes a fence around his words, he won't be able to keep his words.’ Thus, the Rabbis said, ‘a man should not add to the things he hears.’ Rabbi Yose said, ‘Better 10 inches and it stands than 100 yards and it falls.’ Thus, we find this to be the subject of a debate. What is interesting to note is that in any argument of any rabbis against Rabbi Yose the law is always like Rabbi Yose, but here the general opinion of the Gemara is not like Rabbi Yose – here there was probably a majority opinion against him.

 

·

 

The Rambam gives the principles for the commandments: according to him they are not possibilities but the definite reasons. Thus, according to Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai who holds that when the reason for a commandment doesn't apply the commandment doesn't apply, there will be cases where one should not keep a certain commandment. I think that this wouldn't just apply to specific laws relating to the commandments but even specific situations. The Rambam makes it clear that these situations do exist, for he says that the Torah was given for the general situations but there will always come up situations where the keeping of a law will negate the intention of the law. It seems to me that in such a situation one should not keep the law, as the Sages said, “A sin for the sake of God is greater than a mitzvah not for the sake of God.”

 

The specific intentions of the Law the Rambam states are:

1)     To despise and reduce one's physical desires.

2)     Politeness

3)     Cleanliness in heart, actions, body and dress. [The Guide III, 33] (The Rambam says in The Guide III, 49 that most of the mitzvot called “hukim” are to be a fence against the doctrines of idolatry.

 

In volume III chapter 31, he says that all the mitzvot were given for the following reasons: to teach us some truth or remove some false opinion, to establish a proper society, to stop wickedness, to train in good manners, and to warn against bad habits. In short, opinions, morals and social conduct.

 

From these principles it should be clear what the intent of any specific mitzvah is, and thus in the opinion of Rabbi Shimon [or Rabbi Yehuda to the Yerushalmi and Sifri], when it doesn't apply. Now, it is interesting to note that there is no disagreement in the gemara if in fact the reason for the mitzva not to take a pledge from a widow is not to have to go back to her house every night to return it, and thus cause to her a bad reputation. It is just that rabbi Yehuda says you can't decide to limit the scope of the law because of the reason. So, as to the fact that it is based on reason and to which reason there is no disagreement. So, we see that it is not as if there is just God and then the Law. Rather it is God — Reason, and logic — Law. As the Zohar say, Torah is the shredding of the higher wisdom. Now, this idea doesn't disagree with the Kabbalah that gives deeper significance to the laws, for the ideal significance of the Kabbalah is contained within the logic, i.e., in our case, not to give her [the divine presence] a bad name [falling into exile] among her neighbors [the higher worlds].

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 2 – Prayer

 

 

 

·

 

One should not cover his head for prayer, for the reason the Sages give for covering the head is that people don't stand before a king with their head uncovered. Nowadays one can't stand before a king or with his head covered and it is a sign of disrespect to do so, so all the more so one should not do so in front of God. In Tractate Soferim [Chapter 14, Halachah 15] (which is the root for the law of wearing a head cover to the Gra it says ‘One who is not wearing shoes or whose garments are torn or whose head is not covered is allowed to lead the congregation in prayer up until the 18 blessings. Some say only one who is not wearing shoes or whose garments are torn but one whose head is uncovered is not allowed to. He is not allowed to say the Divine Name... However, to both opinions he can translate but he can't read the Torah scroll for the congregation and lead the congregation for the 18 blessings.” Wearing one at any other time is certainly not required. And that was at the time when it was a sign of respect to wear one in front of a king. Now it is a sign of disrespect. [As the Targum Onkulus says they went out of Egypt with uncovered heads.] However, the Gemara itself does say one shouldn't walk four steps without one's head covered, so even though the Rambam holds that is only for a Wise person still this Gemara does imply that it is a good thing for everyone.

 

·

 

One should endeavor to recite the Shema immediately upon rising, before sunrise, in accordance with the view of Rabbi Eliezer. The Rambam rules that the halachah follows the Sages—who permit its recitation until the end of the third hour of the day—only in a case where one has not managed to say it before sunrise. Nonetheless, one is obligated to strive to say it at that earlier time.

 

At night, one should wait until the time established by Rabbenu Tam, approximately ninety minutes after sunset (according to some opinions, seventy-two minutes). This, however, does not imply that one must don tefillin or recite the Amidah at that moment; those may be performed until the conclusion of the day.

 

In the teachings of Kabbalah, a greater emphasis is placed upon rising at midnight to engage in Torah study. In matters where the Kabbalistic tradition and the legal authorities differ, one should follow the Kabbalistic path. It is told that when the Baal HaTanya was asked about this, he affirmed that one should indeed act in accordance with Kabbalah. When the questioner objected, noting that the Shulchan Aruch HaRav instructs to follow the legal authorities, the Baal HaTanya replied: “That is what the legal authorities wrote.”

·

 

To some opinions brought in the Shulchan Aruch one who is not married is not required to wear teffilin. Yet because the Baal Shem Tov in his will did emphasize saying the Shema exactly as the commandment was meant to be I think one should try to do so. [The five things mentioned in the will of the Baal Shem Tov were:

a.      Learning books of ethics every day.

b.      Carefulness in keeping Shabbat.

c.      Carefulness in saying the Shema.

d.      Going to the mikvah for with the kabalistic intentions.

e.      Doing a kindness for someone every day.

 

·

 

To Rav Yehuda in the name of Shmuel saying the Shema is a rabbinical mitzva. It seems the authorities hold it is Biblical because of the Gemara in Sucah. However, it would seem that since Brachot is the main place of the subject we ought to follow the conclusion of the Gemara there that it is rabbinical.

 

·

 

Grace after bread is possible to shorten. For the first blessing only the first and last sentence are required. [As the Sages said if one says “blessed is the Master of this bread”, he had fulfilled his obligation. However, since a blessing that starts and ends with a blessed can't be changed from that form, one must say as I have said.] For the second one needs to mention only the covenant and the Torah and then the final blessing. For the third one, one needs to mention only the kingdom of David and the last blessing. The fourth needs only the three mentions of goodness and the three mentions of abundance.

 

·

 

The short prayer Havinanu in Brachot can be substituted for the 18 blessings for the evening and afternoon service. The Halachah is like Rabban Gamliel only in so much that one must pray the entire Shemone Esre once a day.

 

·

 

It seems to me that it is better not to say the blessing to curse the slanderers since it doesn't do any good to curse ones enemies and the curse just returns on oneself if he is not worthy on any future day.

 

·

 

Don't pray for a true soul mate for the Rambam says there is no such thing [in the eight chapters (and Rabbi Nachman agrees). So, you just won't get married at all since there is no true mate. Rather man has complete free will to choose who to marry. Only in what happens to one he has no free will, not in things one does.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 3 - Shabbat

 

 

 

 

 

·

 

The reason the halacha is like Rabbenu Tam that the night starts 90 or 72 minutes after sunset is that the Shulchan Aruch and the Magen Abraham, the majority of the Rishonim (1st authorities), Rav Sadia Gaon, and the Arizal all hold like him. (The Radvaz even shows that the Rambam holds like Rabbanu Tam) (72 minutes is if a mil is 18 minutes. 96 is if it is 24 like the Rambam says in the Perush HaMishna. The Chasam Sofer says it is 22.5 so that it comes out 90 minutes. The Maharam Shik brings many authorities like son of the Rambam that say the world is round and he assumes that disproves Rabbenu Tam, yet we find Tosphot Rid in Shabbat says openly that the world is round and yet explains Rabbenu Tam accordingly.

 

Besides this also there is the fact that medium stars don't come out until about 60 min after sunset, and stars continue to come out until about 3 hours after sunset. Now to know the medium sized number of a set of numbers, you have to see all the numbers first. Similarly, to know what a medium star looks like you have to see all the stars first (that the human eye can see). Then after you have seen all the stars at midnight in a place where the small stars aren't obstructed by city lights, like in a desert or the mountains, and you have judged 3 medium stars, then the second night you will find that they don't become visible until about 60 minutes after sunset.

 

This is according to the majority of the authorities, but I don't understand why the Gemara in Shabbat and the Gemara in Pesachim can't just be disagreeing, and both be talking about the first shkia (sunset). Even though most authorities don't go for this kind of thinking, but the Rambam does. He doesn't believe the entire Shas has to be self-consistent [Miguel de Unamuno said, “If a person never contradict's himself, it must be that he says nothing.” Thus, it would seem to me a simple explanation that the Rambam in Hilchot Shabbat is not like Rabbanu Tam even though the Radvaz says it is. So, I tend to think it is better to be strict and accept Shabbat at the first sunset but not do work on Saturday night until 90 minutes.

 

·

 

Carrying in a public domain is forbidden.  But one can depend on Rashi and the  Tosphot  that a public domain is only one in which 600,000 people travel through daily. (In a case of need one can depend on a lenient opinion even in a biblical matter.) [However, the Rambam doesn't hold this way, so it is preferable not to carry even in the place where there is an eruv which is worthless if it actually is a public domain. To the Rambam in fact even a lonely dirt road between two cities is a public domain Biblically and carrying there four steps is against the Torah. However, I do believe that one can depend on Rashi and Tosphot whose opinion is brought in the Shulchan Aruch as a “Some say”. Apparently, Rabbi Yoseph Karo himself didn't want to make a final decision in this case. Perhaps because the Rambam holds you don't need 600,000 and the Rosh holds you do, and the Rif isn't clear. So, the Beit Yoseph couldn't use his normal method of using the majority of these three authorities. But if we continue his method of going in that case to the other authorities then the majority do hold by Rashi.

 

·

 

Playing a musical instrument on the Sabbath is permitted. People in general are not experts in making musical instruments, so the reason for the rabbinical decree doesn't apply (i.e., that people might fix the instrument if it breaks.). This is in accordance with the opinion of the Rashbam and Raavad that once the reason for a decree doesn't exist the decree is automatically null and void. And even to the Rambam one can apply this (as it says in the book Or Zarua Le Tzadik of Rabbi Zadok HaCohen in Chapter 2). The reason he gives there is the same as the Rosh in the beginning of Avoda Zarah. The amazing thing is that the Rosh assumes a law made by the Sanhedrin only applies in the time and place it was meant for.

 

·

 

It is allowed to use electricity on Shabbat. It is not fire. Nor is it Tikun Mana. (Each time you turn on your TV, you are not making a new TV set). However, one is not allowed to do any type of labor with it — like cooking.

 

·

 

One is allowed to write on the computer on the Shabbat since the letters are not Ashurit (Hebrew script) and the letters are not stored in the viable form. So, this is a case of two rabbinical decrees — one against the other — and therefore allowed. Drawing on the computer on Shabbat however is forbidden.

 

[The Shulchan Aruch says that to purchase land in Israel, one is allowed write up the documents on the Shabbat — since he is writing in a different language than Hebrew. However, the fact that it is a different language wouldn't be enough since that is forbidden rabbinically. However, the rabbinical prohibition is permitted in this case.]

 

·

 

Paper money is allowed to be handled on the Sabbath since it isn't in the category of what the Gemarah calls “maot” [coins] it is rather in the category of Business documents which one isn't allowed to read. (This is like the Rambam. However many other Rishonim hold business documents are muktzah.) The only permission to handle coins that I know of is Rashi on page 143a of Shabbat that the bones there are “hard and not fit for a dog” and rav Nachman in the gemara says that is the opinion of Beit Hillel. [There is the other Stam Mishna on page 142b, which obviously holds coins are muktza — so we have stam against stam.]

 

·

 

Brushing teeth on the Shabbat with toothpaste is permitted. The melachah where some people get the idea that it is prohibited from is the melachah of smoothing dirt or some substance over a surface like a stove to cover it up which has nothing to do with brushing teeth.

    

·

 

Things that are forbidden on the Shabbat sewing cooking [heating food to over 160 Fahrenheit] carrying anything from an area surrounded by three walls to a public domain where 600,000 people pass daily. To the Rambam a public domain is any road that is 16 amot [32 feet] wide even if that many people don't pass daily. Writing in Hebrew [I imagine the old Ivri script is also forbidden since the Gemara says the Torah was given in that script. The Torah was given in Ivri script but in the Hebrew language. Eventually the Jewish people decided on the Ashuri script. Some Medieval authorities think that this Gemara isn't literal and want to say that the Torah was given in Ashuri script, but it seems to me that it is about as clear as you can get.]. Carrying anything in a public domain four amot [8 feet] [Clothing and jewelry that is worn is permitted. Separating the chaff from the wheat.

 

·

 

It is forbidden to go to the mikvah on Friday  afternoon since that is the time the klipot gather to try to come into holiness and the place they do this is the mikvah.For this reason it is forbidden to pray in a synagogue which is the place of the klipot in general since the klipot try to find the places of holiness and to enter people that go there.

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 4 - Festivals

 

·

 

According to Abayee, the second day of the festival is not a rabbinical law, but from the doubt that the exiles had about the day they were extra stringent on themselves. We hold this way in Halachah and therefore in places where the messengers from the Sanhedrin in Jerusalem can reach by the fifteenth of the month, we only do one day of the festival… Now there are airplanes so automatically there is no reason to do the second day of the festival. [This however is only to Abayee but to Rav Asi it is a Rabbinical law.] Now it seems to me that this could apply to Rosh Hashanah. We can't depend on our calculations, but after the Sanhedrin sanctifies the new moon a simple phone call or e-mail from Israel, could tell us when the new moon was. Now even though the Cuttim could hack in to the computer still the Sages never made it a law that you can't depend on other direct knowledge from Israel. They did say you have to know the messenger, but couldn't you know the person on the phone too?! Thus, it seems to all the halachic authorities that go by Abayee that there is no second day of the festival. However, the Yerushalmi in Eruvin says the second day of Rosh Hashanah is a law from the prophets, and the Zohar also is pretty clear about this. So, I think we still have to keep two days of Rosh Hashanah.

 

·

 

On Yom Kippur one is allowed to eat the amount ½ of an average egg every 4 minutes. If you go by the Noda   BeYehuda that would be the size of a full egg since he said that the eggs nowadays are half the size that the eggs the Talmud used to measure things. I don't recommend using this opinion to depend on. However, drinking is a different story. The amount one is allowed to drink is very small, i.e., the amount one can hold in one cheek of his own mouth. This is less than a teaspoon. However, to the Raavad one can drink this every 10 seconds. I think one can depend on this.

 

·

 

The Gemarah says, “One who reads the Megillah between the other writings (Bibles with pages like our Bibles) has not fulfilled his obligation but this is only if he read it in a congregation but not individually.” That is, if he reads it at home for himself or his family he has fulfilled his obligation [see the Mordechai at the end of Megilah.]

                                                                  


 

 

Chapter 5 - Kashrut

 

·

 

The Rashba in a tshuva was asked about a certain food that was specifically mixed with something not Kosher but the amount of the non-Kosher stuff in it was less than . He wrote that it is permitted. This gets rid of the need for a stamp of Kashrut on a lot of products.

 

·

 

The Gemara in Avoda Zara says that the cheese of idolators is permitted and this is brought down as the halachah by the Rif Rambam Tur Shulchan Aruch. Concerning the vessels, it was prepared in, the Rosh in Chulin Chap. 8, Sec. 42 says there is nothing to worry about.

 

·

 

Meat biblically does need to be prepared in a kosher manner. Chicken also needs to be prepared in a kosher manner, but it is only by rabbinical decree.

 

 

 

 

Chapter 6 - Israel

 

·

 

One should not go to live in Israel when it is surrounded by enemies who want to destroy it. The issue is what to do when it will be peaceful. The Rambam and Ramban hold that one should live there even before the Messiah comes. The question however remains about the oath in the Song of Songs not to go up as a wall which certainly seems to be the case in the creation of a state.

 

Experience has shown that the oath is still in place since the end of the oath has been a constant factor there (i.e., “I foreswear you not to go up as a wall and if not, I will make your blood free for all.”)

 

·

 

The Satmer Rav [Reb Yoel Teitelbaum] allowed his followers to live there as long as they would have nothing to do with the State. But there is no person in Mea Shearim who doesn't receive directly into his bank account money from the Bituach Leumi. The religious, as much as they hate the non-religious there, have exactly the same mentality. One can't help but be influenced by the place he lives in.

 

·

 

There is a tremendous flow of light there, for which reason it makes sense to visit, but not to stay, since you are only theoretically a citizen but not actually. It is the equivalent now of living in a foreign country with the disadvantage that you think it's your people while actually they see you as you really are a citizen of the country you came from.

 

·

 

Don't give up your family, your religion, your mate, your friend, or your country so fast. There may be times when it is necessary but then only under extreme duress. Rabbi Abba hid from Rav Yehuda because he wanted to go to Israel, and Rav Yehudah said that whoever goes to Israel is transgressing a positive commandment as it says, “They will be brought to Babylon and there they will be until I visit them says the Lord.” So, it's one of those things that some authorities say is a good thing, others say it is not, and in such a case its up to the individual to decide for himself. This is one of those vast areas in Torah where free will is given but in orthodox theology there is complete denial that these areas exist. This is one of the most essential points of this book - the fact that there is such a thing as free will even within the confines of the Torah- not free-will between good and evil but free will between two equally good things - and what you should do is dependent on your character and your individual mission in life. Within the strict confines of the Talmud, it is possible to permit just about anything and to forbid just about anything and both ways are correct, one way is from kindness and the other from strict judgement. Many people are somewhere in the middle.

 

·

 

But the truth is we have to rise above good and evil into the realm of truth and light and beauty [which is the combination of truth and light-truth is the vessel that contains light] by development of one's soul and raising it to that level.

 

·

 

The Torah requires you to do what your inner heart says in order to bring up the good in klipat noga and the darkness should disappear by the drawing of the light (here there are two kinds of good, the good on the level of good and evil; permitted and forbidden; pure and impure, and the other type of good on the level of higher light where evil is just lack of that light).

 

·

 

Listening to one's heart isn't just good advice, it is a positive commandment. For the voice of the inner heart is small prophecy and a prophet is required to obey his own prophecy whether he likes it or not.

 

God is strict about the laws of the Bible, but that strictness isn't about keeping the laws in the way they apply in general rather it's about how they apply to you alone — as we see you singular is the noun of many of the commandments.

 

God's code of law applies differently to each person.

 

[Two other major things that God is strict about are keeping what you promise to do for God in time of stress and emergency. He doesn't like it if when the danger goes away, you forget about your promise. The other thing, is things revealed in a dream]

 

·

 

I think according to the way I see God runs the world that one should go to Israel for extended visits, but always retain connection with the country of originates. For instance, one can go for let's say three years and then come back. Then go back again. The reason is that parts of the Divine presence are still in exile so this connection with one's native land can't be broken even if he wants it to. The holiness of the land of Israel is still covered by the klipot and the reason for this is that parts of the Divine Presence are still in exile and needs its corrections in those places of exile.

 

·

 

The Arabs don't recognize any fundamental right of the Jewish people to a state with well-defined borders. There is no way that a faithful Muslim can accept that since it is a basic principle of the Koran that land once under Islamic rule can never be ruled again by non-Muslims and it is a sacred obligation of every muslim to sacrifice his life to bring that land back to Muslim rule. Therefore, there can never be peace until the Muslims give up the Koran.

 

·

 

[Shavuot 16a]

 

Rabbi Eliezer held the first Holiness was only as long as the Jewish people stayed there. This is the halacha to all authorities. Rav Huna held that the holiness of the land of Israel needs to be established by a King and the Urim and Tumim. The halacha is like Rav Huna to all the authorities. Tosphot puts these two together and comes up with the idea that teruma and maaser nowadays is only rabbinical, not biblical. This means in plain english that to this opinion the holiness of the land of Israel nowadays is only rabbinical, not biblical. Thus, even if we concede to the Ramban that there is a biblical mitzvah of living in Israel [which the Rambam doesn't hold with anyway] still who says you can fulfill it nowadays by living in Israel. Biblically speaking Israel isn't holy, only rabbinically, at least according to this last way of thinking... However, there are opinions that it is Biblically holy also

 

·

 

None of these reasons would be sufficient to cause one not to live in Israel except that Jesus said when you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies get up and leave. This advice saved the original Jewish church in Jerusalem for at first the Roman armies came and surrounded Jerusalem and then the general was called back to Rome. At that point the church remembering Jesus' words got up and left for Pele in Jordan. Then the Roman armies returned and destroyed Jerusalem. Even though Jesus said this then it seems to me that the same advice would apply today. [The idea of Jesus was that Israel doesn't have the light of political stability. That light seems to be particular to America].

 

·

 

Certain ideas don't resonate with certain groups of people. This is the reason for the failure of American foreign policy throughout the world. Things like freedom of the press or democracy simply don't resonate with Arabs. However, statements like “Death to the Jews” or ideas of Arab hegemony over the entire region do. It makes a great deal of sense to me that Israel has to deal with Arab uprisings the same way Arab countries do within their own borders.

 

It is true that with Arabs in countries like America ideas like freedom do resonate more because they are becoming americanized, but in the Middle East the idea of freedom has no emotional weight or moment of inertia. It can come and go as easily as the breeze. Even though the land of Israel was promised to the Jewish people God never receded his blessing to give it to Ishmael also who was born after God promised to give it to Abraham's children. This is especially obvious in the Targum where it says “children” in the plural. God only said that he would take it from the Canaanites. And the blessing that Ishmael was included in referred to the land from the Nile to the Euphrates. Which in fact is occupied by the dependents of Ishmael. The later promises to the children of Israel in the desert specified very definite boundaries quite limited to the present region. And further it is even more interesting that the two present tribes that the Jewish people consist of (Judah and Benjamin) are the most populated areas of Israel (Jerusalem and the surrounding area).

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 7 - Marriage and Family

 

·

 

There are five colors of blood that are unclean, and the other colors are pure even if they are red. To the Shulchan Aruch, the Rambam and the Rif and the Rosh and all the major authorities the women of today aren't niddot because they don't have the feeling of the opening of the womb to let out blood.

 

Rav Natrunai Gaon wrote that a nidah  needs to go to the mikveh for marriage relations only as a rabbinical decree. It is Biblical only if she goes into the Temple in Jerusalem. So, we have a lot of doubts piling up one on the other all in a case of what the major authorities consider to be not unclean in the first place since there is no feeling of the opening of the womb. That is: maybe it is a red that is clean. But if you'll say it is a red that is not perhaps the law is like the majority of authorities that without feeling it isn't unclean. But if you'll say the halachah is like the Noda BeYehuda that a feeling of something flowing inside is also considered a feeling, perhaps the law is like Rav Netrunai Gaon.

 

So, there are a lot of reasons to say that after seven days she is pure immediately without going to the mikvah. But its better to go to a natural body of water or a mikvah if possible. Anyway, to have good children the sex should be only on the Sabbath night (Friday night). After true midnight, after the mikvah. This applies only to when it's possible for children to come from the union. The main thing is for one to attach himself/herself to God while having sex and not to fall into physicality, rather spirituality. [You could say also that she doesn't even have to wait at all because of the first reasons]

 

·

 

A man can marry two or more wives. The Cherem of Rabbenu Gershom was only until the year 1240 AD, as it says in the Shulchan Aruch, Even Haezer (however, in a country where this isn't allowed, the marriages shouldn't be on paper).
