The Gaon from Vilna said that to allow this would hasten the redemption for it would bring into the world all the souls that need to be born before the redemption and he said if he would have the strength, he would go from congregation to congregation to tell them this.

 

·

 

A swimming pool is a good mikveh if it's plugged up so that nothing leaks - this is biblically speaking, but rabbinically, a natural body of water is better.

 

·

 

Extra-marital sex is allowed as long as it is in the boyfriend-girlfriend form, not one-night stands.

 

A mistress (i.e., girlfriend) is allowed according to the majority of the first authorities (i.e., one need not be married to have sex - Ramban, Raavad, Rosh, the Rambam according to the Ramban). There is teshuva of a later authority that allows it. However, kabbalistically speaking, it’s better to be married, because a mistress is on the level of the tree of knowledge of good and evil upon which the klipot can take hold -- which they do anyway for sensual sex even in marriage, but not being married makes the sex a bit more prone to them.

 

·

 

Birth control like the pill is allowed. The condom is forbidden according to Rabbenu Tam. For the Gemara (Yevamot) says “three women have sex with a thick cloth in order not to become pregnant” since it could result in their death if they would become pregnant. Rashi explains they can put the towel there before sex. Rabbenu Tam says after sex. Rashi says they are allowed to while Rabbenu Tam says they must.

 

So far for other women there is no permission to use a cloth at the time of sex. Those that are looking for a permission want to explain the Ritvah as meaning the towel is there at the time of sex and they must, implying that other women can. (See the Tshuva of Rabbi Abraham Shneur Zalman and the New edition of the Ritvah.) But the Ritva it says clearly that the three are required while others are sometimes allowed, eg. before they are twelve years old, and others are forbidden, e.g., girls older than twelve and a half. However, it seems to me to ask a simple question according to the opinion of Rashi: If a condom would be under the prohibition of spilling seed in vain then how could sex be allowed even for those three women? Shouldn't they simply not have sex? It seems to me from this that the prohibition isn't that of spilling seed but of the positive command to be fruitful and multiply and that is why the whole discussion in Tosphot revolves around that. So even though this whole thing is only like Rabbi Meir against the majority opinion it does seem that there is someone to depend on so I would have to allow it in case of necessity even though in all probability it may be considered spilling seed in vain to the opinion of the majority. [As the Gemara says,”Rabbi Meir is great enough to depend on in an emergency”.]

 

·

 

A wife isn't allowed to leave her husband except in a case where there is violence. Just not liking him or his not being religious enough or too much, etc., are not valid reasons. This is like the case which the Rema talks about when the husband was playing cards and desecrated the Sabbath, etc., and the Rema said the wife has no right to demand a divorce. Where the divorce is granted in such a case by peer pressure brought upon the husband it’s a get mu'usa (a forced divorce) which is invalid. It may be advisable for people who don't want this problem to depend on the mistress opinion and not have a full kiddushin.

 

·

 

Marriage (kiddushin) is with two witnesses. However, according to the Ran [Rabbanu Nissim] on Kiddushin 16b, the Rambam holds that kiddushin by writing doesn't need two witnesses.

 

·

 

Chupa is bringing into the wife into the husband’s living quarters, which needs no witnesses according to the Beit Shmuel in Shulchan Aruch. Ten people are necessary only for the seven-blessings. Sex is allowed without the blessings. The midrash says that angels are valid witnesses. At any rate, in conclusion, to get married in a Kosher way without witnesses one needs to do the Kidushin in writing and then to bring the bride into the husbands domain.

 

·

 

Oral sex is forbidden since it is the equivalent of masturbation which the Zohar calls the worst sin in the Torah and that he who does so goes to the bottom of hell and stays there forever [unless he goes to the grave of Rabbi Nachman and says there the ten psalms]. The girl that does that to a boy gets the same sin.

 

·

 

The Gemara in Yevamot 76b says that King Solomon converted the daughter of Pharaoh. Tosphot  explains a later question of the Gemara to be, how could he have married her since she was a first generation Egyptian; and answers that he didn't really marry her but “attached himself to her for love” in the way of love, not in the way of marriage. Rashi explains that the Gemara asks how can the verse call it marriage. And it answers that he intended it to be in the way of prostitution. The Maharsha asks on Rashi then why was the Gemara forced to say she converted since it could have been “in the way of prostitution” without it.

 

 

I think Rashi's reasoning must have been like this: A girlfriend is permitted to a King to all opinions [the argument of the first authorities only applies to everyone else]. The Gemara in Avoda Zara 36 says that to the Rabbis opinion, marriage with the seven Canaanite nations is forbidden; and there was a later rabbinical decree to forbid all idolators.

 

To Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai all idolators are forbidden to live with in the way of marriage from the Torah [but real kidushin isn't applicable] and the Beit Din of Shem forbid even to live with them in the way of prostitution.

 

It seems clear to me that Solomon held like Rabbi Yehuda in Bava Kama 115a since he depended on the fact that the verse gave a reason why the king shouldn't marry many wives, so he depended on the idea that if the reason doesn't apply the law doesn't apply. Thus, the daughter of Pharaoh would have been forbidden to him even not in the way of marriage unless he converted her.

 

Tosphot it seems holds like the Rabbis. So, she would have been permitted to him without converting, even as an idolator as long as it wasn't in the way of marriage or publicly. Then the question of the Gemara begins only after he converted her. [Incidentally Rabbi Shimon is the Tana in the Yerushalmi that says Solomon didn't marry her but intended her as a “girlfriend” like Rashi.] Rabbinical law only applies in a place and time that there is a possibility of transgressing the biblical law - this is a general principle throughout the whole Talmud. Specifically, reading from a light on Yom Kippur is permitted because there is no fear one will come to tilt. Rav sent to his non-Jewish friend in Babylon a present since he knew that he wasn't an idolator and the Rosh and Ritva explain the laws pertaining to non-Jews in general only pertain in places where there are idolators. Thus, since the seven Canaanite nations are no longer common among us [and to the Rambam no longer exist] to the rabbis marrying even an idolator is permitted. To Rabbi Shimon marrying an idolator is forbidden but marrying a non -Jew who isn't an idolator is permitted.

Rabbi Shimon held in general that there is a logical basis for each commandment and in a case where that basis doesn't apply the commandment doesn't apply as in Bava Kama 115a where he says one can take as a pledge the garment of a rich widow since the law of the Torah of not taking the garment of a widow should logically apply only to a poor widow for the reason given there in the Gemara. This isn't the Halacha but there are many cases where we depend on Rabbi Shimon in a case of need in other opinions of his and we say “Rabbi Shimon is great enough to depend on in case of need” as in new grain before the Omer outside of Israel.

 

·

 

The Gemara (Nedarim 20) says, “The halacha is not like Rabbi Yochanan ben Dahavai,” i.e., in everything he said or just the last things. [Rabbi Yochanan Ben Dahavai said not to have sex face to back or to kiss in that spot or to talk at that time or to look at that spot. Rabbi Yochanan said the halacha is not like Rabbi Yochanan ben Dahavai, rather anything a person wants to do with his wife he can do. Most authorities hold Rabbi Yochanan meant the halacha is not like him only concerning face to back but the Rambam holds it refers to everything he said.

 

It would seem to me this may explain the Gemara in Nidda that the house of Munbaz had sex during the day light and the Sages praised them because there was a necessity in their case. If we are deferring to necessity perhaps that implies a wider range of permission than the other authorities held from. However, from here we don't get permission for sex with a light on at night which the Gemara specifically forbids. [Obviously Yaakov Avinu held by this for otherwise why didn't he know that she was Leah, not Rachel]?! Just sex in the daytime or the other things referred to would be permitted. I think there may be some permission for candle-light for other opinions outside the gemara for this the Mishnah seems to imply explicitly. But I haven't found any such permission yet. And even if I would, the Gemara clearly doesn't hold by it. I vaguely recall some Yerushalmi that may have implied so much.

 

·

 

If the mother or father transgress the Torah one is not obligated to honor them to the Samag and the Tur. The Rambam holds however that one is still obligated to honor them. However, if they transgress knowingly the Torah, even the Rambam would agree. The first category is not talking about wicked people it's simply like citizenship: people that don't keep the Torah are not in the category of “your people”; obligations the Torah imposes on citizens of the Torah don't apply. But people that transgress the Torah knowingly are much worse than not being citizens but are considered enemies of the state. I wish to add that when the mitzvah of honoring one’s parents does apply, the Yerushalmi calls it the severest of the severe of all the mitzvot. I highly advice children to honor their parents no matter how bad they may be, but if there is a case where the child simply needs to protect himself from a destructive parent, then the child simply, should not speak to the parent at all and live elsewhere.

 

·

 

The modern ideas of women's lib are against the Torah. The woman is obligated by the Torah to listen to her husband. He is not obligated to listen to her. Though it is advisable to honor her, there is no obligation halachically speaking. As Tosphot says in the beginning of Meshechta Ketubot, “The woman is the field [property] of the husband, and the husband is not the field”. If she refuses to do the three basic types of work and the five additional ones according to the Rambam she is beaten by order of the court until she complies. [Mishna Torah, Hilchot Ishut, 2].

 

If she wants a divorce under these circumstances, then the divorce is invalid since it is forced and not in accord with the law.  The reason for these laws is simple.The male or female soul is not an entity in itself, and the popular idea of individuality simply extinguishes the individual soul. There is no such thing as a connection with another person as long as all that matters is one's own benefit.

 

The idea of each person respecting the individuality of the other is a lot of garbage. The human soul is buried so deep that the only way of finding it and expressing it is in connection with others. The expression of the individual can only exist when it is part of the whole - for then the divine light has a whole vessel to come upon. [And thus, the individual divine light that is the center of her soul can only come if she is connected with him.]

 

·

 

The fabric of society is the family. Since the bonds that bind husband and wife together are dissolved in spirituality [Zeir and Nukvah], they can't exist in physicality. Thus, America needs to return to being a Judeo-Christian society. However, those spiritual bonds have been broken for 2000 years. The reason families have still survived is because of the righteous that bind together the upper husband and wife. At any rate it would be logical to assume from this that saying the midnight prayer would help to get one and keep one married to his/her proper mate. But this is only possible not necessarily so since in the general surrounding light those bonds may no longer exist.

 

 

 

 

Chapter 8 - Learning Torah

 

 

 

 

·

 

One is not allowed to learn Torah having in mind to use it for a living. However, it is proper to learn Torah and to trust in God to provide in a way that he shouldn't be using the Torah or be receiving charity as both are forbidden. Rabbi Israel Salanter held that it is allowed to be a rabbi (and to earn money thereby) so it seems he depended on the Tashbatz even though it is against the Rambam.

 

·

 

The disagreement between the Rambam and the Tashbatz is if one is allowed to learn Torah and depend on the idea that he will be given charity. The Tashbatz permits this. However, one is not allowed to say one verse or one word of Torah in order to make money. This is forbidden to all opinions, and one that does so has no portion in the next world. This includes the idea of taking a test in order to show that one knows some subject in Torah in order to get a kollel paycheck.

 

·

 

Women are not allowed to learn Torah as the Rambam, Rif, Rosh, Tur and Shulchan Aruch write. The Talmud quotes Rabbi Eliezer the Rabbi of Rabbi Akiva: “It's better for words of the Torah to be burned than to be given into the hands of women.”

 

·

 

There is an obligation of saying the parsha [section] of the Torah of each week twice and the Aramaic translation once. The way to do this is saying the section of every day once and then the Aramaic during the week. Then on Shabbat to say the entire parsha once. There is no need to say the Aramaic before the second saying of the Hebrew.


 

 

 

Chapter 9 - Converts to Judaism

 

·

 

To become Jewish a woman needs only to go to the mikveh for the sake of

getting married, or for nida, to clean herself from her cycle.

 

·

 

If a non-Jewish woman goes into the mikveh or ocean for the sake of getting married to a Jew or to purify herself she automatically becomes Jewish as Rav Asi said in the Gemarah in Yevamot (the second way is as Rashi explains there).

 

·

 

Someone not believing in God, or the Oral and Written Law is not Jewish, no matter if their parents are Jewish.

—     Rambam in the Commentary to Sanhedrin

 

·

 

The Rambam says in the Commentary on the Mishna in Sanhedrin that one who believes in the 13-Principles-of-Faith is in the category of Israel and it is a mitzva to love him even if he does all the sins he can possibly do. I think the Rambam means that he is in the category of Israel but not actually Jewish until he goes into the mikvah [as per the Talmud and Mishna Torah].

 

To Rav Sadiah Gaon the main principles are three: God's existence, that he is one, and reward and punishment. To Rav sadiah Gaon it is easy to see that many non Jews can come under the category of Israel.

 

 

Chapter 10 - Non-Jews

 

·

 

The non-Jews in the USA aren't idol worshipers. The Rashba and the Meiri held the Christians are in the category of gerei toshav. Even if you don't go that far the Rambam held they are not idolators. The Tosphot at the beginning of Avodah Zara also says that the christians aren't idolators. The reason this is relevant is that there is not, and never was, any rabbinical decree not to marry a non-Jew who isn't an idolator.

 

·

 

To the rabbis in the Gemara in Avodah Zara 36b, the Biblical law is only not to marry anyone from the 7-Canaanite nations and the rabbinical decree is not to marry any idolators. To Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai, who the halachah is like in this case, the Biblical law not to marry any idolators [“All those who induce to idolatry…”] and the rabbinical decree is not to have sex with them outside of marriage [this doesn't expand the law horizontally to include more people than the Torah forbids rather vertically to increase the degree of strictness. The law is like Rabbi Shimon in this case since the later authorities go like him. Thus, there is no law against marrying a non-Jew who doesn't worship idols]. In neither opinion is there any law against marrying a non­Jew who isn't an idolator.

 

Rabbi Shimon specifically refers only to idolators and expands the law to include not having sex with them even out of marriage. To the rabbis in the first opinion the Biblical law is only the seven nations, and they expand it to include all idolators. Even though the language of the Gemara is “idolators” I think the rabbis forbid all non-Jews because otherwise who is the Braita in Mesechet Gerim that says marrying a Ger Toshav is forbidden, unless you want to say that is the opinion of Rabbi Meir that a Ger Toshav accepts on himself only not to eat non-kosher meat. [You could answer this in a thousand ways, but they are relevant to the Halacha which to them also doesn't apply after the seven nations aren't around anymore, as the Rambam says, so to them the whole rabbinical law is null and void since the situation it was made to guard against is non-existent.

 

·

 

However, there is one more decree specifically not to marry a Samaritan for the specific reason mentioned in Rashi Shabbat 16b [see Mesechet Gerim] which only applies to them, since legally they are Jewish, but they don't keep the mensural laws properly. This simply doesn't apply to non-Jews.

 

·

 

The Baal Shem Tov and the entire school of Chasidut are pretty regular in saying that the desire for money is equivalent to idolatry and I believe they mean it more than a platitude, but as a halachah. Even though this may be hard to decide in a court of law, but I think they believed anyone who loves money has the halachic definition of an idolater. The implication is that even a religious Jew can come into this category.

 

·

                                                                                                                          

It is permitted to walk into a Catholic church even though there are statues there since the Gemara says in Avodah Zara 43b that the father of Shmuel and Levi used to go to a synagogue where there was a statue and weren't afraid that perhaps people would misconstrue their intentions (both Rashi and the Rosh explain that that statue wasn't just for beauty but rather was an idol). However, it seems to me that it is better not to go there, for it still is better not to pray in a place where there are idols.

 

 

 

Chapter 11 – The Argument between the Gra and the Chassidim

 

 

 

·

 

The argument of the Gra (Rabbi Eliyahu from Vilna) and the chasidim has always been beyond my reach because he (the Gra) really did say they (the chasidim) are klipat noga - and looking at them today who can disagree? But the one point I still hold by is that the excommunication wasn't on the Baal Shem Tov but the disciples of HaMagid (Rabbi Dov Ber from Mezritsh).

 

·

 

I still can't answer the defenses of the Baal Hatanya who wrote that the excommunication was against those who disrespected those who learn Torah and the words of the Sages and he wrote, “I know that I do not disrespect those who learn Torah, nor the words of the Sages,  i.e., even if the excommunication may have applied to many or even all of his chasidim he knew it didn't apply to him.

 

·

 

The truth be told, the excommunication of the Gra was outside the limits of the halachah -- to excommunicate half the Jewish people without even bringing them to court. The Gra held it was migdar milsa (the need of the hour) but further he may have had some type of Divine Spirit that in fact something was wrong there. So, if the excommunication applies, it any in any case couldn't have applied to Rabbi Nachman for neither he nor his parents were disciples of the Magid which were the specific target of the excommunication (in any case, I made a beit din by Shmuel HaNavi to nullify it.)

 

This is the spiritual uncertainty principle in action. If you look at either, they become a particle and the argument is clear and one is right and the other wrong but if you don't look, and totally ignore it they become waves that reinforce each other in certain things and destructively interfere in others. For instance, to learn Torah you have to be connected to the Gra. “No Gra means no Torah”. [Chasidish Torah is just to show that they learn Torah but it's not Torah.]

 

Any connection with chasidim will interfere. To have real prayer, i.e., private prayer you have to be connected to Rabbi Nachman. Now, in order to solve this and try to get both flows, this will cause both flows to become particles and lose their connection to the light. [Unless both can be fitted into the vessels of Tohu.]

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Section III - LIFE

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 1 - Family

 

“Parents, do not irritate your children or they will lose heart.” -- Colossians 3:21

 

·

 

Ones close friends and family are part of one's soul. To cut them off is to put oneself at risk of cutting off a vital organ. Children leaving their parents home at the age of 18 are in general making a mistake, for the soul isn't ripe then and should still be attached to the tree. Every family is a tree. One can't cut himself off from any part of it without dire danger to himself. This refers to spiritual families where there is love, not to merely physical families.

 

Families are the 10 sephirot:

God, Father, Mother and the children. The true friends are the makifim (outer light). Enemies are the klipot caused by the breaking of the vessels, if they have some reason for their hatred. If not, they are from the empty space from which God removed his Presence in order to create the world.

 

·

 

Eighteen is a very bad age to leave the home for the light from one's father which is the outer light doesn't come strongly until the age of twenty and it’s that outer light which is the strongest protection. Eighteen-year-olds don't realize they are considered a resource. So many institutions do everything possible to take them away from their parents physically and spiritually, which cuts them off from their roots and kills them (spiritually and sometimes physically), and sometimes that kills the parents also.

 

·

 

In general, if the two parents are living together for the reason of love, then the children should not leave the home to live in a different state. For two people living together from love have more to teach their children than all the schools put together.

 

·

 

The root of not getting along with parents starts from the brothers and sisters. One must get along with his brothers and sisters with absolute self-sacrifice. Siblings aren't people who would automatically be friends. Usually they are completely different, but they have a common root. Therefore, they must try to go beneath surface appearance to that common root.

 

·

 

For major decisions in ones life, one should have a meeting of his close family and friends to discuss it. (This idea is from George Fox.) I don't believe in asking rabbis or clergy for advice for they will always give advice in such a way that will get you sucked into their particular version of their particular religion. Look, it’s their way of making a living - can you blame them? But if you don't want to make a mess of your life, take count of all the people who love you sincerely or who have stuck themselves out on a limb for you, (i.e., family and real friends), find the majority opinion on any major issue affecting your life and stick with it. The idea applies only if they do love you and not just a relationship of convenience.

 

·

 

Nowadays there is no pact [contract] between parents and children to stick together. But there should be. Just because society has forgotten what it means to have families stick together doesn't mean you have to. The commitment to stick together provides a makif (an outer protective light) that can ward off the klipot, just like marriage. (The commitment in a society to stick together also provides its unique type of makif (surrounding protective light) and that is the spiritual source of political systems.) Monarchy, democracy, theocracy, communism, socialism, republicanism, which are from the 6 sephirot, Kindness, Power, Beauty, Eternity, Splendor, and Royalty.

 

·

 

The idea of family is to stay with each other through the ups and downs (i.e., since in every family there are going to be periods that each individual member goes nuts, that is the time every other member has to stick with them. As the Sages said, “accept and exist” -- i.e., accept what comes at you, lower your head and let the wave pass over, and then you will be able to stand).

 

·

 

Commitment to sticking together as a family is an ideal which seems at first glance to cancel out all other ideals since there is always lot of inertia to prevent one from the direction, he thinks he must take; however, I think that the temptation to separate is in general a test of the evil side, and only if one stays firm, does he really come to that which he must (without breaking up the family). [It's always good to have lots of inertia. Some things need to be done but it's always good to sit on every major change for a long time. When I was in Kiev and my black friend John Jackson was with me, I remember some incident that I wanted to call the police about and he said no, wait. And we waited and it turned out ok in fact. I've never had an experience with the police anytime that they didn't make things worse.]

 

For Parents

 

·

 

Rabbi Nachman said, “He who doesn't have compassion on his children has no portion in the intelligence of holiness.” Somehow it strikes me that Einstein gave up his family to advance his career and it's that which did him no good. He had already developed the principles of the general theory of gravitation, and never after that developed another viable theory. And he went to Germany to accept a fancy position there, and eventually they were about to expel him, so the day before that he resigned. Now who are we to judge? Yet it is a bit odd. Maybe he would have made more progress if he had stuck with his wife and kids.

 

·

 

Give your children a relationship, especially when they are teenagers. If you don't get along with them at that age, be rest assured, they will find someone else to get along with and fall into some stupid cult which will be their parent figure. Don't ignore religion and philosophy so your children who will search will be able to talk with you about it.

 

·

 

Your children are your life. You receive flow only to the degree you give flow. In Akudim, Zeir and Nukbah are greater than Abba and Imma, so as we progress towards the final correction many times the children are better than the parents.

 

·

 

There is no such thing as children. Children are just adults that look small, and adults are children who look big.

 

·

 

The only way to rebuke your children is if it hurts you more than it hurts them to do so. Children don't respond to words or deeds but to feelings. Feelings are all that matter in human relationships, therefore there are no rules. If a parent who has no love raises children according to all the rules, the result will not be good. If a parent with love raises his/her children even if he breaks all the rules, the result will be good. Giving a child in to the hands of a parent or guardian who doesn't love the child - is murder.

 

·

 

The force that holds the children around the parents as the Coulomb attraction . For more children, the parents need to include more power from the name 45 and 52, i.e., to include more male and female flow. For seven children, the family gains the character of Nitrogen in connection with one more. A Seven child family is inert like N2, but must avoid any connection with nitroglycerine-people, so that it doesn't form bonds resulting in TNT.

 

·

 

Parents - spend time teaching your children your philosophy or they will get the world-views from elsewhere, i.e., spending time with them to teach math or just to talk isn't the same thing.

 

Teenagers have to be bad. So let them be bad in something not so bad.

When your teen comes home from school and wants to talk, never turn him down even if it is daily for hours. If he can't talk to you, he will find someone else to talk to that won't necessarily be to your liking.

 

Children need your respect more than your love. The key to raising children is to assume as a given [an axiom] that if they say something that it means something. Don't think because you are some big shot parents that their feelings are meaningless. If you do you will eventually find yourself to be meaningless in their lives.

 

·

 

One application of Game Theory in raising children is don't try to impose total authority. Assume as a political leader you can't get total control. But there are areas where you can have some minimal control. Maximize your minimal gains. Don't try to get everything. Try to get the greatest number of small gains. (Especially in a free society where children are well aware of what kind of world they live in and will not respond to a dictatorial parent. This is probably the case in general no matter what kind of environment it is, but in a free society the reaction is more pronounced.

 

·

 

Parents are only parents to the older boy and girl. The older children are the spiritual parents of the younger children.

 

·

 

It’s not good to be authoritarian, only authoritative. The reason is that the evil inclination is divided among the nations of the world and every nation has a different evil inclination [as per the Likutai Moharan]. The evil inclination has to get divided up in every house in a similar way, and only a certain kind of leader can subdue it.

 

·

 

Don't bug your children. Respect your children. They are the same people they will be when they are adults.

 

·

 

If you are angry with your children, this is a sure sign that judgements are dwelling on you. Assume you are wrong.

 

·

 

Rabbi Nachman gave said some advice which I think is particularly appropriate for raising children. One of his major principles was, “Not to be stubborn about anything in the world”, which in Hebrew has a little different connotation than in English. It means not to force any issue with children. Also, he said not to slug them. Which in modern day Breslov is interpreted to mean not to hit them at all but I can't imagine that Rabbi Nachman really meant that. However, it probably is a good idea to not hit at all.

·

For Children

 

·

 

For children let me warn you the worst thing you could ever do to yourselves is to cause your parents pain (emotionally). It's worth it to give up a lot to keep your parents happy - even bad parents. I understand there can be exceptions, but this is a general rule.

 

·

 

One who stands alone without his family will probably fall into some trap the religious and political fanatics of the world like to set for people. This is an important principle in life. (Sometimes a parent can be lacking all parental feelings, and thus be unfit to advise his children, but in the natural scheme, one's best friend will always be one's parents.)

 

·

 

The Sages say that one should hold on to the profession of his father. This in fact is the case in a spiritual way, but the meaning isn't that one should do nothing else, but that one should do something related to his father’s profession or interests.

 

·

 

Your parents provided you with your car and road map. The great saints like Jesus or Rabbi Nachman wrote the road map, and their disciples printed it. But your parents bought and paid for it. So, the saints deserve praise for the general lighting of the road. But you owe your parents for your specific light. Rabbi Nachman implies that the general correction is the most powerful, however both are important.

 

·

 

A person whose life function is analytic (like a sine or cosine) can be expanded into a Taylor series — and therefore one should have children. And since the sine or cosine is periodic he can be represented as a Fourier expansion <???> (A)+S [(a)(sin nx) +(b)(cos nx) from zero to infinity, where the first term is what God gives and the second is from the mother, soul of the mother, soul of the soul of the mother etc., and the last term is from the father, soul of the father, etc. (The reason people’s lives are, in general, sine or cosine functions, is that the life-force drawn into the empty space is an oscillating AC current.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 2 - Marriage

 

 

 

 

 

 

“A hasty attachment is held to be dishonorable, because time is the true test of this as of most other things”

-Plato, the Symposium

 

My bounty is as boundless as the sea,

My love as deep; the more I give to thee,

The more I have, for both are infinite. -Juliet to Romeo

 

·

 

I believe in marriage at young ages — in the teenage years as the Talmud says,

and as was always done by the disciples of the Baal Shem Tov and the Moroccan Jews, and Yemenite Jews. The sepherah of Foundation is the teenage years and therefore the most appropriate time for procreation, as the Talmud says that Rabbah said, “The reason I am better than my friends is because I married at 16, and if I would have married at 14, I would have said ‘an arrow in the eye of the evil inclination’”, i.e. he wouldn't have been afraid of the evil inclination at all. Also, two wives are permitted even to Ashkenazic Jewry — because the decree of Rabbi Gershon was only for a limited time as it says in the Shulchan Aruch.

 

·

 

One can combine the circular and the straight sephirot into one, which results in the name 63 (since yosher and igulim are from 52 and 45) by considering the combination of a point in the igulim and of a point in yosher as one point in the new type of sephirot of 63 and 72 (as a product manifold) I think this is the spiritual process that we are involved with now for in the redemption there will be the name 72 so we must be in one stage before that. This would explain why so many Jews are marrying non-Jews; in order to combine the vessels of tikun with the light if tohu (if the non-Jew goes into a mikvah for the sake of becoming a Jew this is permitted to Rashi and Tospot but not the Rambam who requires three judges.

 

·

 

Many times, one suffers because of one's mate. He should know that the suffering would come upon him anyway even without the mate and therefore getting rid of them won't help. It will only make things worse. But in a harsher form.

 

·

 

A Word to Women

 

A.     All men are either eccentric or evil. So, if you notice your husband is bit different, be pleased you didn't get the other type. This is because truth nowadays is afraid to show its face, so it hides itself in weird personality traits. Evil isn't afraid of anything, so they seem absolutely normal.

B.     Men usually cease to be men after they are married and become “husbands”, so don't be surprised when it happens. As you know, you put out a special effort to be nice during the dating dance, so does he. Men, by nature, put out a tremendous amount of energy in the wooing process, but after they are married that energy just doesn't exist. And a man will always fall back on whatever he was in the first place with all the same quirks and weaknesses that he strove to hide while he was wooing you… This is not an act of deception any more than the mating dance of the bees. It's just a part of nature.

 

·

 

But there may be many right ones like Rachel and Leah where Leah wasn't really meant for Yaakov, but still it worked out well because there was still a true connection. But his real mate was Rachel. [Since true mate is a matter of percentage, one person might be 20% a true-mate and another 50%. As Rabbi Nachman explains, every person may have many people that are connected with him in this way.] Though the Rambam apparently disagrees with the idea of a true mate, this idea of percentages explains it.]

 

·

 

The problem of not finding one's proper mate is the modern-day plague on the entire world. Just like 55 years ago World War II was the plague of the world for no known reason except an inexplicable judgement that came into the world, so today judgement of never finding one’s proper mate has come into the world. (This is how today people are punished for their sins from previous lives.) The more sex is idolized the more the newspapers around the world are filled with “personals” of women who can't find any men and men who can't find any woman. The exception is only the very wicked who God rewards their few good deeds with sexual pleasure in this world in order that they should have no reward in the next. The other exception is the very righteous who sanctify themselves at the time of sex in which case the sexual act becomes a part of their Divine worship.

 

·

 

Men's problem is with lust; women's, with anger; legalize a man's right to be married to two wives and you solve both problems. Dividing responsibilities between two women whether there sexual or maintaining a household would be easier. The man won't be on their nerves the whole time asking for sex or needing to be waited on after a hard day at work. While one woman is a nidah the other would be available for sex. Why be stricter than the Bible? As the Sages of the Talmud say, “There aren't enough things God has forbidden, that we have to find more? If only we would just keep what is already there.”

 

·

 

“All is confounded by all-mastering time; faith dies, distrust is born; and the same spirit is never steadfast among friends; for be it soon or late, men find sweet turn to bitter, and then once more to love.” - Sophocles.

 

So - families should stick together through the ups and downs; they will come out in the end on top. When entering into a marriage one must be totally committed to making it work no matter what. But that isn't enough. You have to be aware of how committed your partner is to you. If it isn't the same degree, then all your commitment won't help. And if they are committed to things about you, but not to you, it also won't work. The only thing that can make a marriage work is that both parties have this commitment and the emotional ability to stick with a commitment.

 

·

 

Those that are devout are attached to the divine trait of Rulership, and therefore there is a flow of children to them as Rabbi Nachman explains in the Lekutai Morahan. That is the meaning of the statement of the Sages that the redemption won't come until all the souls in “spiritual storehouse of souls” will be born, which according to Rabbi Issaac Luria refers to the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil which is the Divine trait of Rulership (this is the reason Rabbi Eliyahu from Vilna said that allowing two wives would hasten the redemption).

 

·

 

“Love is the most powerful force in the world.” -- James Cameron

 

Human emotions are the most powerful forces bending and breaking and building societies, philosophies, ideas, creating and destroying worlds, spiritual and physical. But of all the emotions, love is the most powerful, the highest of the seven lower sephirot (forces), but lower than the three higher ones (fields).

 

·

 

At the time of the revival of the dead they and all those who are supposed to be together will be together - but that can only be accomplished by the readiness to give up one's life for each other in this world. But understanding is also on the level of self-sacrifice which shine upon those that love each other; and that merit isn't just for them but for the correction of the whole world - to create a better world at the time of the revival of the dead so that all loved ones will be able to be together forever in God's light in the physical and spiritual world which will all be one at that time, in the world that will be above time and space.

 

·

 

A deeper way to understand marriage would be to apply it to the two sephirot of Beauty and Royalty. But the Divine Presence has fallen into the klipot, so many women end up marrying some klipah and bringing more klipot into the world unless she can free herself from the evil side. This is the reason it is imbedded in the nature of women to be attracted to money and power.

 

·

 

Marriage in America is particularly unstable. One out of two or three (depending on the area) break down. The Jewish orthodox community which came from Europe took a generation to get “Americanized”, and now their ratio is quickly reaching the same level. Curiously though, in Christian communities where the family attends church regularly the ratio is 1 out of 40. In families where not only do they attend church, but also have daily devotional life and family prayer the ratio is 1 out of 400. These are staggering statistics. While I'm at this I will mention the other curious fact that the healthiest state in the USA is Utah. Now you might want to say that it is because it is in a desert region; but Colorado is the unhealthiest (and it is also in a desert region). The difference would seem to be the difference between the Mormons and Las Vegas. These statistics conform with the idea of Jesus being the Messiah of Joseph [foundation of Emanation the source of peace], for it is a principle of the Torah that by following a saint one is blessed.

 

·

 

There are as many types of marriage as there are types of human beings. However, the basic types are:

1.      The spiritual marriage: This marriage is the revelation of an already existing bond. This one can weather all obstacles, since its essence is eternal. But it requires that both mates be homo-spiritualis — spiritual beings.

2.      The fun marriage: This is the marriage of the scientist philosopher whose motivating principle is curiosity and creativity.

3.      The reasonable marriage: Not bad if based on feeling also, but reason is a very poor basis for human relationships.

4.      The community sponsored marriage, or the practical. i.e., those that wouldn't be together except for the honor one or the other has from the community and the community support. These are put together and kept together by the community. There is nothing holy about this. It is purely biological. Marriage of the Jewish orthodox are of this type. [In each of these four types, for the marriage to be stable they both have to be of the same type of person. But as you can see a stable marriage doesn't mean there is anything good about either person.]

 

·

 

There is such a thing as finding the right person and knowing that it is so. But if the love isn't like that of Jack and Rose (from the movie Titanic) where each was willing to give up their lives for the other then I would say live together for a year before you get married to see if you'll remain in love. [It is worth it to mention that Jack's willingness to jump in after Rose was due to his kind character, for he didn't know Rose at the time. The lesson is that a kind person will be kind to everyone regardless of who it is.

 

·

 

All women come in pairs. That is one reason why to allow two wives. Every man either has no choice who to marry or two choices. Both are on the level of a true match. Just one makes more sense but there is no love, just like the other makes no sense but there is love. (Most marriages are the ones that make sense but there is no love.

 

·

 

The genius of the species wants improvement of the species so promiscuous sex is not good because it is aimed at quantity, not quality. Marriage is possibly good since the mates check out each other beforehand to see if they are compatible which is in fact irrelevant but what does matter is that they convey the information true the genius of the species which knows if the female male aspects complement each other. If so, they get sexually aroused. None of this has anything to do with compatibility or character.

 

The reason for infatuation is that the genius of the species [yechida] sees that the male and female aspect of these two individuals complement and complete each other so the children may turn out better than either. However, there is no guarantee that this will be the case since it still depends on God's will. Promiscuous sex is evil since there is no possibility of improving the species since there is no discretion as to whether the male and female aspects complement each other.

 

Lack of infatuation means a knowledge of the genius of the species that the children resulting from the union will not be good. This is why the Jewish Orthodox community deteriorates every generation. Even though there are no more arranged marriages, but they also aren't based on love or infatuation. Therefore, one must be very careful to marry only a person he or she is infatuated with. Even if it only a temporary feeling it doesn't matter, for at least at the beginning it has to be there.

 

Marriages based on infatuation alone are not usually the stable ones and thus are not in the best interest of the individuals involved, but the genius of the species is looking for the good of the children. That is why they are attracted to each other. Hopefully it should be possible to have marriages based on infatuation that the more mature members of the family and friends also approve of so there should be hope of stability also.

 

·

 

Keeping one's area clean is important. However, there are several things to know about cleanliness:

1)     Just because you are cleaning doesn't mean you have to yell at everybody else to clean. If you want to be clean, very nice, but don't make everyone miserable because of it.

2)     The reason TV was created was so that you can clean your room while you are watching it.

3)     The reason you can't teach a teenager cleanliness is that it has to come from inside, the teenager has to become disgusted enough himself from living in filth to clean up. At any rate it is a very important rule in parenting not to rule, not to take the rulership from God. God alone is the Ruler and when one tries to rule others [or himself by imposing arbitrary rules] one is infringing on God's rulership.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 3 - Sex

 

-          “For the gods are slow, though they are sure, in visitation, when men scorn godliness and turn to frenzy.” — Oedipus At Colonus by Sophocles

 

“Joy of life depends upon a certain spontaneity in regard to sex. Where sex is repressed, only work remains, and a gospel of work for work's sake never produced any work worth doing.” -- Bertrand Russell

 

 

 

 

 

 

·

 

There is something about sex which reacts against a person when it is merely physical. If it doesn't involve a spiritual bonding, it reacts. Sex demands to be treated with respect and as the bonding of two souls into one. If not, it gets angry like a jealous wife and exacts a price. Sex which is purely sensual spells the end of the relationship.

 

·

 

There is no such thing as free sex (even in marriage). When one doesn't sanctify himself at that time, the price he pays is anger, i.e., he receives anger into his soul. Sex with sanctity draws love, kindness and blessing into the world. Sanctity in sex means the binding of the souls together and then bringing them up to God. It has nothing to do with marriage.

 

·

 

Pleasure is on the level of the tree of knowledge of good and evil and therefore not good or bad in itself but dependent on what one uses it for. If one brings up the sparks of holiness in that pleasure into holiness, he himself goes up and the evil falls. Just saying a blessing has nothing to do with this. It depends a lot on what one actually does with that pleasure. If it’s having children, it depends on how he raises the children. If it's food, it depends on what one does with the energy. Pleasure for the sake pleasure remains on the original level and it falls into evil and becomes evil itself. Pleasure however for the sake of God and done with attachment to God is like a sacrifice and is on a very holy level.

 

·

 

In a time that the matches aren't between true matches, God still draws the proper souls by one soul in the world who is on the level of Joseph (the sephirah of Foundation). This is bechinas (on the level of) what it says by Joseph “the girls jumped over the wall” to see him as Rashi explains there and also what it says by Rebbi Yochanan who waited outside the mikvah so the women coming out from the mikvah would see him and draw the souls that came into the world from the level of Joseph.

 

·

 

Sex when it is an expression of Love is a mitzvah since all Love is of God. And when it is for physical pleasure, it is a sin even though it is within marriage since then it is from the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil. The Sages hint to this when they say only a disciple of a sage can eat meat since he brings up the sparks of holiness in the meat to God. Also, they said a person that marries the daughter of an earthly person transgresses the command “cursed is he that lies with an animal.”

 

·

 

In a relationship, if the female says “it's over”, IT’S OVER. since women don't want the sex as much as the security which she obviously believes she has found in another way... Also, they are closer to the evil side since their root is in the lowest sephirah. Also, their root is related to the sephirah of judgement which makes them prone to anger [i.e., pure evil]. Men are from the middle sephirah and thus want sex more and are less close to the evil side for sex in itself isn't good or evil. It depends on what one makes of it.  

 

·

 

According to the Talmud, “The man asks with his mouth and the woman in her heart,” i.e., the man actually has to ask for sex. This is opposed to modern ideas that the man is supposed to beat around the bush. However, isn't asking for anything in the category of idolatry?!

 

The Sages say in another place, “one that asks for his portion is as if he stole it.” The answer is that if when you ask you know that in truth, “there is nothing besides Him,” and everything you see is simply the infinite light of God in these garments before your eyes — or put simply, everything you see is God at least as he manifests Himself to us. However, asking anything from someone that in your mind isn't included in God [even if you know that their granting the request is dependent on God] is idolatry. For that is actually the exact definition of idolatry. The Torah doesn't deny that there are other gods or higher angels appointed over the nations and over specific things like wisdom. The Torah is full of the existence of them. But you can't serve them. [This incidentally explains the verse there is nothing besides Him that Rabbi Nachman said is literal. Now you could ask, couldn't it mean there are no gods besides Him (as we find in the Torah the subject of a verb sometimes missing as Rashi points out often)? The problem with that is that there are other gods besides Him, so to speak, but they aren't gods but angels appointed over their specific tasks. So, when it says there is nothing besides Him, it has to be taken literally, that none of the things God created have any existence without Him. In a practical vein the actual existence of matter is the condensed light of God. It is not from the empty space but from the light that was drawn into Akudim, the light returned up and the vessels stayed behind and thus became solidified.

 

Because of the breaking of the vessels later on, the matter we see doesn't appear to contain any of that light, as it would have — if not for the breaking of the vessels. But in any case, the actual substance is from the light, not from the empty space. I have thought however that in some way there is a relation to the empty space, but it is probably not true. The real probable cause of the solidification is the very reason why there was a creation in the first place, i.e., the basic “lack” that was in the kindness of God before there was anyone to do kindness to.

 

So, He had to create separate beings from Himself in order to reward them with the highest good, i.e., being one with Him. So, when you look at the world around you it is accurate to conceive of it as the condensed light of God. To actually receive the revelation of the light however is in the next world. This world is only a preparation. So even the light that shines here is just to purify us for that great light there. Meditation doesn't draw it. It merely helps one go into oneself to discover who he is. There is no mental energy. All the metaphors in this book are talking on higher spiritual levels, not the physical world.

 

The Life force exists on one level, and the spirit on another, and the soul on another etc... These levels are related only by the Strange Loops or some hidden staircase from level to level. They are not accessible by any trick. God hates tricks and He will never shine his light on anyone that thinks he can get it by some trick, practice, or good deed, etc.

 

God's light is a gift that may come once in a lifetime or stay awhile but it can never be forced. What meditation can do is to bring one into his own vessels, and to clean them out and polish them but it can't draw the light. If God wants to pour in the water after you cleaned your vessel that is up to Him. Even the mitzvot of the Torah are to make us holy and to love and fear God, but they can't draw God. As He said, “I will have mercy on him who I will have mercy upon.” — The Strange Loop again.


 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 4 – The Ways of Life (or Principles of Life)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

“One needs no cause. Whatever is decreed to come to one, will come without any cause at all.

-Madregas Ha Adam (Rabbi Joseph Yozel Horwitz)

“Not he who fasts and prays is acceptable, rather he who knows HIM.

-The Rambam in the Guide for the Perplexed, chapter 53.)

 

·

 

One should have absolute trust in God to give him a living and all his needs in spiritual and physical matters. Still, one should do something for a living which is a part of serving God. “Great is work, for God himself has commanded that one should do some minimal amount of work” — Sefer HaMidot (by Rabbi Nachman).

 

God runs the world between two poles, trust in God and self-reliance: and as with the uncertainty principle the exact location between those two poles you belong at any one instant isn’t determinate. This comes from the dichotomy between the circular and straight sephirot. Rabbi Nachman said one should do just enough effort to make a vessel to receive God's blessing (in a natural way) if he so desires to give it. The idea of the natural vessel is the name Elohim which has the numerical value of the word for nature which reflects the circular sephirot. In that vessel then can come the blessing from the Inflammable Name which reflects the straight sephirot.

 

·

 

In general, the evil inclination can be broken only by an oath to do the right thing. This applies also to any evil habit like masturbation — however its also good not to eat anything in the morning until 12:00 pm, in order to break that evil inclination.

 

·

 

Many times, advice you receive in a dream will be much more accurate than even what good friends give. The Rambam held that the statement of the Sages that prophecy was taken from Israel meant only until the year 1240 and that in that year prophecy would return to Israel. He had this tradition from his father who received it from his father and so on. The Rambam also says that all prophets besides Moses receive their prophecy only asleep and in dreams. He even says that if the prophet is awake, a deep sleep has to fall upon him before he can prophesize. This would seem to indicate nowadays there is reason to at least consider the possibility that a dream may be more than a dream. I have had dreams telling me what to do or telling me to follow certain daily rules [e.g., “You have no hope except to say the midnight prayer”, or cleanliness in the garments to the degree of changing even if there is a little perspiration; and. “You learn Torah. Physics is a side thing”, etc...] and I have regretted not following them.

 

·

 

In Safed there was a fellow named Mordechai Shebabo who was a physical education teacher in the public high school. He also happened to be an expert fencer. He was on the Israeli Olympic team as a fencer. A few nights before he had to leave for the Olympics in Munich, he had a dream of Rabbi Moshe Alkebetz telling him, “Don't go to the Olympics. Come to my grave to fix it and to clean the area.” He of course paid no attention to it, but then on the next night he had the same dream. After the second or third night he had already decided there was something to it. He went down the next day to the Cave of Rabbi. Moshe Alshich and began cleaning it. In the meantime, the rest of the team went to Munich, and were all massacred by Palestinian terrorists.

 

·

 

One should go to the shrine of Rabbi Nachman in Uman every Rosh Hashanah, in order to fix the trait of power during the year, for the vertical line of light of power is located there.

 

·

 

When one gives up hope, that's when hope begins. God doesn't step in until one gives up -- to show that it's not your prayers or efforts that count, only his Will.

 

·

 

Don't own anything too much. (i.e., don't be attached to anything too much. Don't consider it yours too much.) God has a way of running things which show one that which he thinks is his, really isn't his at all.

 

·

 

In any disagreement between the mind and the heart, one must go after the

heart. “Trust in the Lord with all your heart and upon your understanding do not depend.” (Mishle) i.e., don't depend on your logic, but the voice of God in the inner heart. (But not the desires of the outer heart. This is because human relationships are in the spiritual realm which isn't subject to logic).

 

·

 

The Toldos Yakov Yoseph explains that the difference between the side of good and the side of evil is that the side of evil wants to destroy the good totally, while the side of good doesn't want to destroy the evil but to subdue it and allow it to exist.

 

·

 

The principle that there is nothing besides God, one always has to accept from his arch enemy. Judaism never noticed it until they get it from Hinduism and Rabbi Chayim of Volozhin from the Chasidim, Rav Shik (of Breslov) from Chabad. The same time this concept came into Jewish writings -- the 1700s -- is the exact time the European community became infatuated with the Bhagavad Gita and the Sutras. At any rate, for what it is worth, I will mention that the kabbalah in the Pardes of Rabbi Moshe Cordavaro) has the exact middle opinion between Shankara and Ramanuga. The teaching of the Gita is exactly duplicated by the Baal Hatanya, that the only way to realize and come to the Oneness of God is by meditation on it.

 

·

 

Many of life's important principles one has to accept from his arch enemy, or never get them at all. (Love as a principle was never noticed in Jewish writings. Jewish writings are devoid of it for about 2000 years. It's the Christians that made a big deal about it and finally we noticed it.)  

 

·

 

Some people are on the level of action, some on the level of words and some on the level of thought. The way of life which applies to one can't apply to the other. But within each group there is good and bad. On each level one must find God.

 

·

 

The attitude of being a fighter for justice or of hating any group or feeling like the victim of injustice or raising children to have these attitudes creates vindictive people who are in permanent conflict with the world and fighting for some cause.

 

·

 

Sometimes in life one should realize he has to come to the highest point he can get to. Carl Jung felt that in the middle age period a transformation comes. The sages said forty is the age of understanding. Many times, there were great leaders that ruined their legacies just by staying on a bit too long, -- and should have just found something else to do. The Melians thought they could hold out against the Athenians because they knew their cause was right and they knew they were more virtuous than the Athenians. If they had given up, they would merely have become an Athenian colony. Instead, they held on, and all the men were put to death, and the rest of the population were enslaved. Many times, it is just time to give up.

 

Yet one characteristic of winners is their lack of ability to give up on something that just drives them on no matter how bleak it looks. Like Rabbi Nachman said there is no such thing as giving up. (i.e., that even when one has given up God is still able to save him, so there is no reality to giving up.) Truman was a failure at 33, bankrupt at 38, yet President of the USA at 60. 

 

This contradiction perhaps can be answered by Epictetus: “The reality of good lies in what is in our power. Do not wish to be a judge or politician or a lawyer, but to be free-and there is but one way to freedom- to despise what is not in our power.” -Epictetus

 

·

 

A key to self-evaluation is the opinions of one's true friends and close family. They may not see the whole picture, but when you put yours and their point of view together you get a three-dimensional perspective rather than your own two-dimensional or their two-dimensional point-of-view. This is a simple mathematical fact. The truth is that even one’s enemies point of view should be taken into account, because even if you allow for the fact that blind hatred is the reason for most of it there still is probably some kernel of truth.

 

Some of the most important lessons in life one has to learn from one's enemy. The reason for this is that the world one lives in is really just a reflection of one's personality and stems from himself. Therefore, all ones' friends and family and enemies all represent different parts of one's own personality. Therefore, there is really no solution to one's problems except a basic change in their personality, which after the age of five is pretty rare.  However, I believe there is hope, for one's personality is actually a reflection of a higher element and that is one's philosophy-or world view. Change that and you have changed your personality. Even if the change is ever so slight it will still have an enormous effect on the events surrounding you.

 

·

 

This applies to whole peoples also. For instance, Germany never had to give up the idea of their being a chosen race. They in fact have tremendous talents. (Similarly, the Jewish people don't have to give up the idea of being the chosen people. They in fact are a God-imbued people.) The problems come from false conclusions from the basic facts. World conquest isn't a logical conclusion of “chosen race”, but world betterment is. Germany could have avoided all the problems by an ever-so-slight-change in their philosophy. But in the long run, you can never really know who you are until it is all over.

 

·

 

An example that a slight difference in philosophy makes a vast difference in action is the slight difference between John Locke's democracy and Russo's. Locke made human rights supreme and government secondary, and that led to a democratic England and USA (until America became a socialist republic under the New Deal).

 

Russo made the general will supreme and his book has been used as a blueprint for tyrannies and reigns of terror since then. Even though he emphasizes the importance of the individual, like Locke, he believes the public can decide what rights the individual can have. (It's interesting to note that Locke's idea of inalienable rights has nothing to do with believing that people are good, because he actually says that people are born as blank slates). Locke derives this from the Bible. This is far from the relative humanism of the Sophists. Rather this is a belief in absolute right and wrong and in human life has an absolute value on the scale of values that is inalienable. Life is from the sephirah of Wisdom, and right and wrong on the level of the lower sephirot, so life has a value above right and wrong. [But you may ask what about the penalties of the Torah? Those relate to values that the Torah places above life.]

 

·

 

In general, everything that happens with a person is an expression of their personality. If one sees failure, he must know that it's only from his personality and its correction is only by correcting his personality. The only way one's future will be happier than the present is if one's future contains a radical change in one's personality. Some search for a happiness outside of themselves which doesn't exist. It can only exist inside oneself, if it is created there. The door to a better future is the heart — if you can open the door. Thus, we come to the advice of Rabbi Nachman of talking with God in a private place. This is a key, but it doesn't open the lock unless you make it do so. This can be misused and is no guarantee but can help and is a powerful help.

 

·

 

I believe Rabbi Israel Salanter must have been trying to figure out how to change one's personality when it is a negative type. The best he could come up with was to learn Musar, (the ethical works of Torah.) But he must have been aware that many personality types will rise to unbelievable heights in the name of religion, Chabad, musar, Torah, etc. and will perform awesome deeds of righteousness for the benefit of all mankind but also inflict savagery and untold suffering upon millions of people (particularly non-believers).

 

·

 

I believe the true cure for a negative personality lies in the idea of John Fox that a person's major decisions in life should be dependent on the vote of his/her family and real friends as a group coming together to weigh all the aspects together. This has the power of preventing a person from making serious mistakes. (“The victory is yours when you yield to your friend” -- Sophocles.) And if they are a true friend and family, they won't prevent him from his positive dreams. Also tempering revelation with reason and rationality has a strong effect of preventing fanaticism and the guilty Puritan complex.

 

·

 

According to The Duties of The Heart the entire Torah is based on the idea of gratitude. It's important never to forget the kindness someone has done for you no matter what happened before or after. However according to the Rambam in the commentary on the Mishna the whole Torah is based on faith. This idea of Torah has deeply affected Judaism until today. He says that no matter what one does he will get to the Garden of Eden [i.e., the Jewish Garden of Eden, not Christian one depends on belief in Jesus] if he believes in the 13-principles. And if he doesn't believe in them, it doesn't matter what he does, he will never get to the Garden of Eden. However, in the Talmud we find everything depends on one's deeds. You get exactly what you give. This would seem to contradict Rambam. If we would have only the Rambam we would say that deeds matter only if there is already faith. However, we find The Alter from Slobadka and the Baal Shem Tov held that deeds and faith are closely interlinked. The Alter says that evil deeds show that the faith itself is flawed and is only outward, while the Baal Shem Tov holds that evil deeds bring to an inner lack of faith. According to this people that are good have inner faith deep inside their heart even if they aren't aware of it. People that are bad may express faith outwardly but really don't have it. Perhaps this is the opinion of the Rambam himself for in the laws of repentance he says the Garden of Eden depends on good deeds and wisdom.

 

·

 

The bubble one makes for himself to isolate himself from the world will revolt and rebel against him. This applies to individuals that think they can hide in yeshiva, and to whole communities as well. The reason is the world is governed by the laws of chaos and strife, so if one shuts the world out the chaos has to overtake his particular bubble inside, and then it's worse since it is confined to a smaller radius. You can't fight entropy forever.

 

·

 

One's happiness depends on being oneself, not on getting things (or someone) he thinks he needs. If one is himself, he will automatically get the things he really needs. The reason is that the higher light doesn't flow through constricted vessels.

 

·

 

When you take a seat on a train or bus and then change it you will find the second many times to be worse than the first. Many times, there is a hidden hand which guides us, though we are unaware of it.

 

·

 

Many times, one doesn't find what he is looking for or understand what he is learning until he gives up looking or trying to understand. This is because the thought or the essence of what we are looking for, has gone into the surrounding circular light. When you let go then you are guided back to the right place, or the right thought is guided back to you. That's why Einstein discovered Relativity only by sleeping on it, and most great scientific discovers are the same (this is to say that of course you can't find what you want or understand what you want unless God wills it to come to you at that time but the reason he uses this round about method of accident is because the idea has to come from the surrounding light into you.) Thus, we find Issaac Newton was prompted by the falling apple, Mendeleev was revealed the periodic table in his dream. I've heard that Churchill got his best ideas during World War II, while relaxing in the bathtub. In fact, penicillin; the thin layer of the galaxy, and so many more discoveries are by accident. Feynmann was prompted by a student flipping a plate in the dining room. Even the theory of chaos came in such a way).

 

·

 

I used to be annoyed when there was a fly in my room until I noticed that Analytic Geometry started by Descartes watching a fly in his room. It occurred to him that you could describe its position by three coordinates. What would have happened if he had gotten up to chase it out? At any rate I figure if a fly could start Analytic Geometry, then flies can't be that bad -- remember the event with King David and the spider?!

 

·

 

When I have to run to something usually it turns out that I never should have gone or that there was no need to run. As the Sages say, “He who presses the hour, the hour presses him. He who is pushed away by the hour, the hour stands for him. Rabbi Israel of Kaznitz said, “when one has a sudden urge to do a good deed, it's a bad sign”. Rabbi Nachman said not to be stubborn. Anything that is a true mitzvah must be worked on for a long time in order to do it. However, when the time for a mitzvah comes one should do it right away and not delay in order to do it better later (as the Mishna Brurah says).

 

·

 

Direct your energies towards a single goal - the goal your heart says is right, (not your mind or logic.) Don't aim for two targets for then you won't hit either. Concentrate all your fire on one target. One's spiritual energy usually isn't limitless, so you do have to deal with the fact that any goal to be achieved well is going to need your entire attention.

 

·

 

The problem with hatred is that one becomes that which he hates, because the side of holiness doesn't hate anything in the way of wanting it destroyed, rather corrected and saved. The way of being saved from ones enemies is to judge them on the scale of merit. And pray for their good, spiritual and physical, in this world and the next, then your prayer will reflect off them like a mirror right back to you. And it may help them also.

 

·

 

Archenemies are always almost completely identical (in ideas and in conduct). One side may in fact be right and the other wrong, but it is still striking how similar they are, e.g., the right-wing Israelis and the Palestinians, the hippies and the establishment. As the old saying goes, “extremes meet.”

 

·

 

One should say the thirteen principles of faith of the Rambam immediately when he wakes up in the morning.

 

·

 

One lacking money should say the chapter that deals with the manna in the desert. There is a tradition brought in Rabbenu Bachayee that one who says it every day will never lack a livelihood.

 

·

 

One should pray with the intentions of the Rabbi Issac Luria in the Siddur HaRashash, except from Passover until Shavuot when the Rashash said not to do the intentions because that period is for the building of the sephirot. I always had a question on this because there is a distinction between the sephirot of the day and of the year, but apparently the Rashash held the if the sephirot of the year aren't built then you can't build the form of each day which are dependent on it. [This would mean also during the days from Rosh Hashanah until Succot. But I think that is going too far and one should pray with the intentions then and depend on the opinion of the Ramchal in his book on the intentions where he mentions that distinction and I think it is clear that he felt one should pray with the intentions all the time.]

 

·

 

One should put all the intentions into one, i.e., unite all the divine names into one point.

 

·

 

For one's children he should say the part in Genesis which deals with creation every day of the week. -Sefer Hamidos.

 

[at least for forty days straight for forty days is a whole time slot.]

 

To get married one should say the Parsha of the sacrifices of the princes [Numbers], and the Song on the Red Sea [Exodus].

 

·

 

The morning prayer draws wisdom, the afternoon draws understanding and financial security, and the evening prayer brings knowledge and blessing to one's children. They are parallel to the 3 Patriarchs. The midnight prayer is parallel to Leah and Rachel the Matriarchs.

 

·

 

The most important principle in life is not to cause suffering to another person. If one does, it will always come back to one. [As the Sages said, the measure one measures out, is measured to him again. The Hindus assume this to be by reincarnation but in fact there are many ways this can be done. Reincarnation is only one of them].

 

·

 

It is a good idea to have water near the bed to wash ones hands in the morning instead of walking to the sink, because Reb Zushai said it is a segula to do so, and the Zohar is strict about it.

 

·

 

Astrology is forbidden to the Rambam but permitted to most other authorities like Tosphot and the Ramban.

 

·

 

“Truth is the most powerful thing in the world. It can pierce through great mountains” — Rabbi Eliezer Shik.

 

·

 

It is an absolutely essential part of any home to have at least one guest. There are homeless people in every place. There are always people who need a helping hand. Letting someone sleep on the couch is important for every home. Yet one should never overdo his kindness in such a way that makes it hard to keep it up. Don't be too kind, just a little kind. We see in the Torah that Abraham was kind to the angels, but Lot went out of his way to beg them to come in and made a very big deal about it. In such a way one gets worn out quickly. It is better to do it with tzimtzum [control-and limit.]

 

·

 

In the hierarchy of spaces there is a space called emotional space where the components are emotions. [There is also one called Idea Space where ideas interact.]

 

 

Ij=k;

jk=i;

ki=j.

 

Love multiplied by truth = victory.

Love of love of Judgement

Love of Truth love of eternity doing kindness.

 

The sephirot emotions of the evil side are love of cruelty, love of sex as a physical act, love of lying, or not learning wisdom etc.

 

·

 

Two things one must be careful to avoid: fame and illicit sex [i.e., sex outside of marriage].

 

The reason is not that either of these things are evil, but because they are dangerous. Sex and honor are incredibly powerful sources of energy and just like atomic energy, if not handled with extreme caution they can be deadly. Now sex even in marriage is by no means necessarily holy but certainly less dangerous since there is at least the surrounding light of the marriage commitment. 

 

Now the story that Rabbi Adam Baal Shem told the Baal Shem Tov about his previous gilgul shows that one must be careful not to reveal any good deeds one has done or anything one has learned. It seems clear from the Lekutai Moharan that the reason for this is that saying the good deed gives the kelipot an ability to attach themselves to it.

 

·

 

Rabbenu Yona explains that making a Rav [teacher] for oneself means even a friend. The Yerushalmi [brought by the Rambam and Rabbenu Yona] says even any old man from the street. [The incident where there was a rabbi wanted to decide a halacha, so he said, “Bring in an old man from the street.”]

 

·

                                               

There are two kinds of honor: one Divine honor and the other honor of men. Honor is a surrounding light from the sepherah of Malchut (or understanding). Sometimes a person has neither type, and in his case any fame or publicity he gets will be just the evil eye and be very damaging for him. Other people do have one or the other type of honor and in their case the fame or publicity doesn't hurt them. However, in the case of the Divine honor, if one has it shining on himself, but he is a sinner then he will be infamous and despised. These purifies him so that he can continue to receive that Divine light.

 

 

 

 

Chapter 5 - Friendship

“Men of notorious depravity or obvious deceit yield nothing in nastiness to hypocritical pseudo-philosophers and treacherous friends.” —Tacitus, The Annals of Imperial Rome

 

·

 

People you think are your friends never are, and those who you think aren't usually. A true friend is someone who will help you when you are down and out, and that's impossible to know until it happens.

 

·

 

In a far-off Arabic land, a long time ago there was a Jew who had a son who was neglecting the daily prayers and spending every evening at a different friend’s house partying. The father asked his son, “How many friend do you have?” “About 50 or 60”, he answered. The father said, “that is amazing for I am an old man and after so many years all I have is one friend and one half-friend. How is it possible that you have fifty or sixty already and you are just a young man?”. “Let's try a test. I'll spread some ketchup on you and give you a long knife and go to each of your friend house saying you were attacked, and you fought off your attacker and grabbed the knife from him and killed him and now you need to be hidden from the police.”

 

In the early evening he went to the first house, the friend opened the door, he told his story and the “friend” yelled “Get out of here, demon” and slammed the door on his face. The second house barely opened the door and immediately slammed it shut after seeing him. And thus, the evening went. From house to house he went until 11:00 pm when he returned home. No one had helped. The father said “Now let's try a different experiment. Let's send you to my half friend who barely knows you”.
