As soon as the half friend saw him covered with blood, he immediately grabbed him inside and without waiting to hear what he had to say, he immediately stripped off the clothes burned them, threw him in the bathtub, got rid of the knife, and locked the front door and pocketed the key. The son then tried to explain that now that he was cleaned up, he could go home, but the half friend said “you aren't going anywhere tonight”. And so, the son was stuck there until the morning. Then the “half-friend” took him by stealth to the fathers home and the father explained what had really happened. The son knew then what a real friend is.

 

·

 

In an ideal world we would all be true friends like this (or like Jack and Rose, “If you jump, I jump” -Titanic, the movie), however we don't live in that ideal world. But we still should try to be the best friend we can, and value our half-or quarter friends as long as that small percentage of friends in them is real.

 

·

 

Someone who has done you one favor is much more likely to do a you another than someone you have done a favor for, since its already revealed they have the level of giving flow in relation to your level. (That is in that subject they occupy a higher plane and water flows from up to down).

 

One who has reneged on a promise once will definitely do it again. One who has let you down and shown him or herself to be untrustworthy once will do the same again if given the chance.

 

 

 

 

Chapter 6 - Success

 

 

 

 

·

 

“Beware of any activity that requires the purchase of new clothes,” [Thoreau] because the clothes reflect the character and if the new activity involves different clothes, then it's not for you.

 

Every person was created with a certain Tzelem {form} {world line in time and space} that he grows into. Therefore, any attempt to impose an external order on his life will fail. He can make plans, put in much effort and try with all his might, but if that order is not a part of his nature, and the nature of his world-line, it won't be successful.

 

This is what Socrates meant by know yourself. Most people waste years of their lives and sometimes all of it trying to force some type of external order on themselves that they have been taught is right for them but really isn't.

 

·

 

Christopher Morley said, 'There is only one success -- to be able to spend your life in your own way. [quoted in the New York Post by Nelson and Dauten]. But even so, happiness is having worthwhile goals and accomplishing them relative to this.

 

CHARACTERISTICS OF LOSERS

1)     Interrupting work to answer the phone.

2)     Not learning a useful skill.

3)     Punishing friends and being nice to enemies.

4)     Bad manners, e.g., not thanking for gifts. — Readers Digest

5)     Dressing inappropriately

6)     Coming late for an appointment

 

CHARACTERISTICS OF WINNERS

1)     Maximizing the number of minimum (small guaranteed) gains, as opposed to big non-guaranteed gains (as in Game Theory). This is like Rabbi Nachman's way of learning quickly to gain as many small points as possible as opposed to learning one part of the subject really well but at the expense of getting the overview well. The Baal Hatanyah deals at great length to resolve the conflict of which is more important; the overall view [the name 52]; or the inner light of the specific details [the name 45].

2)     Taking a long time to get to the goal. Every day for twenty years is a lot more than cramming it in six months and forgetting. Thus, the idea of the Noam Elimelech: lessons every day to learn a little bit Bible, a little bit halacha, a little bit of science, a little Kabbalah, a little meditation. Over the course of many years, it adds up

 

·

 

When Pope Julius II asked Michelangelo when the work on the Sistine Chapel would be done, he answered, “When I shall have done all that I believe required to satisfy art.” It occurs to me this is exactly the idea of James Cameron's obsession with getting the Titanic a hundred percent right and not caring about dead-lines or cost. “I made it a sacred goal of the production, a goal that came to be shared by everyone involved, to honor the facts without compromise.”

 

·

 

People tend to have some particular addiction which comes up in their conversation. - i.e., a certain affixation on a certain body part, or idea, or event that they continuously bring up. This is indicative of the nature of the outer light surrounding that person or lack of it in certain places. These hang-ups are what prevents a person from success.

 

·

 

The difference between good and evil is that a good person gets pleasure out of giving someone pleasure and an evil person gets pleasure from causing pain. It really has little to do with who is receiving the good for the good, enjoy giving pleasure even to evil people and the evil get pleasure from causing pain even to their friend. Most people are between these two extremes and try to benefit their friends, but this doesn't reflect their true character.

 

·

 

The question of how to react to an enemy is the subject of debate in every generation. The Sages of the Talmud say one who is kind in a place where cruelty is needed, will eventually become cruel where kindness is needed. You should pray for the good of your enemies but still guard yourself from them. I think this idea would explain most of the statements of Jesus, the Bible, the Besht, Buddha and the Sutras in this regard, so that there shouldn't be any contradiction. This is why I have written that the blessing in the eighteen blessings cursing the non-believers should be skipped.

 

It seems clear from the historical record that the Christians were originally considered part of Judaism, and thus protected under Roman law and not obligated to sacrifice to the image of the emperor. However, after much effort was spent explaining to the Roman officials that the Christians were not a part of Judaism, the persecutions began at the time of Judge Pilany and continued for two hundred years. Now, to me it seems obvious who was the most anxious to exclude the Christians from Judaism. In fact, there was a very rich agnostic who wanted to exclude all references to the Jewish root of Jesus in the four Gospels — and was told to take his money and leave. It seems the early church wanted to preserve their Jewish roots. So, praying/cursing and hatred against the Christians just seems to have backfired against us. Perhaps it's about time to admit our mistake.

 

·

 

Saving the world is not a noble occupation. It usually results in suffering, not help. If the world has ever been made a better place, it’s by the self-searchers who seek only to understand and correct themselves.

 

·

 

Just because you get inspired by a place doesn't mean it’s any good. It may just be the sparks of holiness that have fallen there and see you and attach themselves to their root, i.e., your soul.

 

·

 

What disturbs men’s minds is not events but their judgements on events. ­- Epictetus

 

·

 

I have heard from almost every enemy I ever had (by way of conversation with them before they became my enemies), what their world view of people was — and it always was the same -- they look at people friends or relatives as assets.

 

These people make it their business to get as many friends as possible to further their objectives. In retrospect, I can see why all these people ended up being my sworn enemies. They discovered that I think too independently to be an asset to anything or anyone. And it’s interesting to notice the world-view of all those who remained my friend. Invariably, they look at people from an extremely human point if view.

 

·

 

If someone has betrayed you once, be sure that they will do it again if you give them a chance. This can refer to parents or friends or anyone or a collective community.

 

·

 

Life is peace with conflict.

 

·

 

By doing kindness (many times) one suffers, but one should know that suffering would have come upon him anyway, in a different form, except that by doing the kindness the judgement is weakened.

 

Learning heavy books which have to be done sitting down should be by making a pile of them on one side of the desk and doing the amount necessary and transferring them one by one to the opposite side of the desk. For lighter books one should lie down and hold them over his head so the blood rushes to the head and concentration is easier.

 

·

 

For depression one has to go to the mikvah or a natural body of water and dip in his whole body and play a musical instrument in order to draw the surrounding light of Binah — Understanding.

 

·

 

Never take yourself or what you are doing so seriously as to look down on others. It is very important to give every person respect because God created them for His reasons and has a place for everyone in His heart. Every person is born with a certain Tzelem” or Form that he is born into. It isn't in his power to change it. So, it isn't right to look down on anyone, even evil people. They may have the ability to change but so do you and how easy is it for you to change your character?

 

·

 

When there are indications not to do something that one supposes is a mitzvah sometimes the indication is to tell you that it is not a mitzvah. However, the other times it is to tell you that it is an extremely important mitzvah. The only way of telling is to go into your closet and meditate until hopefully you get the right answer. The reason for this is that each person has a root soul in Emanation, creation Formation or the physical universe. Since each of these four worlds has varying degrees of evil the indications also will vary. Thus, a person whose root soul is in Emanation will have all the indications pointing in the correct direction. One whose root is in Creation will have the majority pointing in the right direction. For Formation the majority is in the wrong direction and for the physical person all the indications are in the wrong direction-which causes them to remain physical and never to try to rise above it. Those involved all day in physical activity are from the physical. Those involved in learning are from Formation. Those involved in meditation and prayer are from Creation and those whom the Light shines on the whole day are from emanation. Sometimes a lot depends, however, on the place also since for instance New York has only the light of Formation and the Physical. In some places like Israel the light of Emanation shine but the light causes souls of people not prepared for the light whose root souls aren't from emanation to break and become evil. California has the light of Creation. Thus, Israel won't be safe until collectively Jesus and Rabbi Nachman are accepted since then there would be a connection for every person with emanation in the way that wouldn't break their vessels.

 

 

 

 

Chapter 7 – Saints

 

 

 

 

 

 

·

 

The reason one needs to be connected to a saint is that even with all the preparation of virtue and study unless God shines his light on one then he simply isn't connected with God [even though God is still connected with him by the contracting light. And without that light one's spiritual life is simply self-delusion. There is no such thing as spirituality except for that light. [However, there are different levels of it so on the level of royalty or the contraction God is still looking at one and he still must be careful in what he says thinks and does. At any rate, because of this one must be connected with a saint that is connected to the light. This is in fact one of the 613 commandments as it says in the Torah to be attached to God and the Sages ask how is it possible to be attached to God? Isn't he a burning Fire? And they answer to be attached to students of the wise men, i.e., do business with them and to give to one of them your daughter.

 

However, it is hard to know who is a saint. Rabbi Yaakov Abuchatzara gave the criteria [in Maaglai Tzedek]. If you see two people serving God; one can do miracles and the other can't, know that the one who can, is a greater saint that the other. We see this in the Bible, for Eliyahu said to the head of the troop “If I am a man of God let fire come down from Heaven...” Thus, we see that the proof of his being a man of God was his ability to do a miracle. HE could have done the miracle without saying “If I am a man of God”, but he added those words to teach us this lesson. Also, the Bible teaches us how to discover if someone is a true or false prophet. If they say any good thing will come to pass, and it doesn't, or if he says to serve false gods or to stop keeping the commandments then he is a false prophet.

 

This may seem to contradict what I have said elsewhere about the importance of listening to one's family and friends, not to rabbis. However, the answer to this is as follows.

 

At any there is a level of saint that applies to each individual in a spiritual way, that is his parents and friends for though they may not be saints in terms of the rest of the world they are in general   the level of “saint” in relation to each individual. The test is if they have actually helped the individual in some tangible physical way. If not, then they are just a lot of hot air. For what they do for is on the level of a miracle, and by their love for you they can have “Small Prophecy” to know the outcome of a course of action. This is like what the Sages say that in naming ones child one has small prophecy.

 

Honor of ones parents is in the Ten Commandments and honoring a rabbi is not even mentioned in the Bible. Thus, even though the Sages tell us the importance of honoring a true saint or sage this prescription has to be taken with a grain of salt and in such a way that wouldn't contradict the open command of the Torah.

 

·

 

A good way of really telling who is a saint is the test of time. For instance, the writings of Moses are doing pretty good still after 3000 years. So are the books of other saints. Modern-day so-called rabbis will be lucky if they are remembered 20 years after they have passed except as some foot note in a history book.

 

·

 

It's impossible to know the answer to the criticism on any saint because of the uncertainty principle -- the better you know the answer the less you are aware of his being a saint. And the greater the saint is the less we can know the answers to the questions on him.

 

·

 

The thing that made Rabbi Israel Abuchatzera and all the great saints, wasn't so much their prayer, fasting or learning, rather it was their tremendous desire to help people. When that desire exists in one, God gives him the ability to help people far beyond the rules of nature. The tools to help people are simple acts of kindness, but for people like Rabbi Israel Abuchatzara it was possible to go into the spiritual roots of the problem in the higher worlds and correct the problem's there, and that would trickle down to this world where the problem would disappear.

 

Yet even a regular person can do that to some degree by prayer:

●       By going to the shrine of Rabbi Nachman for Rosh Hashanah; by learning Kabbalah and science; by doing the unifications of Rabbi Luria Ashkenazi

●       By prayer with the intentions of the Rashash

●       By doing the nullifying of judgments by the shrines of the saints in Israel

●       By reading the whole Torah every verse forward and backwards and then saying the Divine Names that come with the verse. (The simplest way is saying the first letter of every word with the vowel under it as it is written in the Torah, then the middle letters with the vowel which is specifically for that letter, and then the last letter in the same way. (This method is good to use with the Lekutei Moharan which also has the strength to nullify judgments.

●       The most important thing to do is to bring loved ones together. For in the next world loved ones are together. However, in this world usually true mates are separated by time and place and even if they come together its only for a brief time.

 

·

 

When one denies a righteous person completely, he cuts off the flow of spiritual energy which might have reached him. So those who may not know Jesus but don't deny him may still receive the flow of the light of kindness from him.

 

·

 

When a Tzadik is born there is born his evil side in another person. That's why he has to pray for that person because it's really a part of himself, just he was lucky that it was born elsewhere.

 

·

 

 

The way God runs things changes so what one saint does to get some spiritual level will not work nowadays unless that same spiritual flow is upon him. But private prayer still works since it's the light of the crown which is the type of Divine flow coming into the world. Learning Kabbalah is just on the level of wisdom, so it doesn't work like it used to.

 

·

 

To reveal the Divine traits, one needs an empty space. America, the land of freedom, is between the East and West. And that's why America has grown, since it’s a land of freedom and good deeds can only grow in a free environment. Chaos has its own beautiful patterns and since in America there is some degree of freedom of thought, ideas are able to flow around and sometimes to converge into a great vortex, like the great red spot that is on Jupiter.

 

·

 

The disagreement between the Talmud and Jesus is on the level of the argument between the righteous. Jesus or the Talmud can't bring blessing unless they are hidden by the argument on them.

 

·

 

Most great saints don't have the right ideas -- just great hearts. Most great geniuses don't have great hearts, just great heads. They have a common thread and share many of the same characteristics but if we are to live according to God's will, we can't listen to necessarily any one saint or any one genius if we are to find a correct path in which God is accessible to common people. It is necessary to listen to the wise and the saints of all ages especially those that have withstood the test of time and to try to gain an idea of how their teachings apply to us today (e.g., I don't think Mother Teresa necessarily had a great head, but rather a great heart. She was a devout Catholic. Should we all then become Catholics? I don't think so, and I don't think we'll all be dammed if we don't, though that belief is part of the Catholic faith).

 

·

 

The Rambam writes that making anything a mediator between you and God is idolatry (just the same as serving anything besides God. So, apparently there should be a problem doing any mitzvah which is supposed to bring you close to God and bring blessing from God.

 

Now, the idea that a mediator is against the Torah isn't accepted by all authorities. So, to them there is no problem with the Gemarah saying that when you have someone sick at home you should go to the Torah scholar to pray for you; nor with the Gemarah about the saint who was having trouble with his neighbors and went to the grave of his father asking for help; nor with the Gemarah saying that if people would be able to go to the grave of Moses to pray, the redemption would come right away.

 

But if we go with the Rambam we would have to say that mitzvot and tzadikim are included in the 10 sephirot of Emanation and thus are considered one with God. I would say the Rambam avoided all this by saying “making a creation a mediator”. Also, when you do the mitzvot, those are the things God said to do to come close to Him and receive his blessing, so they are serving God, and in a way the mediators that God has specified for his service. This would include being “attached and united” to a Tzadik which is one of the 613 commandments.

 

·

 

The difference between the Rambam and the other authorities is that if one holds that a Tzadik is a sephirah of Emanation then to the Rambam it would be forbidden to ask him to pray for you, but if you hold like the other authorities, it would be permitted.

 

·

 

The idea of combining the paths of the righteous is from Zushia the brother of the Rabbi Elimelech of Lezinsk. He, however only used the idea for the chasidishe saints... I have gone out on a limb to take it further to combine all saints. If this is correct it is a tremendous truth. If not, I will be dammed forever by the view point of any religion. [Reb Zushia got it from the verse, “for God knows the path of the saints”, “knows” has a double meaning, of putting together. So, Reb Zushia derived the idea that God puts together the diverging paths of the saints. This was in relation to the Chasidishe saints who all had completely different paths. One was into prayer, another into good deeds, another into learning and so on.

 

·

 

Jesus contains the vessels of Tohu [chaos] and thus majors in physical healing, and in bringing people to the Garden of Eden in the next world; which is also so to speak relevant to the vessels of the light, which are people's souls, and the actual surroundings of those souls in the next world. Rabbi Nachman has to do with more with the drawing of the infinite light of the crown, or of wisdom its vessel. He has very little to do with healing anybody or miracles in general.

 

·

 

We are indebted to the Hindu thinkers [Shankara and Ramanuja] for the emphasis and clarity of their belief that the God is the only reality. This belief eventually got into Judaism, where it was all the time (but submerged), until the Baal Shem Tov brought it to the surface and the Litvaks were forced to concede to its truth - however reluctantly that may have been. Yet the pessimism of Hindu and Buddhist teachings (i.e., their idea that human deeds are fruitless and have no essential value) stifled their civilization for 2000 years while the Jewish belief in the power of the mind [the father] and the Christian belief in the power of good deeds [the mother church] shaped and brought forth western civilization. Here we have another example of the importance of Reb Zushia's idea of combining the paths of all the saints

 

·

 

How to Tell if Someone is a Saint

 

Rabbi Yakov Abuchatzeira writes in Maaglei Zedek, that if you see two people serving God, but one if full of miracles and the other is not, you should know the reason is because the one with the miracles is a greater saint than the other even though you don't know why. As Eliyahu the Prophet said, “if I am a man of God let fire come down from heaven.” He made the test of his righteousness dependent on a miracle. This test would leave all present-day rabbis out in the cold.

 

·

 

The reason some psychic people or even saints lack certain knowledge is that part of their soul is missing. Some saint/psychics can advise on everything until it comes to a monetary issue, where their love for it blinds them. Also, in a more general way this explains why only one Jewish saint saw the truth about Jesus even though there were many other saints before and after him. This also explains how Rabbi Akiva could decide that Bar Kochba was the Messiah - the Messiah frequency was missing in his radio.

 

·

 

It was revealed to the Baal Shem Tov that he came to his high level not so much from the learning of the Talmud as from the Mikvah. The Noam Elimelech said: Moses came to his level by doing unifications every day immediately (in the morning) when he woke up. [The Ari said Moses and Binyahu ben Yehodaya both did that type of service.] Rabbi Nachman said the main thing is “hisbodedut”, private conversation with God.

 

These are three types of Divine service that three saints said could bring a person to a high spiritual level. I wonder if these maybe are the “three types of service” that the Messiah revealed to the Baal Shem Tov that if any person would do them along with three specific unifications, they would be able to “make unifications and rise to the higher worlds like you.”

 

The Baal Shem Tov had to swear not to reveal them, but it would make sense to say that he himself did them. Though he did many types of service we know the mikvah was a major factor. For other things he did, we would only be guessing if they help. Anyone could suggest a bunch of things that happened to appeal to them, like learning Gemara, learning Zohar, fasting, davening early at sunrise, saying the midnight prayer, this would all be speculation. But on those three things [Meditation on God's Divine names, private prayer, mikvah] we have the testimony of three saints that they work. 

 

·

 

Rabbi Nachman is the level of Messiah of David who combines Royalty with Beauty and whose higher root is the Crown. Jesus is on the level of Messiah of Joseph whose root is Foundation and whose higher root is Wisdom. One needs both - as one sephirah by itself produces no energy. Only when they revolve around each other are useful fruits produced

 

·

 

The way of telling if a person is a saint is if you feel good around them. This is because holiness permeates the area surrounding a saint.

 

·

 

There are two kinds of saints: the hidden and the visible. The hidden saint is accelerating towards God and thus is invisible to inertial observers some or all the time. The world-line of this saint is a hyperbola (which is the root of the letter Kaph), which stands for the crown, for this saint is on the level of the crown. [This is due to the fact that an event horizon can result from acceleration, not just a gravitational field.]

 

 

 

 

 

Section III - Politics

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 1 – Politics and the Torah

 “Without true virtue, God is just a word.” [Plotinus II:9]

 

“They make merchandise out of you.” [Peter II]

 

 

·

 

Because some people believe their purpose in life is to have pleasure, the Torah wanted to take the major body of the Torah government out of their hands, [the judicial branch the local, the circuit and supreme courts, and the police] and put it into the hands of the intellectuals [Aristotle's politically minded people], that is people that had semicha [rabbi from rabbi up to Moses] so that in no way could the whims of the general people decide who should be a rabbi. This, of course, is no guarantee, since people always get the government, they deserve, and the intellectuals aren't going to be all that much better or worse than the regular populace.

 

However, a little bit better it does remain. The way, however, that it ensures that the rabbis don't become a self-serving bureaucracy is by the ability of the people to choose the king who is in control of the military.

 

The reason why the Torah does give some power to the people even though they see pleasure as being the purpose of their lives is that pleasure is a guide to correct conduct. It isn't a goal, but it is a guide to the actions that God considers correct. But it only comes into the category of good if it is done for the sake of God.

 

 

·

 

Politics and religion are closely related, for we find that before the Edict of Toleration, only 10% of Romans were Christian, but within a few years after that, the vast majority became Christian. This is one reason why rabbis and priests guard their power so closely - it really is for the sake of God- to keep people religious. But the externalization of religion is the death of inner religion and piety so the Torah limits the laws that can be imposed on people and essentially takes religion out of the hands of man and sets up the rabbis only to clarify points of the law about which some doubt arises and judges and police to enforce the law. In essence the Torah is the constitution, and the Sanhedrin is to interpret the Torah but not to change it.

 

·

 

The argument of Rousseau and John Locke is dependent on the two worlds of chaos and correction. Locke has individual rights reigning supreme and Rousseau the general good. The root of their disagreement is in the worlds of tohu and tikun [chaos and correction]. A synthesis of their idea would be to bring the vessels of correction and the light of chaos together so that individual rights can be contained in the outside order.  However individual rights or public good have absolutely no weight in Torah thought, whether the written or Oral Law. You may find some hint here or there, but these are not Torah ideas. The Torah has only one idea: Serve God and keep his laws and if you serve other gods then woe is to you. However, implicit in Torah thought is the idea that you cannot add to the laws which implies that no man can impose further restrictions than what is already given once in the Torah, and which will never change

 

·

 

The system of the Torah is not centralized system. The Sanhedrin at the time was only to decide cases of law where the litigants came to them. The king was to guard the borders and fight the wars. The kings of Israel were heads of the army, not judges to teach, lay down or enforce the law. Just like today the president is the head of the armed forces (the limits to the power of a King are a subject of debate in the Gemarah). [To one opinion in the Gemara there is no commandment to have a King at all. The Torah only says, “when you will ask for a King.” It doesn't say you should do so.

 

 

·

 

Rabbi Meir from Rotenburg the rabbi (teacher) of the Rosh said, “No law could apply to a community unless the community accepted it first.” The Talmud says, God told Moses that one can't appoint a leader over a community unless one first asks the community. That was a case where God and Moses both knew the right person. Thus, we find some idea of democracy in the Talmud (even though the idea was that what the people thought mattered but that they wouldn't accept the leader even if God said to unless they were asked first). But I must point out the Sanhedrin wasn't voted on. They received semichah from a rebbi who received it before them, who received it before them, etc., until Moses. (Today there is no semichah.) The actual amount of power given to the king is a debate in Mesechet Sanhedrin. In one opinion he has very little power and in another he is a real monarch. And the King is chosen by a prophet or the Sanhedrin. So, Democracy seems to have no root from the Torah. And this is amazing, since the Torah does deal with social and political and civil issues.

 

 

·

 

So, in conclusion freedom within Biblical Law is an important principle of the Bible and the Oral Law -- not democracy. The Torah allows the Jewish people to choose any type of king or government it wants, in any way it wants. All that matters to the Torah is the fulfillment of the mitzvot; it really doesn't care what type of government there is. It is well borne out by history that every form of government has had periods in reigns of terror and periods in freedom. The government will never be better than the people of the country.

 

I think the Torah ignores the question of the form of government because it felt that it is irrelevant. All that really matters is whether a particular group of people have a desire to be formed into a body-politic or a commonwealth. If they do, then whatever form of government, they chose is ok as long as the laws of the Torah are kept. Theoretically, this could be even a Democracy since the Rambam says the people of each town chose their representative to send to the Sanhedrin, and this could have been done by a vote while the act of ordination [semicha] could have been a final formality.

 

·

 

The political laws of the Torah are statistical laws based on the normal distribution of a large number of people. So, the law of voluntary war is that non-Jewish nations will subject Israel or be subjected by Israel as is the case with all nations, there always has to be one that imposes its will on the others or there is chaos and constant war.

 

·

 

It is interesting to note that the laws of the Bible deal mainly with Temple, the prohibition of idols, and civil law. According to the Bible, there are only relativity few religious things which one should do like Shabbat and tefilin. I know that's not the same thing as freedom of religion but it’s a lot different than religious intolerance in orthodox communities today or in history (light only flows within the vessels of the sephirot when it is unconstricted, not when it’s frozen in some frigid environment of fear, or when constricted into some unnatural form. The Torah gives certain boundary conditions, but besides that, “Thou shalt not add or subtract”.

 

·

 

Therefore, the Torah provided a system that point's up, yet would give them an enormous amount of freedom (within the basic political structure) for each individual to decide for himself how to get there. Societies where there was tremendous intellectual growth were not religiously or politically free societies. The Renaissance which existed and flourished in Italy a hundred years before it even reached the rest of Europe took place in a society of political intrigue and Papal rule. Mozart lived under the reign of Fredrick II. Socrates did pretty well in Athens for all his 90 years or so until it got to be a democracy and they killed him (Freedom and tolerance are important but have little to do with the type of government, rather with the type of people of the society.) Authoritarian rule can be rational if it is to cause the growth of the people. Revolution is justified only when the rule is not for the benefit of the people, but not because of the type of government.

 

·

 

Shmuel said, “there is no difference between this world and the days of the Messiah except for subjection by governments.” This seemed to have started at least with the concept of the Magna Carta. This is the beginning of the 6th thousand-year period which is when the Zohar says the process of the redemption will start, going every 60 years up to a higher level (now this statement of Shmuel is the subject an argument in the Gemarah: Rabbi Yochanan said the prophecies of all the prophets apply to the days of the Messiah, the Rambam brings both so he seems also to be saying that the redemption is a process that takes place over a long period of time and rising from level to level.)

 

·

 

Now a democracy really shouldn't be any different than any tyranny for the masses can be just as evil as any dictator, however statistically speaking a large body of people aren't going to be too far from the mean (average value), so generally a democracy won't be too good or too bad (as long as one individual doesn't seize power), while any other form will vary according to who is the king at that time.

 

Therefore, one can ask why doesn't the Torah require a Democratic form of government? The answer is that the people did in fact choose their own king, for the Torah addresses the Jewish people as a whole “place upon you a king”, and the idea of the prophet or the Sanhedrin deciding was the way the people decided. (The Torah doesn't specify the way to pick and just leaves it up to the people themselves. And this is the smartest thing because it really doesn't make any difference. People get the type of government they deserve and the kind of life they deserve and the kind of spouse they deserve.) [The way the people decided who would be king is by the Sanhedrin or the prophet. Either way was acceptable.]

 

·

 

Every utopia has failed. From “The City of God” of Saint Augustine and the “Utopia” of Thomas Moore and Plato's “Republic”. Zionism which assumed that since the Jews were financially successful in foreign lands, they would be all the more so in their even failed since Israel exists on the money of American Jews. Even the Democracy in the U.S.A. is becoming increasingly totalitarian in nature. The answer is the Baal Ha Tanyas idea which is really from the kabbalah, but the Baal Ha Tanya shows how to use it. We need chaos and order together, i.e., we need the light of chaos in the vessels of order, freedom in an ordered society and inter­connected world. This can only be with Jews who have the power of combining opposites. Yet freedom must exist because every person has his own higher roots that they must adhere to but only within the vessels of order. The only system that has a chance of working is an integrated system. The Torah system could have worked by itself (for the Jewish people) until many of its secrets fell into scattered places. Even the written law was only given on the physical level and is the garment of the inner-Torah. And the laws of the Torah are the body of the Torah. But only the Soul of the Torah is the real Torah. So even though the written law is perfect, the deeper philosophical political and esoteric, and scientific ways of understanding of it have been forgotten and lost (as the Rambam has already stated in reference to the philosophical and scientific secrets of the Torah).

 

·

 

The underlying principle of the Torah is kindness and justice. There always has to be one country imposing its polices on everyone else for there not to be chaos. The idea of the Torah was to have that country be Israel in order that the polices should be civilized. If in fact the state of Israel would be in the place of America today, its polices would in fact be even more tolerant and civilized than America. So, gentiles believing in the Bible come into the category of “Thou shalt love thy neighbor like thyself”— the sages say that this means “people that are with you in Torah and commandments”. Many Sages said that the gentiles become a part of the body of the Jewish people by their acceptance of the Bible [i.e., Christianity and Islam]. This may seem forced, but without this idea, the Torah, Talmud and Shulchan Aruch are definitely fascist. [However, if Islam today wouldn't be a sworn enemy of the Jewish people, it would revert back to being a branch of the Judaism and it would be a commandment to love Muslims.]

 

 

·

 

The Rambam holds that one can accept a ger toshav From Amalek. Therefore, in his opinion the seven commandments of Noach take even the Seven nations or Amalek out of the category of Milchemet Mitzvah. Since the mitzvot of obligatory war and non-obligatory war are semuchim [adjacent] they are parallel. Therefore, the seven mitzvot take other nations out of the category of non-obligatory war [to the Rambam]. This provides a different basis of looking at non-Jews other than the accepted way. The accepted way however is the opinion of the authorities brought in Shulchan Aruch. At any rate even to the other authorities, taxation on other nations is a political necessity. One nation in the world has to be the policeman.  The reason one state in America isn't a threat to another is that the Federal government is over them all.

 

·

 

Freedom is an implicit principle in the Torah for even if we accept the principle of making a fence that the majority of the Sages held by the fence still has to be around the laws themselves and not infringe on personal or public and individual freedoms more than absolutely necessary for the continuance and fulfillment of the Biblical laws. [and in fact, if the majority of the people don't accept the rabbinical law it has no validity anyway which is why the oil of non-Jews is permitted even though it was from the 18 rabbinical laws of Hillel and Shamai.] In fact, the whole baal tshuva movement and the orthodox Judaism of today are really just escapes from freedom. For modern man in general is terrified of freedom and so within the disguise of the Torah they still have to make up more and more restrictions and justify it by pretending that the Bible requires it. Now it is true that freedom per say is not an important principle in the Torah, but the Torah has an idea much more powerful: Don't add and don't subtract from these laws. So, with the giving of the Torah God created the social national body of Jewry but took away from the government the ability to impose its’ man made restrictions.

 

·

 

 

The church in its inception felt they could take anything beautiful or good or true in the pagan society they lived and incorporate it into their practice. Throughout the centuries the church has adapted and incorporated many of the customs of the people of the area it went into. The failure of the church to adapt to the customs of India and China and learn from the many good traditions they have, has defeated its progress there. Judaism has much to learn from this. Rather than abandoning the basic principle of the Torah [belief in the Oral and Written Law] as the alternative movements have done in Judaism, we should keep the principles but also not be afraid to learn what is good and beautiful from others.True Torah life can take root among all Jews, but it must adapt to the sensitivities and nature of the people in each area and community. Any attempt to impose the fascist Judaism of Brooklyn and the ultra-orthodox in Israel on the rest of Jewry will fail.The Baal Shem Tov and his followers were the last leaders to know this principle. [It so happens that they were saints also, but in practical terms they also knew the need to adapt to the people and see the higher spiritual root of each community they were in. Many of the customs they explained the higher spiritual significance of were indigenous to those communities and not customs carved in stone for all people everywhere. This was the attitude of the rabbis of the Talmud also. However, those were unique times for in general God has promised the Jewish people that   their rabbis and leaders would be evil and misguide them. Thus, rabbi Yochanan cried every time he came to that verse that said this and he said a servant whose master has promised to misguide him what hope is there for him. I, however, can answer this. Ignore the rabbis and do rather what you know the Torah to be saying.

 

·

 

One could ask, “Isn't the Torah the exact equivalent of fascism?” Isn't its stated aim to achieve world dominion and to enslave all the nations of the world to the Jewish nation and to kill all Jews that don't keep the Torah as they do and all nations that don't submit to their rule?

 

The answer would be to this, that the European nations are actually from the ten tribes, and the rest of the world, in as far as they accept Christianity or Islam, come into the category of Gerei Toshav [semi-converts] and the Torah obviously isn't saying to enslave them since there is an explicit command to make sure they are provided for, i.e. if they have enough for themselves — fine, and if not, you are required to give them charity. Incidentally, a Ger Toshav according to one opinion in Mesechet Gerim, is someone who accepts on themselves not to do idolatry [which, as I have mentioned, includes even the Catholic church — according to the Rashba and the Meiri — since they aren't worshiping the statues but using them to concentrate on the souls of the saints they represent, and ask them to pray for them, or for their blessing which the Sages say is permitted and in fact said that a person that has a sick person at home must go to the sage of his city to ask him to pray for him.]

 

Only with regard to idolatrous nations does the Torah say to conquer or be conquered. This explanation doesn't help King David however, for he went to conquer for profit, but I do have an explanation of King David i.e., that he said go conquer a “troop”, i.e., people that were going to pillage. [I believe this is a very important new thought. However, this isn't to all authorities as we see in the Shulchan Aruch. But this answer is in accordance with the spirit of the Rambam who puts Goyim that are scientists and philosophers on a higher level than the Jewish people and he wouldn't agree with going around killing and pillaging the goyim and taking those who surrender for slaves and tribute.]

 

·

 

The exact difference between Rabbi Nachman and the Medieval Authorities of the Torah is the same as the Difference between Martin Luther and the Catholic Church.

 

To Rabbi Nachman and Martin Luther salvation is dependent completely on faith, and in particular faith in some saint. However, in the Catholic faith and to the Rambam we find the affirmation of man's dignity and the belief that man could aspire to be like God based on his own efforts.

 

Yet, I would like to suggest that Rabbi Nachman is a bit different than Luther since Luther's idea of faith was negative -- it was a reaction against doubt rooted in his negative feeling about life. Rabbi Nachman's idea of faith was an expression of oneness with the Creator and affirmation of Life. It is faith in God as He is manifested in one's own heart.

 

This is the reason Rabbi Nachman's doctrine doesn't lend itself to authoritarians that want to claim to be his representatives. However, Martin Luther is responsible for the idea of the importance of every person as an individual, not as part of a group, and no one but him can claim authorship of that idea.

 

·

 

Freedom from tyranny of another nation was the original redemption from Egypt. Then, only freedom from another nation constituted redemption. There never was a concept of freedom from your own king until 1215. The Magna Carta, which was 25 years before the year 5000 in the Jewish calendar -- when the 2nd redemption started -- constitutes freedom in such a way that even the government of your own country can't infringe on your freedom.

 

The idea of freedom of the individual arose only at the time of Martin Luther. [Later I noticed that Hegel also saw history as progress towards freedom]. The Redemption is from the sepherah of Binah understanding and the more the light of this sepherah is revealed in the world the more redemption there is since “all freedom comes from Understanding”

 

Yet the Sages also said “judgements are awoken from Understanding”. So, freedom has brought a price with it. For in the Middle Ages there was a large degree of security for the individual. There were the guilds [unions] which provided steady work. The financial reality was local and personal and not based on greed but on life and people. The real purpose of life was salvation. Greed was one of the cardinal sins. This attitude affected how business was done. The rise of the modern state and capitalism has created two types of people: 1) the callous that has been born and bred to know that he has the face the world alone and has little sympathy for anyone especially in business;2) the fearful of this vast aloneness of the world and run into totalitarian systems to provide them with emotional and financial support. This is the cause of fascism and communism and the rise of the fundamentalist religions today orthodox Judaism, fundamentalist Islam and Fundamentalist Christianity and the Eastern cults. None of this has to do with an intellectual search for truth but for security in an insecure world. Thus, whatever truth may have been in any or all of these religions has been obliterated to make fundamentalist doctrines that would feed the need of the people. The world today is a lonely place. Friendships are for instrumentality. Love is another word for usefulness. My only answer in this book is to stick with your family and true friends people that you know have a true love for you. This is worth more than all theology and even true religion and faith put together. I don't think we should go back to the Middle Ages. This advice of mine is to provide true support in the world that is lonely and insecure, and bypass authoritarian systems that will fail. For in the long run Man won't give up his freedom and the all the cults like Fundamentalist Islam or Orthodox Judaism will rise and fall like fascism. [Freedom is a need of the human spirit, not a want] [Later I saw that Hegel also saw the impossibility of return to the feudal system.] [Since the redemption is the process of Understanding coming into the world the individual becomes freer, has more problems, and the political entity enlarges from city states, to a city that rules over an Empire [the Roman Empire]to feudal estates joined by an informal alliance making an informal state to the age of the formal state to the present age of informal globalization. Next, I suppose would come formal globalization.

 

·

 

To assume that people act in a certain way irrelevant of the doctrine they follow is simply not true. The laws people believe in affect their character. Statistically speaking if you measure people's prejudice before you pass a law outlawing prejudice and then immediately after you pass the law you measure it again, the amount of prejudice is found to be reduced significantly. So, if the rabbis of the Talmud itself say all problems in the world come from the rabbis of each generation and we see the doctrine they follow is that of the Talmud itself, we know that something is missing in that doctrine that is needed to make people righteous. The reason is as the Ari says that the laws are given from the aspect of the Tree of Knowledge of good and evil, not from the aspect of the Tree of life which is the Kabbalah.

 

·

 

The Orthodox who excelled in piety in Poland, Slovakia and Rumania were wiped out. In Rumania were the Jews of Transylvania who were ultra-orthodox, the Jews of Bukovina, who were Chassidim and the Jews of Bessarabia, who were traditionalist, and the Jews of Old Romany who were assimilated. They were all wiped out except for the assimilated Jews of Old Romany, and all the non­religious Jews who didn't listen to the rabbis and emigrated to America or became Zionists and went to Israel. It has been said to me that the rebbes wanted their Chasidim to die righteous in Europe and not unrighteous in America or Israel, but then why did Rabbi Wasserman try to escape – it is only because the axle of his wagon broke that he went back (as he said himself). Did the axle decide the halachah?!? First the halachah was the Jews should live, and then the axle determined that they should die? Some have tried to say that the Gerer Rebbe urged his chassidim to leave, yet Rabbi Shimon Huberband wrote in the Warsaw Ghetto “The Rebbe of Ger, like the majority of Polish rebbes, opposed settlement in the land of Israel. If the Rebbe of Ger had ordered his chassidim, among whom were thousands of very rich industrialists, to make Aliyah to Eretz Israel, the situation of both the communities in Israel and in Poland would have been different”. They killed European Jewry by the hopes they inspired in them. [The Sages of the Talmud in fact say (Shabbat, page 139A) “If you see a generation in which judgments have come upon it, go out and inspect the judges of Israel, for all retributions that come into the world come because of the judges of Israel.” All this should be enough to disprove the religious view that the Jews of Europe were wiped out because they weren't religious enough. It would seem the opposite is true.

 

·

 

We Learn from Gödel’s second theorem that the only versions of formal number theory which assert their own consistency are inconsistent. This is a general problem for all humankind; for in fact how can anyone know if they themselves are sane? Don't they have to use their own logic to figure that out, but how can they trust their own logic if they are insane? Therefore, the majority of people are used as a guide to what is sane. Yet see where the majority of people have gotten us! The majority of people are selfish, cruel, and stupid. The world's history is that of war, crime, violence, and cruelty. [And the psychologists who determine what is normal behavior have the highest divorce rate of any group in America.] [Also, I noticed something strange about those who go into psychiatry. They are usually the particularly weird ones that have a need to fit in. And invariably they are the ones that the studies in university are done on. So, you have a neurotic group of people dictating to the rest of humankind the standards of normal behavior and they have their studies on their own neurotic group to back up their claims.]  Throughout history it has always been the ones who refused to fit in that have contributed the ideas necessary to making the world any better.

 

Chapter 2 – The Baal Teshuva Movement

 

·

 

Fear of freedom caused many people to go into Orthodox Judaism or other authoritarian cults. But by trust in God and confidence that God truly runs the world, one can face the future without fear. “One person can't touch what is meant for someone else”. However, it is important as one faces the world without the moral support of some vast group to feel a part of, that one sticks with his family and true friends. “Praise God all families of the Earth.” [I am not implying however that all authority is bad. There is rational authority and non-rational authority, i.e., authority that is intended for the growth and future self-sufficient independence of the subject is good authority. Authority which has in mind to keep the subject indefinitely dependent on the leader is evil.]

 

·

 

There is a great crusade to indoctrinate non-religious college age people into the orthodox community. From many aspects this looks attractive except for one point. They themselves form an organic community. It is an entire network. When they have a strain in their marriage, they increase their interaction with friends and family and receive a large degree of support therefrom. The newcomers however are never really integrated into the community and therefore when they have a strain the community doesn't help and usually hurts considerably and since they broke their ties with their own families, they get no support from there either [of course there is some token help but nothing that really helps. And especially if they marry someone religious from birth or more integrated into the community than they will have to face an entire community effort to break up their marriage, and take their children and money as is already well known from common occurrences everyday.]

 

There is a deep reason for this for everything below has its roots above, and the several non-orthodox movements within Judaism have their roots up above that are different than the orthodox. It's not that they are right. Those movements are wrong on many points. However, the non-religious Jews that belong to them come from a different spiritual root than the orthodox. In many ways that root is higher than that of the orthodox. And so, one who comes to join the Orthodox will not be accepted, not because of anything wrong with him or them but because they in fact have the innate intuition to realize what he doesn't realize; that he doesn't belong with them.

 

·

 

One of the great problems I see today in Yiddishkeit is that it is an ethnic religion that tends to ignore a great force that is inside every person. That is the force of humanity, i.e., of being human. In theory this part of a person is totally ignored and all that is paid attention to is the Jewish part of a person. What is wrong with this - other than it being contrary to the Rambam - is that there is apparently a force of decency and compassion that if ignored or suppressed can be stamped out.

 

Since I deal in this book with the Kabbalah, and the Kabbalah is clear that the only good part of any person is the Jewish part, I have to assume this force which I call the force of humanity, is in fact a Jewish force that has become adopted among the nations either by their own religions which have accepted Jewish principles or the exile of Jews among the nations, or the exile of the ten tribes “north”, i.e., into Europe apparently becoming the north European nations. At any rate, this force of humanity, I believe, is what the kabbalah calls yechida, the genius of the species. Chaya is the genius of the nation. The soul is the genius of the tribe, or state of the nation. Spirit is the genius of the family and the nefesh is the individual soul. Thus, the higher one rises spiritually the more he cares about others.

 

Thus, the emphasis of the Torah on the Jewish people specifically only applied until the non-Jewish nations also began to gain the yechida, the genius of the species. For up till that time only the Jewish people embodied that genius. Thus, according to this way of thinking the inner spirit of humanity is what the Torah really means by Jewish.

 

This is the reason why one must stick with one's family, since they are manifestations of one's spirit. Now the urge and longing for spirituality isn't from the soul, which is just a vessel for the Divine light, but rather from the Divine light itself. Thus, there is usually a tendency on the part of the soul to stick with his own family, friends, neighborhood, country -- while from the Divine light one wants to go off searching for something. As in all things one should find the middle path.

 

Many times, one is taught to find the Divine Will in the teachings of his rebbi or other saint or head of his yeshiva. Yet it is more in accordance with the Torah to find this guidance in the world at large. The universe is God's yeshiva. The real spiritual teachers are the people that really care about you, because they have the most intuitive understanding of your own soul. Being born in America, makes one’s nation [not people] America, however being Jewish makes one also part of the Jewish people. The fact is, no matter how Jewish one is, he partakes of the character of the country he was born in, and no matter how much he partakes of that character, inside he remains Jewish. This isn't the same as the difference between politics and religion which should remain separate. [UNFORTUNATELY, IT DOESN'T SINCE POLITICS HAS BECOME A RELIGION — Liberalism, Zionism, Religious Zionism, and Anti-Zionism are all religions now. I think it was better when religion was religion and politics was politics.]

 

·

 

The problem with Orthodox Judaism today is that its ethics is based on an end, i.e., the advancement of itself, and that is very different than a morality based on the Divine Will [as per the first authorities] or on Reason [as per the Rambam]. The value of any end depends on its being set by Reason or the Divine Will and the advancement of Orthodox Judaism isn't an end stated or implied in the Torah. The Torah's morality is to do the mitzvot in order to get to be attached to God. [Since Orthodox ethics is end-based, this explains why in the mind of the orthodox it is permitted to lie, cheat, steal, kidnap and murder in order advance their movement, for to their way of thinking the advancement of their movement is all that matters. Only an ethics that is principle-based avoids these problems. However, Safardic Jewish ethics has been principle based until recently and thus their version of Torah ethics was much closer to the Torah. Also, Torah Ethics even with Ashkenazi Jewry was largely principal base in Russia and Poland. Only at the turn of the century did the socialist ideals floating around infected them and then it became a socialist movement and thus it remains until today.]

 

 

 

Chapter 3 - THE U.S.A.

 

“Nothing in America is so painful as the lack of joy. Pleasure is frantic and bacchanalian, a matter of momentary oblivion not of delighted self-expression. Men sit throughout the day glued to their desks, amid typewriters and telephone, serious, important and worthless.”

-Bertrand Russell

 

 

·

 

America is becoming increasingly totalitarian. This could spell the beginning of the end for it. I do believe however that there still is some hope for America. There needs to be a balance between secular and religious forces, because if either becomes the sole force we would have tyranny. And the worst thing would be if they worked together. The best thing is if they both remain sworn enemies of each other and hopefully that will leave an “empty space” in between for the decent people. We need to safeguard the things modern democracy and capitalism have accomplished in freedom for the individual. But we need to continue this process by an integration with the Bible.

 

The reason America is becoming a police state is that freedom is being confused with the idea of protection of the rights of individuals. In a capitalistic free-flowing society, there are basic patterns of flow like in an ant colony where the free flow reinforces the caste system. When the government is perceived as the way for one group of people to get the money of another group, which they assume is their right, since they are the majority, the state becomes a police state. All people are born equal — this means born with the right to enjoy the fruits of their labor or intelligence. But it doesn't mean born with the right to someone else's money. But today that is exactly what Americans thinks. Therefore, America is doomed unless it goes back to its Christian roots. Yet the decay of a nation and its values can be the rebirth of something greater.

 

Perhaps it is the idea of a religious democracy, in place of the secular democracy. That is a democracy based on the majority rule, but with the Bible as its constitution [AS in fact John Locke envisioned in the first place.]

 

Actually, the problem of America is, as Hegel saw, that when any society gets to the point of self-reflection it is at its peak and then must start the decay. Hegel didn't know the reason for this, but I think it is from Gödel theorem. The venerability of TNT is that it is capable of expressing statements about itself.

 

Once America saw the contradiction of the Bible and the principles of democracy it felt it had to go in one direction or the other. But they didn't know that the whole strength of America depended on that contradiction, not on one or the other or both but the contradiction itself. [Perhaps this is the reason Rome fell, they became totally religious, instead of the necessary combination of religion and secularism together.]

 

 

·

 

The power of America is from the individual. In the past, democracies didn't work for there first had to be the correction of the vessels by monarchies combining the sparks and combining the vessels of tikun. Then the light of chaos could be drawn into the vessels of correction in England and America. (The idea here is that the vessels of chaos weren't combined together and therefore they broke when the light hit them, thus democracies whose strength is from the individual all broke and were short lived throughout history. In the USA there used to be a large degree of individual freedom but a strong central government which provided the political stability needed to keep it together.

 

·

 

In America, adults can live any type of depraved life style they want but the youth are expected to live pure and holy and innocent life styles. The reason for this is that the sexual hormones are activated exactly on the 18th birthday. If the adults expect the youth to act righteously then they should do so themselves, and if they refuse because “you can't legislate morality” then let them, not legislate morality to the youth.

 

·

 

The world has to oscillate between two poles, with the Jews in the middle:

●       Ancient Greece and Rome.

●       Rome and Byzantium

●       Christianity and Islam

●       England and France.

●       Europe and the East.

●       The USA and Russia.

 

The oscillation between the two poles is a good thing. This creates a freedom in the middle for people to grow and develop, but problems arise when each side assumes it’s a two person zero sum game, i.e., what one side wins the other side loses. In that case the conflict creates a situation where both sides lose. By cooperation both would increase the market for their ideas.

 

·

 

There are two tendencies now:

One, is the expansion of the political entity from state into a global state. But since that spreads the power thinly there is an opposite tendency to contract the political entity into ethnic religious groups and global corporations [economic states]. The conflict between these two forces causes a pattern of chaos to emerge. The second pattern is back to the Middle Ages when there was not “state”, just loyalty to the Catholic church or to Islam in a general (but very real way) and to one's particular landowner or feudal lord or prince. In the U.S.A. the courts no longer judge by the constitution, but by who has more money to buy a better lawyer - and juries now always decide along ethnic lines.

 

The second way is because of peoples tremendous fear of freedom and the intense emotional isolationism of today. Therefore, ideas of globalization which are simply another form of colonialism can't apply in countries where the center of mass is the ethnic principle like the countries of South East Asia. It is likely that those countries will eventually confiscate the assets of American and European investors.

 

·

 

Once the light of enlightenment [Royalty] was in Israel, then it passed to ancient Greece, then to Rome, and then to Europe. The light shone from Europe to America. Now a civilized a nation is judged by how “Westernized” it is. That light will return to Israel, but the light of foundation is specifically for America.

 

·

 

To a large degree America and Israel seem to me to be very religious countries. For where there is freedom of religion, whatever religion or belief people have will be real, while where it is forced, it won't be real. A little bit of the real thing is much better than a lot of the wrong thing.

 

·

 

Freud suggested that the unconscious was the real cause of behavior, and that moral values were projections of the unconscious. Therefore, the idea of absolute values, responsibility and rationality was a myth. This thinking still shapes the minds of psychoanalysts and psychotherapists, and many have become influenced by that point of view. This is I believe the reason for the decay of values even among the pseudo religious that keep the rituals of each religion, but in terms of real morality are quite lacking.

 

·

 

We have come to the time Bertrand Russell feared, “When science has become venerable, it will control our lives as much as religion has ever. I foresee the time when all who care for the freedom of the human spirit will have to rebel against a scientific tyranny.” - Marriage And Morals, Bertrand Russell. However, this is to be taken in context. There are many standard procedures in medicine and valid approaches in psychology. These should be used.

 

The same Rabbi Nachman who despised doctors, when the first vaccine came out, said “you have to take your children even in the middle of the winter to the village where they are giving the vaccine.” – The appendix of the Book of 13 stories.

 

The general practice of Breslovers is to get three doctors opinions before any major procedure. The criticism here is on the character of psychologists and therefore automatically on their effectiveness.

 

·

 

John Adams wrote in his diary on his trip to New York to convince them to sign the Constitution, “I can't understand why everybody in New York is so nasty.” (This was when it's total population was only about 10,000). There is an extraordinary spirit of greed and anger in New York. It isn't reactionary anger, but anger which is ever present and only waiting for an opportunity to surface.

 

·

 

The freedom of the media to enter a court room is the only thing to check the power of judges in the USA. [In Hegel's ideal state also the court proceedings had to be public.]

 

·

 

I find it fascinating that everyone is worried about the moral issue of cloning. Already it is banned in Europe and America (even before it exists). Angry letters into the newspapers about scientists involved in cloning. Yet not a peep about abortion. I can only conclude that, in the western mentality, to destroy life is moral but to create life is immoral.

 

No wonder this last century has been so bloody. In the 1960's the goal in life of the majority of youth was to find a true life philosophy. Today it's to have money. We are digressing backwards. War can't be too far away. The dislike today of the scientists means that the connection between rulership and wisdom is gone and therefore rulership has fallen into stupidity and when that happens things tend to decay into chaos rapidly.

 

·

 

Some of the other things which are odd about America is the attitude towards sex. Homosexuality is legal but wholesome sex between people already biologically ready and in need of it is not (i.e., teenagers). But, then again, there is no concept of wholesome sex in America. If a man has sex with many women, it's legal as long as they aren't his wives; killing life by contraceptives and abortion and masturbation is considered OK but creating life by sex between teenagers who are biologically ready and have much more intense feelings of love than adults, is not. Creating life by cloning is not. Creating more life by granting men the right to many wives is not. Biblical values would do this and the world quite a bit of good.

 

·

 

The transfer of power in Russia from financial establishment to the intellectuals led to it being transferred to the military under communist rule. In America, the transfer of power from the political financial establishment to the intellectual led to the destruction of the American family. One reason would be that the intellectuals are usually from the wisdom of the evil-side, since they don't in general accept faith as their guide. Wisdom, if not connected with God falls into the evil-side. Also, another reason is that logic without the heart is a poor guide, and in those cases logic, not the heart was the guide. Another way of looking at this is that the sepherah of Royalty is the same as that for Faith {Malchut}, so Rulership is dependent on faith. Wisdom is good when it flows in Faith, but by itself it gives its flow to the wrong side.

 

·

 

Psychology today is essentially a manifestation of peoples fear of freedom. Therapy is dependency on a magic helper — the therapist. The purpose of Psychology is to convince people that they need a therapist and then to use that need as a proof that they are accomplishing something. Psychology is the escape from responsibility.

 

·

 

Super people are most creative yet the psycho-therapists and psycho-analysts destroy them by convincing them that there is something wrong with them and forcing them thus to conform. To a psycho-therapist, the worst sin is not fitting in, not being adjusted. With this as the working principle of our society of which we have given the pseudo-science of psychotherapy legal authority, we have destroyed all our potential geniuses. God forbid, if a social worker or a psycho-therapist had ever gotten their hands on a Beethoven or a Mozart — both with “abusive” fathers.

 

The only reason they may have anything to show for their false science is the fact that everybody needs someone to talk to that won't be judgmental, will listen without interrupting, and just render impartial advice as best they can, [that is the reason there were Catholic priests]. The Devil couldn't destroy America all by himself since he is only one angel, so he sent the psycho therapists to do his work for him.

 

·

 

There can't be spiritual growth in New York, since the city is the root of the broken vessels which don't connect with each other. Growth can only be in a friendly atmosphere. You can be a saint in NY, but I don't think you can grow.

 

·

 

The political chaos that ensues at the breakup of the family is what destroyed the Roman Empire, Renaissance, Italy and, unless we wake up, America. The reason for the breakup of the family is the erosion of the place of the father. What could save it is to nullify the idea of separation church and state — which in fact is not in the constitution. All it says is there shall not be a national church. OK, then let each state choose its own State Church.

 

The only countries in Europe that stood up to the Nazis were the ones that never had division of church and state, as has been noted by others. In fact, the Jews had a relatively good time in Germany for 2000 years until they threw out Jesus in the 1800's. Einstein noted that only the churches in Germany stood up to the Nazis, not the intellectuals, or the universities. [I assume he meant the Lutheran churches, which were the ones that spoke against the Nazis as far as I know.]

 

It has been noted that the Pope of that time chose diplomacy over courage, but it has been shown that he saved the Jews of Italy by choosing carefully with which issues to confront the Nazis. Edith Stein was killed because the nuns of her Catholic Church did in fact stand up to the Nazis. The run of the mill Lutheran pastors talked against the Nazis then were threatened to be gassed and then some kept talking until they were gassed, and others shut up. I wonder today when millions of people were being wiped out in Rwanda, how many of you shed a tear, or even barely noticed?

 

·

 

The effect of the scientist on society isn't by what he says but by what people think he says.

 

·

                                                                                  

People have always been killing each other for all types of reasons. It used to be territory or plunder. Then for religion. Then for nationalism. Then for the struggle between communism and democracy. If it won't be for one reason it will be for another until the final redemption of mankind comes.

 

Anything that matters a lot to people they will kill for. The only time people will stop killing each other is when nothing makes any difference to them anymore.

 

Now, at some point in our history religion mattered. However, religion hasn't mattered to people for a long time. Now that secularism has lost it potency, religion will again become the reason people do good or evil.

 

 

 

 

Section IV - Ideas

 

 

 

 

Chapter 1 – Ideas in Kabbalah - The Song of the Soul

 

Introduction

 

Science and Kabbalah are two distinct fields with apparently no relationship between them. However here is my intention to show how each can illuminate the other as long as each keeps to its respective parameters.

 

Mathematics is the lowest sepherah of the spiritual world and the highest of the physical, as Rabbi Luria says “the essence of numbers is in the sepherah of Royalty”, so its’ laws govern both disciplines. Rabbi Issac Luria uses a physical model to describe the spiritual reality (as per the Eitz Chayim).

 

In this section I attempt to show the mathematical principles of this reality. Further, as physics needs mathematical models to clarify itself, so the spiritual world needs physical models to make clear its meaning. These I also will attempt to show but bear in mind these are different worlds-- parallel but different, and each lower world provides a model for what is above it and is like a reflection in a pond. I think that every mathematical model has a corresponding spiritual and a corresponding physical reality. Now know, many will object that the formalist philosophy of mathematics claims that math only deals with abstract symbols that may or may not have a relation to reality. But this simply isn't true. Reality itself seems to be based on math, and mathematicians know this. They use the theory of numbers as an aid to gain knowledge about formal systems, and thus they show that in truth they believe that numbers are actually a part of reality.

 

 

·

 

Four types of flux (or Divine light) flow into the spiritual empty space: The Divine names 72, 63, 45, 52, i.e., gravitational, strong, weak, and electro-magnetic.

 

·

 

The four worlds of Emanation, Creation, Formation and Action correspond to the four types of space: metric space, normed space, Banach space, and Hilbert space - where for each different types of operations are valid.

 

[The Ari is clear that in AK even ideas of spiritual space don't apply so he is apparently talking about a spiritual space where the concept of distance dissolves — Isn't that Tensor space?]

 

In general, the Kabbalah seems to deal only with totally arithmetic operations [gematriot], except it hints to the other types of space only occasionally, e.g., when the Ramak brings down that:

 

  י2+ + ה2 ו2 + ה2 = 186 = place [makom]

 

which indicates that this is a 4-d place, and that a norm comes out to be the square root of 186... The 5 forms (partzufim) have their origin in the 5 flows from the name 72, 63, 45, 52, which are Gravitational, Strong, Weak, Magnetism-Electricity.

 

·

 

The relationship between the circular sephirot and the straight ones is that the 10-component curvature tensor of the circular sephirot is proportional to the 10-component energy-stress tensor of the straight ones.

 

(The Eitz Chayim seems clear that the basic existence of vessels, or what we call ‘matter’ is in the straight sephirot, and matter is best represented by the energy-stress tensor).

 

The constant of proportionality should be decided in a way that the normal 613 commandments for Jews and 7 commandments for the children of Noah should be reproduced under normal circumstances of weak fields and small velocities [i.e., that these basic laws of human conduct are invariable in all frames of reference and it is possible to understand their application in all situations if we can know the constants and exact formula, for, as of now I understand that the laws of the Torah are eternal and unchanging yet their application is unknown in many circumstances.]

 

The 10 components of the energy-stress tensor in the spiritual realm which describe the distribution and flux of energy and linear momentum of every sepherah or soul. This tensor follows the four laws of continuity which are from the four letters of the Ineffable Name. The ten components of the Einstein tensor (the rearrangement of the Ricci tensor) which deals with the curvature of spiritual and physical space-time is the source of the gravitational field.

 

The energy stress tensor describes the 10 straight sephirot and the Einstein vector is the 10 circular sephirot - Einstein figured out that they must be proportional - I'm just saying the same thing for the sephirot like he said for the vectors.

 

What this means is that the spiritual powers of the commandments and the ten statements as they condense into the physical realm become the energy stress tensor and the Einstein vector tensor. [That is, the commandments are a measure of the spiritual mass-energy (vessels and light) energy density and momentum of a person], this involves an approach to the sephirot different than the regular one, for here we are saying that the first 9 describe the components of the 3-d tensor which traditionally would be just 6 sephirot.

 

Thus, there are twenty amino acids which correspond to the twenty symbols of TNT which correspond to the twenty components of the curvature of four dimensional space, which correspond to the twenty components of the Einstein tensor and the mass energy tensor that have to be proportional according to Einstein. [See page 533 of Gödel, Escher, Bach].

 

Also, there are ten equations that describe a fluid in four and ten quantities that characterize that fluid corresponding to the ten sephirot of yosher and the ten of igulim...The correlations thus;

 

1)     I am the Lord p = p (n, s)

2)     Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain, T = (n, s)

3)     Remember the Sabbath day to keep it Holy, dr=[r+p]/n+nTds the first law of thermodynamics [conservation of energy]

4)     Honor thy father and thy mother, m=(r+p)/n
