The only thing that he said one must do regardless of whether it increases his personal devakus or not is to be by him for every Rosh Hashanah

 

·

 

Rabbi Nachman explains that in the higher Intelligence time goes slower and in that all the days of one’s life are instantaneous. The reason for this is that from the point of view of one who is moving at the speed of light all, events, future and past, appear simultaneously. Thus, the way to get attached to God, and included in that higher Intelligence, is by moving at the speed of light in spiritual terms. Of course, that is impossible for matter: therefore, one has to go into a closet and not be seen by himself or others, and then his wave function can be manifested, and he can become attached to God by attaching their thoughts to Him. However, since sin separates one from God as it says in the verse, “your sins were dividing between you and your God”, one needs go to the grave of Rabbi Nachman. However, the idea of serving God is not to be attached to any saint but to God alone; one should try to attach himself to God directly. Attaching oneself to a saint may not be idolatry, since the saint is attached himself to God, but it still isn't the main idea. However, unattachment to God as when one's mind is occupied with things separate from God, is idolatry. Yet, by faith that there is nothing besides Him, one can serve God by himself himself all things.

 

·

 

Rabbi Nachman apparently holds that prayer is above Torah, and the Talmud says learning Torah [even one word -- the mishnah in Peah makes clear that there is no lower limit to the amount, i.e., even an infinitesimal amount of learning is more than all the commandments -- which includes prayer] is above all mitzvot. One [Rabbi Nathan’s] explanation is that prayer for physical things is below Torah, as the sages mentioned about the student in an incident that he was praying when he should have been learning. Yet this isn't a good answer since Rabbi Yochanan disagrees in that very case and says, “If only a person would pray all day”.

 

The Baal HaTanya says in the latter days things have changed, and I thought this sounds outrageous; however, when we reflect on it, I think we can see his point. For the root of the Torah is the Name 45 and the root of the mitzvot is 52 and so perhaps after a certain point in time the flow of light shifted from going down [the name 45] to going up [52], so that now prayer connects one to the flow of light. As I always find that things the Baal HaTanya says that sound the most outrageous usually have the most sense.

 

·

 

The idea of Rabbi Nachman of life being like the form of the aleph means like the form of a Clothoid[13]. The highest level is an asymptote which can never be reached, for it is God himself. But, by being included in God, one reaches it. However, this is only on the level of the first infinity. In the Geometry where the asymptote is the second infinity, one has to start the process all over again. This is the reason why people’s lives are a series of ups and downs -- and the ups and downs get more frequent as time goes by but less dramatically, since the radius of curvature increases proportionally to how far you are from the origin [your birth]. This also explains why in the explanation of the higher repentance, Rabbi Nachman describes an integral, since in fact the x-coordinate of a person progressing towards that point is

 

x=an cosTd

 

This also explains the reason, for the /2 is the equation for uncertainty, which is the root of this universe, for this comes from the asymptotes of the formula for the Clothoid [a(/2)1/2,a(/2)1/2)

 

·

                                              

In the Christian world there has been a great debate between the two poles -- of individual spirituality versus that of the group, according to the level one holds in the hierarchy and the need to receive ones holiness from the rabbi or the priest etc.

 

Now Rabbi Nachman combines both poles. For, to him, the importance of belief in wise men is of utmost importance. Yet, he also stresses individual spirituality, and says that each person has in him a level of the Messiah. But he combines these ideas, for he says that one really has three centers of mass that he must revolve around: that of himself, of his friend and of his teacher.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Section V - Christianity

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 1 – Jesus Christ

 

·

 

The argument against Jesus is primarily based on the references in the Talmud against a certain Yeshu which was a common name at the time and the book “Seder Olam” refers to three Jesus's that lived at that time, and one that lived at the beginning on the second temple period who was the disciple of Rabbi Yehoshua Ben Chananya. Historically, there was a famous Jesus also at the actual time of the Destruction of the Temple that used to walk around the city of Jerusalem predicting it's doom. The Tikunai Zohar also has a reference against Jesus. However, in all fairness it seems likely that the Zohar and the Gemara were in fact referring to Jesus and in fact didn't like him.

 

·

 

Rabbenu Asher (the Rosh) writes at the end of Gittin that the Jesus mentioned there is not Jesus Christ. To say that the other places where that same person is mentioned in the Talmud are him would require a proof, of which there is none. In fact, the facts of the life of Jesus have been corroborated by at least 60 non-Christian documents, and none of the stories of the Talmud about Yeshu fit any of the facts about Jesus we are forced to admit that the Yeshu of the Talmud is not Jesus Christ, rather someone else at the beginning of the 2nd-Temple period who was a disciple of Rabbi Yehoshua Ben Perachiya, as the Talmud says, while Jesus Christ of Nazareth was born 400 years later.

 

·

 

According to Rabbi Avraham Abulafia, Jesus is the Messiah son of Joseph -- a preliminary stage before the Messiah son of David, i.e., the sephirah of Foundation. The concept of a messiah from Efraim is brought in the Gemarah Zohar, especially in the works of Rabbi Moshe Chayim Lutzato, and the Gra in Kol Hator (i.e., the sephirah of Foundation). (He [Rabbi Abulafia] also says things about the cross which would imply that Jesus didn't lose his high level of Messiah son of Joseph any time. Yet, he also says the verse “you shouldn't have a false god” applies to Jesus -- meaning that the church after him did fall into idolatry.)

 

What is significant about the opinion of Rabbi Abulafia is that all the major kabbalists accept him as an authority. Rabbi Chayim Vital quotes him extensively in vol. 4 of Shaarai Kedusha, and Rabbi Moshe Cordovaro quotes his books all throughout the Pardes. The Chida (Rabbi Chayim David Azulai) has a section on him in Shemos Hagedolim, and concludes that he was in fact a great saint). (The fact that Rabbi Abulafia did write this about Jesus is easy to see for anyone who wants to take the time to go to the basement of the national library at Hebrew University and look at the microfilm copies of his books.

 

(Professor Moshe Aidel has written and published extensively about Rabbi Abulafia.) (The Halachah in the long run will turn out to be that since the validity of Jesus is a debate among the Rishonim (authorities of the Middle Ages) either accepting him or not is valid according to the Torah rules, and neither one way or the other can be excluded from valid Judaism. (It would be pretty hard to exclude Rabbi Chayim Vital from valid Judaism after he has made his way into the Shulchan Aruch and the Mishna Berura. In fact, the authorities in the Shulchan Aruch sometimes hold an opinion, but then write that after they found out that the Kabbalah said differently, they withdraw it, for “who can go after the lion?”).

 

·

 

Rabbi Abulafia's idea is crystal clear. In a nutshell it is that Jesus was a prelude to the redemption. For, at the original breaking of the spiritual vessels of nekudim the vessel of the sephirah of Foundation (Jesus) broke because of the light coming into it from the higher sephirot -- which couldn't contain the light. After it fell with all the other broken vessels into the creation, God fixed it and brought it up to Emanation (its original place), and God strengthened it and gave it power to contain the light of Kindness. Therefore, Jesus being united with the trait of Foundation and containing the light of Kindness is a kind of pipeline for the light of Kindness to be drawn into the world.

 

·

 

This is different from Messiah of David who is united with the Trait of Royalty and has a different job in the world, the completion of the process. This idea of Jesus is in conformity with the New Testament, but is very different from the Christian idea of Jesus. Their idea of Jesus being a second giving of the Torah seems to be totally alien to Torah theology, however Rabbi Judah Ha Levi wrote in “the Kuzari” that both Christianity and Islam will share in the messianic benefits as branches of Judaism and were foretold in Ezekiel 37:17. The Rambam goes even further and says that Christianity and Islam spread the words of the Torah and “the law of truth” over the whole world. The amazing thing is to see how many of the major halachic authorities wrote along these same lines: Rabbenu Gershom, Rashi, the Rashba, Rav Sheshet [in Tosphot], the Beit Joseph, the Rema, and Rabbi Yakov Emden. [Rabbi Yaakov Emden calls Christianity the “part” of the Torah given to the non-Jew.]

 

·

 

At the time of the breaking of the vessels the sefirah of Foundation (of Akudim) fell into the world of Creation. And then God brought it back into the world of Emanation and drew into it the light of Kindness.

 

Therefore, Jesus being unified with the trait of Foundation had in him the light of kindness. But he was not a prophet, since he never claimed to have prophecy and never said, “Thus sayeth the Lord”. A prophet is connected to Victory or Splendor not to Foundation or Royalty like Messiah of Joseph or David.

 

·

 

Rabbi Moshe Chayim Lutzato in the Ginzei Haramchal, (pg. 246) seems to be referring to the aspect of the fall of Jesus to which Rabbi Abulafia also refers in which Jesus, became the subject of idol-worship of the church until the Reformation of Martin Luther.

 

·

 

That part of the soul of Jesus (the lowest of the 4 parts) may very well have been in hell until the time Rabbi Chayim Vital saw him rise from hell. This is like part of the soul of Samuel which Saul spoke with.

 

·

 

It is possible that Rabbi Abulafia is of the same opinion as Rabbi Moshe Chayim Lutzato that Jesus fell into the evil kelipot and that the Gemarahs about “that person” in fact refer to Jesus. That is the job of every righteous person to go into the klipot and to rise therefrom, so that by his rising he should bring all the sparks of holiness that have fallen there up with him. It is odd the Jews and Christians agree that Jesus went into hell. Their disagreement is on the duration of his visit and the purpose of it. They both are looking at the same event, but from different perspectives.

 

·

 

The Sages must have seen Jesus going into a black hole which led to the separate universe of the Christians and never saw him arrive — just suspended in space but from the perspective of Jesus he went in and came out of the white hole on the other side.

 

·

 

The root of Jesus is in the circular sephirot, therefore he is usually only accepted by non-Jews whose roots are also there. That is why Jesus is considered bad by Jews whose root is in the straight sepherot, for when they look at him they see him in an area which, relative to their position in the empty space is the klipot, but from the aspect of the circular sephirot it's the highest degree of holiness.

 

·

 

Since Jesus was from Joseph his holiness is hidden, “as the fish in the sea” (the blessing given to Joseph) — and therefore the Sages of the Talmud didn't recognize his greatness. We find that Rabbi Akiva thought Bar Kochba was the Messiah, and he endorsed him. We find many places were the Sages admit their fallibility. I don't see why we should attribute to them something they didn't hold applied to them. (In fact, we see in the incident of Rabbi Eliezer that they didn't care if God himself held differently than them. Their job, as the saw it was to decide the law based on the majority opinion —whether that opinion was right or wrong just didn't matter.

 

Yet, according to the Torah the majority opinion can be wrong (Leviticus 4:13)[14]: which, according to the Talmud in Shavuot is referring to the Sanhedrin of 71 elders permitting accidentally one of the 36 types of sin that involve being cut off. So the majority is the way to decide the law, not the way to discover truth.) The Talmud is a record of the Oral Law as it was discussed and debated at that time. The Sages don't need to be infallible in order to be deep and important just like Newton's Theory of gravitation was deep and fruitful even though it wasn't correct --but a necessary stage of development.

 

·

 

We need to look at the New Testament and the Gemarah with historical retrospect and care, but also with respect. The 57 or so New Testament documents dug up in Egypt don't disagree on the basic facts of the life and teachings of Jesus. When we do this, a very clear picture of the Christian sect just being another sect besides the Scribes, Prushim (Pharisees) and Essences arises, who all had conflicting philosophies but were all equally committed to the Oral and Written Law.

 

·

 

Now, to find the spiritual root of the argument between Sages of the Talmud and the Christians, since the universes of the Jews and the Gentiles are connected by a black hole, the Sages saw Jesus fall into the black hole, but remain on the event horizon — while from the point of view of Jesus and the gentiles, that's when he entered their space and the time of their correction began. Before that, Jesus simply could have gone back in time as in the Feynman diagram.

 

You could conceivably have several manifestations of a tzadik (saint) at any one time, the one coming back (the 2nd coming is a constant process), and another that has already returned and going about preaching (as poor man and as the son of God coming on the wings of Heaven) (even conceivably as a good and bad one that meet at the bottom of the “v”and 8 each other and the soul of the tzadik-saint coming back through time losing entropy and the body going forward in time and their meeting and disappearing into pure energy, and then in that form transversing the realm of space-time until actually entering the black hole and disappearing from the Jewish scene, …so in essence I'm saying the dispute between the Christians and the Jews for the last 2000 years has been due to a lack of imagination). This is also how its possible for many people to have the level of Messiah the Son of Joseph through the soul of Jesus or the sparks of his soul.

 

 

 

(The reason the world of the Jew and gentile is connected solely by a black hole is that the circular sephirot were drawn out into the empty space, and then starting from the top again were drawn to the straight ones -- so basically, to get to them you would have to go through the singularity in the center -- (which from the aspect of the straight sephirot looks like the lowest one could sink to -- and it appears one stays there forever), and then come out the other end and enter into the circular sephirot, which is basically what Jesus did.

 

The idea of God appearing as a person is mentioned in the Gemarah of Sannhedrin where it says God went into a physical body at the time of Nebuchadnezzar to give him a haircut (which most rabbis don't mention when arguing against the Trinity).

 

So, theoretically there can be a world line of Moses, or any saint like so:

 

 

So at any one period of time the soul of a tzadik can be viewed as either good or bad (an anti-particle), depending on where you met his world line (as the Zohar says, “The spirit of Moses is stretched out throughout all generations”, this means that the time-line of Moses is stretched out through all sephirot, which, to the Ramchal is the time-line. So, I really haven't added anything new here.

 

A.      One progressing with the world getting older.

B.      One getting younger.

C.      One the oldest is aging to the world outside having returned from the future.

 

·

 

Since Jesus is united with the sepherah of Foundation which contains the light of Kindness, it is impossible to receive the light of Kindness without some direct or indirect connection with him. Even an unknown connection can draw that light (even if one just says he doesn't know) -- but a total denial of him seems to lead to wickedness.

 

·

 

Jesus himself says that the Messiah can't be the son of David. This seems to imply in itself that he was the Messiah from Joseph who must precede Messiah son of David.  God promised David that the Messiah would come from his male seed. And in general, the succession to the Crown is through the male seed as it says in Deut. 17:20, “so that he will have length of days in his rulership, he and his sons in the midst of Israel.” Jesus was descended from David only from his mother's side.

 

·

 

Jesus quoted the Torah when tempted by the evil one, “The Lord Your God You shall fear and Him alone you shall serve.” It seems clear that Jesus believed one must serve God alone, not Jesus. The Torah also says, “There is nothing besides God.” Coming to this knowledge of the oneness and uniqueness of God -- loving him and fearing him and keeping His commandments -- is what the Torah defines as serving God.

 

·

 

Because of the uncertainty principle, there will always be questions on Jesus or any saint that can't be answered. Like the fall of Rome, the crusades, the treatment of Galilio. If you believe in the Torah and the Talmud, there will be questions you can't answer either.

 

·

 

The Gemarah in Avodah Zara (pg. 9) says that you shouldn't buy land outside of Israel after 470 AD, for the Redemption will have come already. It also says the Messiah will come when the Roman Empire has spread over the whole world — which means that the whole world known then (as they said about Achashveirosh, that he ruled over the entire world, which was only actually the Persian Empire).

 

At any rate, the Roman Empire doesn't exist, so neither of these Gemarah's make sense unless they are referring to Jesus. (Besides this, Rabbi Abulafia said that the Gemarah in Sukkah regarding the Messiah son of Joseph that it  is referring to Jesus.)

 

·

 

Jesus being a tzadik makes it allowed to ask him for a blessing just as with any Torah sage, as the Talmud says, “One who has someone ill at home should go to the Torah sage in his town to pray for him.” In another place in the Talmud, it says when a certain rabbi needed to be saved from his enemies, he went to the graves of his parents to ask them for help [not for their prayers but for their help].

 

The Sages say that the reason the grave of Moses was not revealed is that if the Jewish people would know where it is and go there and ask him to pray for them that the final redemption would come right away.

 

·

 

Daniel 8:22 has to be referring to Alexander the Great (of Macedon) since in the previous verse Daniel says the previous Empire was Media and Persia. This verse says the empire of Alexander would be broken into four parts. I would like to suggest that they are:

1.      Egypt under Ptolemy Soter.

2.      The Indian territories and part of Afghanistan which were given to an Indian ruler in return for military help.

3.      The Seleucid Empire.

4.      Macedon.

 

This would imply that the next few verses would be referring to Jesus who was in fact at the latter time of the Greek Kingdom, after the Greeks were protected and freed by Roman decree [so at least they could be described as a kingdom if not an empire].

 

The verses later in Daniel 11 say openly that a messiah would arise during the empire that comes after the fall of the Greek empire and that could only be the Roman empire. The Talmud also says that the Messiah would come only when the Roman empire would spread over the whole world. Since the Talmud also says about Achashvairosh that his empire spread over the entire world would mean the whole known world at that time, this would imply that the messiah came when the Roman Empire was at its peak, not necessarily over the whole world, but the whole ‘known world’ at that time, which was during the rule of  Tiberius, when the Roman Empire reached its peak.

 

The Roman Catholic Church isn't the equivalent of the Roman Empire, since it existed at the time the Talmud was written, and if the Talmud had meant the church it wouldn't have written ‘the government’ [‘Malchus Romi’, which translated means the government of Rome].

 

The whole story there in Daniel 11 seems to be clearly talking about Julius Caesar and Cleopatra, as has been noted before by the Jewish commentaries. And then, “AT THAT TIME”, the redemption comes. So it seems we have to conclude that the particular messiah it is referring to is Jesus, as Rabbi Abulafia already concluded in his kabbalistic way. [Daniel 9 also says that the messiah would come during the second temple period.]

 

·

 

Faith in any saint has to be with understanding the true position and spiritual level of that saint. Otherwise, it is possible to fall from that faith. Therefore it is important to understand the place that Jesus takes amongst the other saints, and not to make it to seem that he was the only one that ever existed. This doesn't contradict the idea of the Trinity. It merely puts it into perspective.

 

·<???>

 

Joseph was the basis for the sepherah of Foundation in Emanation. Jesus is the new basis. The change of basis matrix is:

 

(Ye)  = a11Y + a12O + a13 Se + a14 Ph

(SH) = a21Y + a22O + a23 Se + a24 Ph

(U)   = a31Y + a32O + a33 Se + a34 Ph

(A)   = a41Y + a42O + a43 Se + a44 Ph

 

[I used here the four letters of Joseph's name, and the four letters of Jesus name in Hebrew as vectors. I assumed Joseph is the first foundation (basis) and Jesus is the new foundation. (Here I am assuming that Jesus is Foundation of Emanation, not just of the circular sephirot, and represents a change of basis and not just a new mapping into the circular sephirot. I don't know how to represent that type of mapping. It seems likely that there is a connection between this and the 4 times 4 matrix of the four Divine names: 72, 63, 45, 52. The only connection I have ever been able to find is in the first blessing of the Shemone Esre where Foundation is brought up to Glory which is the sepherah that is associated with the Divine name of four letters.)

 

·

 

One of the arguments used against the trinity is that God can't come down to earth in a bodily form, yet we find in the Gemarah Sa­nhedrin (95b) that he did just that as it says there, “Rabbi Abahu said that ‘if the verse didn't write it, it would be impossible to say’. The verse states: ‘On that day God will shave with the razor on the other side of the river the king of Assyria, the head and the hair of the feet and also the beard he will take away. The Holy One, Blessed is He, came and appeared to him [Sancheriv] as an old man. He said to him, “when you go to the kings of the east and the west, what will you say?” He answered, “I am also worried about this, what should we do?” He said, “Go and disguise yourself.” He asked, “how should I do that?” He said, “go bring me a scissors and I'll give you a haircut”. “From where should I get it?” “Go into that house over there.” He went and found some ministering angles who appeared to him as men and they were grinding date seeds. He said “give me a scissor”. They said “first grind one seed and well give you a pair”. By the time he got back it was already dark. He said “bring a lamp” he went and got one. As he was coming a spark touched his beard and his beard caught fire. He came and he gave him a hair cut. Rav Papa said that explains the common saying “if you singe an Assyrian and he liked it burn his beard also.”

 

I can imagine many will think that this Gemara doesn't mean this literally, however, that is not so since Rabbi Abahu said, “If the verse didn't say this it would be impossible to say.” Now, if the whole story is just a parable, then it would be possible to say. Rather, Rabbi Abahu is saying that this verse is saying something so contrary to reason that if it didn't say it, it would be impossible to say, i.e., that God himself came down to Earth in a physical body to give Sancheriv a haircut.

 

The Zohar has nothing to compare with this except that it says (vol 3, pg. 240): even though it is not the way of God to eat and drink, for the love of the Jewish people, God eats and drinks.

 

Incidentally, I think the Gemara in Sanhedrin it refers to is the sepherah called “Tiferet” [Beauty], since the Zohar usually refers to that particular sepherah by the same language that the Gemara used, i.e., “the Holy One, Blessed Be He”.

 

[Perhaps there is a hint for this idea in Genesis. For it says,  “a man fought with Jacob”, and later the man said “you have fought with God and with men”, and when asked his name he refused to identify himself and later Jacob called the place “The Face of God, for he said ‘I have seen God face to face and my soul was saved’”. [This is the literal translation.] Later, the Prophet Hoshea said about this that God appeared to him and served him. [Hoshea 12:3-6]

 

Now, the sages have a different idea of what happened there, and said it referred to the angel of Esau — which really isn't a problem, for the simple explanation is that God contains all aspects good and evil for there is nothing besides him. Now, if that was God in human form, who we usually refer to as Jesus, it is in fact interesting that Jesus became the intercessor of Esau [Rome]. It is assumed in general that God refers in general to the aspect of God that is above all time and space, but also to each individual level that is one step  higher that the previous, which contains the light of God relative to that previous level.

 

As the Sages said about the Tana who explained every Hebrew word ET in the Torah as a ribui — including something else — when he got to the verse that says, “‘Et’ the Lord your God you shall fear”, he stopped. For what could that ET possibly include?

 

Until Rabbi Akiva came and explained, “‘Et the Lord your God you shall fear’, to include disciples of the wise.”]

 

[This idea that God is each immediate higher level is actually hinted at in the Torah, where Abraham said to Avimelech, “the gods tricked me into leaving my father’s home” i.e., the set of all the spiritual levels up to God].

 

I know that the two major themes of the Old Testament are that there is only One God and to Him alone it is proper to pray and serve. And the other being that the Jewish people are the chosen people forever and that this will never change. However, the idea that we need an intermediary is also there, from the blessings of the Patriarchs to the requests of the people to the prophets.

 

Thus, I would like to suggest that the level to which no intermediary is necessary  is the level immediately above one called Elohim which is the set of all those levels. But to God as he is really is above time space and conception [that is represented by the ineffable Name], apparently we do need some help approaching. I don't mean that we can't approach Him directly because obviously we can, but rather that it helps to have a little help.

 

Why else do we do the mitzvot? Because God said to. Well, God also said about the angel he was sending before the Jewish people, “Don't disobey him for my Name is in him.” So here, God himself has indicated the significance of an intermediary. (“Other gods” are other levels not attached to the “rope of holiness”, i.e., that are not manifestations of God.)

 

[In every generation, there were and will always be one part of the Torah that will be politically incorrect. The Rambam made a somewhat reactionist theology against Christianity but the simple way the sages look at the Torah is thus, as I have written. E.g., when they explained that God called Jacob ‘God’ as Rashi brings down in Genesis that would seem to go against the Rambam that you can't call a person God [the Raavad in fact disagreed with the Rambam and held that believing that God was or can be manifested in a body is not against the Torah].

 

The Rambam obviously was embarrassed by many laws of the Torah that seem to go against reason, and he had to create a rationalization for them. Nowadays, other parts of the Bible bother us, e.g., when God promises to give the land of Israel to the children of Abraham and then Ishmael is born and God promises to Abraham that Ishmael will fear God.

 

Now, slavery of the Bible is embarrassing to the Jews, and the fact that the Bible says you have to go to the rabbis to understand the Torah correctly is embarrassing to the Christians. Now, legally speaking, the slavery of the Torah is actually seldom, or indentured servants — because there are strict laws of how to treat a slave, and in fact the Russians were doing a lot better as serfs under the Tzar than when they were emancipated and toppled the Tzar and created a communist state.

 

Now what was God doing wrestling with Jacob? If we say that was the aspect of God that contains evil then this is understood. Or just the opposite. Perhaps it was the good aspect of God fighting with the evil aspect of Jacob. For Jacob contained all the future Jewish souls many of which are not good.

 

It could also refer to chaos and correction, i.e., God represents the higher world of chaos [63] and Jacob, correction [45] as it usually is thus in Kabbalah anyway and the wrestling is the vessels of correction trying to contain the light of chaos until the dawn, i.e., the rising of the light of the name 72.

 

I think the real explanation is that  first Yaacob had to fight God [good] and then evil Esau which is what every person has to go through in order to come to that level of God — beyond space-time and conception.

 

For a person to come what he must come to he first has to fight evil, then he has to fight God, and then becomes a man. [There is a certain point a person needs to come to, a critical mass, so to speak, for him to start to wake up.]

 

This is represented by the fact that God put the fiery angels before the path to Gan Eden. For one must go through Hell and Heaven to come to the Tree of Life. The angels try to stop one and then if they don't succeed they use their sword.

 

God here also represents Being [the right sepherah Kindness], and Esau non-being [the left sepherah, lack of light]. Jacob had to fight both to come to “Becoming” [the middle sepherah, Yod He Vav He.] This is the significance of the wrestling, i.e., the joining of Jacob's level [right] with Esau's level [left] to come to the middle [Torah].

 

The reason Infinite God is sometimes manifested in finite space and time, as with Jesus, or in the Temple, or in other ways, is to give the finite intelligence of man some grasp of Him and thus to become attached to Him which is the purpose of man’s creation. Since there are five levels of man's soul, each manifestation of God is to give man a grasp of a higher infinity [as the difference between all the numbers between 0 and 1 and all the numbers between 0 and 2]. As the:

1.      Temple [inanimate]

2.      The Waters: “The spirit of God hovered on the face of the Waters”.

3.      The Chayot: “I the Chayot that I had see on the river Cevarand, on it was the Presence of God. (Chayot can mean animal in Hebrew). It refers to a type of angel that is the higher spirit of the animal kingdom.

4.      Jesus. “Also, the Presence spoke through the mouth of Moses”.

5.      God also spoke frequently in the Bible through an angel to reveal His Infinity to the highest level of man, the Yechida.

 

·

 

One of the arguments I have heard against Jesus is that the three requirements of the Messiah were not fulfilled by him, i.e., the three requirements the Rambam gives: of building the Temple, returning all Israel to the 613 commandments, and gathering the dispersed of Israel.

 

However we find that these things are the subject of a debate in the Gemara, Sanhedrin 98a. Rabbi Yochanan in fact says like the Rambam that all the promises of the prophets are for the days of the messiah while the higher spiritual world we can't comprehend. Shmuel says that all the promises are in fact for the higher spiritual world while the only difference between his time [under Babylonian rule] and the time of the messiah will be the subjection of the nations on Israel.

 

That is in fact probably what would have happened if they had accepted the teachings of Jesus [since it was the hot headed nationalists then who provoked the wrath of the Romans and the subsequent exile. But any savior can't do his job unless he is believed in. Even Moses could do nothing with the many people that didn't believe in him, as the sages said that only 1/5th or 1/50th of Israel came out of Egypt since the rest God caused to die during the seven days of darkness, since they didn't believe in Moses.

 

[So in a way, Moses brought a worse Holocaust on the Jewish people than the Nazis since the Nazis never got up to killing 88% or 98% of the Jewish people. So we see being a savior isn't enough. The people have to accept the savior. And if they don't, woe to them]. And if no one had believed, Moses in fact could not have saved anyone — as he told God his reason for not wanting to go, “They won't believe in me.” And, in fact, his promise to bring that generation into Israel would have been a false prophecy if not for the two people of the generation that did believe in him all the way: Calev Ben Yefune and Hoshea Ben Nun.

 

But at any rate God's purpose will not be thwarted totally, and we find with the introduction of the Magna Carta in the beginning of the 6th millennium when God did promise the redemption, that the yoke of the nations has slowly been lifted off Israel, who are now able to live in relative freedom compared to the chaos and suffering under the Romans and the Dark Ages.

 

In fact, I think that it is possible that Shmuel was referring to messiah of Joseph and Rabbi Yochanan to the messiah from David. And, in fact this is hinted at by the Rambam who brings the statement of Shmuel also, so apparently, he felt that it is possible to reconcile those statements. This, however is not like the gemara which says openly that Rabbi Yochanan and Shmuel disagree.

 

·

 

One of the other objections I have heard against Jesus is that his teachings disagree with that of the Sages: however I have found that not to be correct, e.g., Jesus held that a saint has the power to forgive sin as it says in masechta Rosh Hashanah 17b, God forgives the sin of many for the sake of the one and also we find, Moses prayed to God, “forgive their sin and if not, wipe me out of your book”.

 

·

 

Another objection I have heard is that Jesus put good character traits above doing the commandments. This would in fact be a legitimate complaint if not that all the later Sages of Israel agreed with it. The Chafetz Chayim wrote in Shmirat HaLashon that good character comes first as it says in the verse, “To walk in his ways and to keep his commandments,” and he brings another statement from the sages, that the first thing a verse mentions is first in importance before the later thing — and, this verse specifically is referring to kindness and compassion. The Kabbalist Rashash says, along these lines in Nahar Shalom, that character is the basic soul of a person, while the commandments are only the garments of the soul. The Gra says things along these lines throughout his books.

 

·

 

We find in Sanhedrin 104b, that the Anshei Keneset HaGedolah wanted to count King Solomon among those who have no portion in the next world. Different echoes came to indicate to them that they were wrong until eventually they changed their minds. My question is if this body of Sages which included the three last prophets could make a mistake about King Solomon, couldn't the later Sages of subsequent generations make similar mistakes. Now, the Anshei Keneset HaGedolah were so great that God kept trying to convince them of their mistake until they finally gave in, but who says that God would do that with later sages?

 

·

 

One of the objections I have heard against Jesus is that the Sanhedrin of the time killed him. But, the Talmud says that Herod killed all the Rabbis of the Pharisees who had Semichah, and there was left only one Rabbi, Baba Ben Buta — that was when Jesus was only a year old or so. So, when Jesus was about thirty, how could the Sanhedrin have very many true rabbis on it. Where could they have come from, except the Sadducees. Anyway, we find opinions among the Christian scholars that Scribes in the New Testament was changed from the original word ‘Sadducees’. [In the Greek, they are very close. At the time the disciples of Paul were editing the documents to be included in the New Testament the Sadducees were on good terms with them and the scribes and pharisees had become enemies.

 

·

 

[On the subject of the stirring dirt and water on Shabbat that Jesus did, cf. Beitza, Chapter 4, in the Rosh [Rabbainu  Asher]. Jesus held like Rashi in that Rosh.

 

·

 

On the subject of washing the hands, Jesus held like the Gemara in Chulin and the Zohar that the first washing before eating is a mitzvah not an obligation, or he depended on the washing from the morning. He also held like the Yerushalmi in Zeraim and the Gemara in Suchah that the Sages don't have the authority to uproot anything from the Torah even for a positive command. The Gemara in Succah holds that we don't put off a mitzvah of the Torah for a rabbinical decree as it says, “we don't take the lulav on the first day of yom tov that falls on Shabbat, because we don't know the exact first calculation for Rosh Chodesh [the new moon]. Thus if we did, we would take it in despite of the rabbinical decree of Rabbah, of ‘perhaps he will carry it four amot in a public domain’”. The Rif states the Gemara in Succah for the halacha, so he holds the same way. See the Ritvah in chapter 4 of Rosh Hashanah.

 

·

 

The Greek word for picking corn also implies rubbing it between one’s fingers, which is permitted on the Shabbat. It just seems like Jesus and his disciples encountered on the Shabbat ultra-religious Jews who were ignorant of the halachah as happens all the time with people that are super religious — they always keep on adding restriction upon restriction. I have seen many times people doing perfectly permitted things on the Sabbath and getting  attacked by the ultra-orthodox, who simply didn't know the halachah — and even when the Shulchan Aruch [Code of Jewish Law] was brought out to show them, they wouldn't believe it.

  

It is also interesting to note that Jesus said the same idea as the Rambam in The Guide. Jesus said the Shabbat was given for man. The Rambam wrote that the object of the entire Torah, in general, is the well-being of the body and the soul — and specifically, the Shabbat was given to witness the fact that God created the world, and to give man rest and comfort.

 

[Moreh NevuchimIII:27, 43]

 

Couldn't it have been “hora’at sha’ah” [a need of the hour], as the Rambam explains about Eliyahu the prophet on Mount Carmel? For, to the Rambam Eliyahu didn't sacrifice there because he received a prophecy allowing it, rather because of the general principle of “hora’at sha’ah”.

 

In the War Rule 5:1-5 of the Dead Sea Scrolls, according to the translation of Robert Eisenman and Schiffman it says, “as it is written in the Book of Isaiah the prophet”, “The thickets of the forest shall be hacked away with iron and the Lebanon trees in their majesty shall fall. But a shoot shall grow out of the stump of Jesse, [a twig shall sprout from his stoke [Isaiah 10:34 and 11:1] a shoot of David, and they will be judged, the... and the prince of the congregation will kill him, the army of… with drums and dances. And the high priest commanded… the corpses of the Kittim”.

 

Here is mentioned the fact that there were a few verses of Isaiah that we don't have in the present day Isaiah. These verses clearly speak about a messiah that will be killed by the ruler of the people and sanctioned by the high priest and armies of the Kittim, i.e. the Romans, according to the Targum Unkelos. This explains references that Jesus and Paul made to verses predicting his death that we don't have in our present day Bible.

 

·

 

A further objection I have heard is against the virgin birth. Christians usually bring a proof to the virgin birth from Isaiah 7:14. Jewish people arguing against them point out that the word “almah” doesn't mean a virgin but a young girl. However, the   Jewish commentary, the Even Ezra  explains, “It is probable that it means virgin or a girl who has had sex,” i.e., either one is equally likely. [Besides that, one could always answer from the verse in Genesis that the Sons of God came in unto the daughters of man and they gave birth.]

 

·

 

One important proof of Jesus is very simple. If physics would teach people to be good and those that learned it would be not good then we would have a question about its validity. But now that it teaches about physical reactions and those reactions occur as it predicts, then we have no question. Now, since the Talmud teaches people to be good and the people that learn it are not good, we have a question about its validity. To throw it out is not possible since the Bible itself says that the rabbis alone have the authority to interpret it. Thus, we have to figure out what is wrong with the Talmud.

 

Many solutions have been offered. As we see in Israel, none work. Based on every solution that is offered there is a yeshiva/s built on that principle. None of the results of those solutions come out particularly better or worse than anyone else. Jesus is left as the only viable option who has had success for 2000 years of inspiring countless hospitals, orphanages etc, and taming violent civilizations and people.

 

·

 

To a degree,  it is possible to accept the idea of the Trinity [since it is the job of every person to be one with God and we assume a true saint has succeeded in that job].

 

Thus, Christ was the infinite God coming into finite limits in order that finite man could have some concept of God. This is the reason for the manifestation of God in all the places in the bible [like the Temple, or at Mount Sinai, or by an angel], where he limits himself in time and space.

 

This is to give the human mind the ability to expand. The human nefesh [life force] can receive the light of God on the level of faith [alpha 0, the first type of infinity]. The spirit can receive the light of beauty [alpha 1, the second infinity]. Jesus was to allow the second infinity to permeate the consciousness of Man. Rabbi Nachman is for the soul to receive the light of the next type of infinity, Understanding.

 

 

Chapter 2 - Christianity

 

·

 

Western civilization grew on the ruins of the Roman Empire, since, according to Rabbi Abulafia, the vertical part of the cross signifies Hebrew and the horizontal part Latin and Greek. Therefore Christendom which had to contain all these three elements in order to become Western civilization, is significantly different than the rest of the world which remains in the Dark Ages until they become westernized.

 

·

 

Christianity just got too moral, and secularism just has got too immoral after Kant. Nowadays, we base laws on science which are unproven and unfounded and only barely out of the crib. Christianity has to first throw out all the laws of the Bible, as Paul said to do. Then they have to make up their own morality. Secularism first throws out the Bible, then logic and reason as per Kant. Then they have to find their own things to fight like tobacco. (I would guess that alcohol kills a lot more people on the road than tobacco but America found out then the wise statement of Einstein, “You can't make illegal what people are going to do anyway.”) I don't know the reason God forbade certain things in the Bible and permitted others, but I suspect He knew what He was doing.

 

·

 

The path to knowledge for the Jew and Christian has apparently taken the long and hard paths. Getting out of religious thought and going to Aristotle and humanism seems to have done much more for knowledge in general. Yet Jesus and Baba Sali are also realities I must resort to the idea of drawing the light of the circular sephirot (humanism) into the vessels of correction (Jewish people) Jewish soul).

 

·

 

In the opinion of the Meiri and the Rashba Christians aren't idol worshippers but in the category of gerai toshav [proseleties of the gates] . In the opinion of Rabbi Joseph Karo they are Gerai Hashaar (proselytes of the gate) which is on even a higher level than gerai toshav (proselytes of dwelling who have legal status and rights in Judaism though they aren't Jewish, since they keep the seven Noaide laws) Rabbi Yaakov Emden writes “Christianity has been given to the Gentile world by the Apostles as part of the Jewish religion and its founder has made the moral laws stricter than those contained in the law of Moses.”

 

·

 

Rabbi Nachman said when one starts to come into the realm of holiness, judgements are awoken against him. Thus, you could explain the problems Rome had after accepting Jesus, from that aspect.

 

This would also explain the problems the world had at each stage a new knowledge came into the world, “He who increases knowledge, increases pain.” [Proverbs]

 

·      1666 was the year of the discovery of the Law of Gravity of Issac Newton and simultaneously the year of plague in London.

·      Special and General Relativity;

·      World War I/II and Quantum Theory

·      The Renaissance and the plague.

·      The Kabbalah and the expulsion from Spain.

·      Chasidut and the Napoleonic wars.

 

This is because each new development is the result of two opposites reacting together so the new synthesis comes out a new and improved product. But, the residue of this process is Judgements.

 

It seems possible to predict from this —now that the world is coming to a new age of consciousness that some Judgements also will be awoken.

 

In  a different section I have written what I think may help, specifically the five parshiot Rabbi Nachman said that help for this.

 

·

 

Jesus emphasizes private prayer, loving all people — religious or not — emphasizing kindness and righteous action. He sounds more like Socrates than the Pope. And while I'm at it why not mention that these were the things the kabbalists emphasized too. (And all the great sages of Israel, e.g. Rebbi Sar Shalom the Kabbalist, the Chafetz Chayim, the Baal Shem Tov, the Gra, Rabbi Nachman, etc. Doesn't that mean that all these people understood something that they just couldn't convey to their disciples.)

 

·

 

The basic reason that Christianity isn't idolatry is that, at first there were no kings, just gods at the head of each people. As many different peoples there were, that's how many gods there were.

 

The Christians, accepting and worshiping the God of Israel, are by definition not idol worshipers, whether they believe Jesus was God in human form or not. This, of course, the Meiri and the Rashba and other Medieval authorities noticed before me, and gave Christians the category of Gerey Toshav [proselytes of the gates], not idolaters.

 

·

 

In the old Kabbalah we find prayers addressed to the sephirot [traits] of God. We find an Amora going to the grave of his father saying, “Save me! Save me!” — from his enemies. We ask the angels for blessings on Friday night.

 

At what point does praying to a trait of God not constitute idolatry and  to a stone yes? Aren't they both creations of God?

    

The Rambam explains that the prohibition on idolatry refers to the way idolatry originally started — that is, the generation of Enosh saw the stars in Heaven, and reasoned that since God has attributed honor to these creations it is right that we do so also, and so they started worshiping them.

 

Since the main prohibition of idolatry is dependent on the intention, if one prays to something thinking of it as a creation separate from God it is idolatry. But if he prays to it knowing that it is only a manifestation of God it is not.

 

[Though this above idea may seem strange to many people however we find Rava in the Gemara [and the Rambam hold as law] that even if one bows down to a statue for love or fear of the statue, he hasn't transgressed the prohibition of idolatry until he accepts it as a god, i.e. he believes it to have a separate existence besides God.

 

If a person would believe that God has put his name on a stone, [i.e., he believes the stone is a manifestation of God and has no separate power or existence besides God], even though this is a mistake, and that person bows down to the stone, it isn't idol worship legally since in his mind, he is worshiping God.

 

[In the language of the Gemara, “He didn't accept the stone for godliness”.] It isn't even “Shogag” [accidental] since the prohibition depends on the thought. That is why going to the graves of the saints or bowing down in front of a Torah scroll isn't idol worship, since the people that do so believe that God has placed His name on that thing.

 

This explains why many of the first authorities held that the Christians aren't idol worshipers. This also explains why the desire for money is actual idolatry [to all the Sages of Chasidut]. This is idolatry, since even the people that do this don't believe that God has placed his Name on the money. So, we can see from this that even the Catholic Church isn't doing actual idolatry with the statues, even though they are still forbidden from the verses that specifically say not to make molten images.

   

However, the Rambam holds differently than this, and he believes that thinking that one needs any kind of middle-man between one and the Creator is idolatry.

 

This has to be understood in context — for to the Rambam there is a higher plane than Good and evil, that is Truth and falsehood, and the great evil of idolatry is that it is falsehood.

 

What makes it worse than other mistakes is that it depends on what one makes a mistake about. Making a mistake about mundane things isn't so bad as making a mistake about God. However, most authorities, even in the Talmud don't hold this way, and until this day it is the custom of Jews everywhere to go to their holy men for a blessing.

 

And even the Rambam can't get away from the middleman for he says, [The Guide III:52], that the Intellect is the middleman between one and God. [You can't complain about the Rambam speaking about every mitzvah being a middleman. For he would say every mitzva isn't to attach you to God but to give you the right opinions].

 

·

                                                 

The prohibition of idolatry is to serve any of the creations of God, not a prohibition to pray or ask a favor from any creation, while knowing that it is in God's hands, for we ask saints for a blessing, and we go to a bakery to ask for bread, and on the night of the Shabbat we ask the angels to bless us.

                                                             

·

 

I heard from Issac Ram that the catholic church has the spirit of Jesus even though they are idolatry. The more liberal denominations of the church are like the meeting place between Western thought and Jesus, but the spirit of Jesus is really there only in trace amounts.


 

Chapter 3 - Paul

 

·

 

The disciples of Jesus who knew Jesus whom Jesus chose (as he said “I have chosen you”) suspected that Paul was telling people not to keep the commandments, and sent for him. And he came to Jerusalem and defended himself saying; that he was only telling non-Jews that they didn't have to become Jewish to be saved, but he never told Jews not to keep the commandments. And even did commandments in Jerusalem in front of people to prove that he was observant. Then again later the disciples became suspicious and sent Peter to see what was going on. As it turned out, their suspicion was correct as we see in Paul's letters.

 

[The letters  were written over several years and perhaps represent Paul's later ideas, but they still give us the basic gist of Paul's ideas - which the true disciples of Jesus had made clear was totally against the true doctrines of Jesus - and they threatened to excommunicate him if he would teach such false teachings, which as it turned out he actually did teach. However it may be that Paul held like Rashi in Macot 24 (“The righteous shall live by his faith”), so I think Paul is legitimate.

 

However, his hatred of the Law seems to have simply replaced the laws of God of the old Testament with new meaningless rituals of the Catholic church. I just don't see a point to attacking the laws of the Torah to the extent that he does. I guess he wanted to emphasize the importance of loving the tzadik, and that that is the only hope of salvation but  that doesn't seem to me to justify attacking God's laws. 

 

·

 

In his letter to the Galatians [Gal. 2:6, in 57AD] he wrote about the disciples of Jesus who were the leaders of the church in Jerusalem, “those people who are acknowledged as leaders - not that their importance matters to me.” In 2 Corinthians 11:3-4 he acknowledges that the disciples of Jesus were teaching about “another Jesus” different from the one he was teaching about. But I admit the disciples in Jerusalem also don't come out looking so well: Annanis and his wife after giving all their possessions to the community don't seem to me to be guilty of the death penalty for keeping a few things for themselves.[15]

 

 

 

Chapter 3 – Jews and Christians

 

·

 

 “I testify that whether a man or woman, slave or maid servant, Jew or idol-worshiper, the Divine Presence rests on a person only according to his deeds” -Tana Deve Eliyahu, from Eliyahu the prophet. “For it is known that the souls of Israel are from the earth… but as for the non-Jewish nations whose souls are from Heaven, they need not perform deeds (613 mitzvot.)” -- The Gaon from Vilna (The Gra.) Commentary on Shir HaShirim, Chap. 1, Verse 6.

 

According to Rabbi Shneur Zalman (The Baal HaTanya) (in Parshas VaYishlach) the root of Esav is from worlds higher than Yaakov (Tohu) and that is why Isaac wanted to bless him, but the mistake of Isaac was in not realizing that Esau had fallen from that root.

 

I think to answer the contradiction between the Gra and the Baal HaTanya that the world the Kings of Edom in the straight sephirot must somehow have a connection with the circular ones.

 

At any rate I didn't know from where the Gra and the Baal Hatanya got this from until I saw in Shaar Ruach HaKodesh: Yichud 10 on the verse, “These are the three Children of Noah” which basically gives as the root of the children of Noah the Three Divine Names of 161, 143, and 151. But the support for the Baal HaTanya’s point of view is the fact that in the same letters are hinted the name Elohim with the yud filling the letters. Even though that is wholly important to note that it is the later permutations of that name which give rise to the Klipot, it seems to me that the root of non-Jews is the three names, “I Will Be” in the eye of Adam Kamdon, not actually the full names of 161 ,143, and 151 respectively, for in the full names there are no circular sephirot, [unless we are referring to the circular sephirot before Adam Kadmon]. But in Adam Kadmon, the circular sephirot are only in the three names Ehyeh in the dots of the 63, or the forehead, which is anyway the root of Israel and not relevant to this discussion.

 

According to this idea, the explanation of the fact the three names Ehyeh take the 22 letters and make vessels from them would refer to the letters of the other languages and this fits with the idea of the Baal Hatanya’s that the letters of other languages also have holiness.

 

Now a hint to the Gra is the fact that the Torah blesses the children of Abraham and Issac to be like the stars of the heavens but the children of Yaakov like the dust of the Earth. Now even though the blessing for Abraham of being like the stars certainly goes for the Jewish people as we see in exodus 32:13, still that blessing clearly goes on all the other children of Abraham and Issac, [i.e., the Christian and Muslim people].

 

·

 

Rabbi Issac Luria said the Jewish people have their root in the drops of semen that Adam spilled during those 130 years after the sin and were born again as people and sinned because of the rust still attached to them and had to go through the purification process of the flood, the dispersion, and the Egyptian exile. This may sound pretty bad; however, the root of Israel in the Higher worlds is from Wisdom, but since they were supposed to be the children of Adam they came out with his seed. Rabbi Nachman says the descendants of Moses have even a higher root than that. At any rate, the root of the Jewish people is from the worlds of correction but have had to go through a difficult purification process.

 

·

 

Rabbenu HaKadosh said to Antonious that the promise to destroy Esau only refers to those that hold onto the deeds of Esau. The Gemara also says that any who do not believe in idolatry is called Jewish. In the Rambam’s enumeration of the 13 principles, we find that he says that anyone who believes in these principles comes into the category of “Israel” even if they do as many evil deeds as they possibly can - and anyone who does not believe in them is not Jewish. Thus, I find in the Gemara and the Rambam the idea that whether one is considered Jewish is not necessarily dependent on conversion or if one's mother was Jewish, but rather it depends on one's principles and deeds. It is possible to ignore the Gemara since it can be explained as just a drasha (not halacha) but the Rambam who draws on these Gemaras clearly means his statement to be taken as halacha...

 

What if we take the drashot of the gedolai hachasidut that clearly held that the desire for money is in the halachic category of idolatry to its natural conclusion? Does this exclude Jewish people with the desire for money from the category of Israel? Is now Mother Theresa and Princess Diana Jewish because they engaged in deeds of loving kindness - [The other mitzvot, they were not obligated in since Rashi says we should not do all the 613 any more since it would lead to no one meriting to the next world.] Clearly, other first authorities besides the Rambam would not hold like this since they held that the Jewish and nonJewish soul are different.Now there is a debate as to where the Rambam lived in a spiritual sence.Some hold in Jerusalem and others hold in Athens.I think his feet where in Jerusalem but his head was in Athens,ie. he obviously had a vision as to what determined a persons Jewishness was how attached to God he is.But to get from the halacha to there ,i don't think he knew, but rather he felt intuitively was correct. And this may apply in general for he certainly wanted to bridge between reason and the Law, but I don't think he really knew exactly how.

 

I think the Kabbalah provides the answer to all these questions. For clearly the mitzvot contain only the holiness of the vessels, not of the inner light which depends on many factors, e.g., if God wants to put his light into it for that person at that time. In a similar manner Jewish people have only the holiness of the body, not of the spirit unless any particular persons happens to merit to it. Now the Rambam holds that the holiness of the spirit comes from faith in the 13 principles and so in his opinion anyone Jewish or otherwise believing in these principles is spiritually Jewish.

 

·

 

Jesus had the vessel of tikun and the light of love from tohu, so non-Jews feel more affinity towards him than Jews since he contains the light of their higher root.

 

The root of the Jewish people is in the sepherah of Royalty which is the daughter of Wisdom so they are usually more into good ideas (or bad ones when they fall from their root). The root of Jesus is in the sepherah of Foundation which is filled with the light of kindness so Christians are more into good deeds (or bad ones when they fall from their root.) The amount of hospitals and general help of the Catholic church for mankind for the last 2000 years is nothing less than awesome. Similarly the amount of study and books of the Jewish people for their history is also awesome.

 

·

 

Tana DeBay Eliyahu, “whether a man or a woman, a slave or a maidservant, a Jew or an idol -worshipper, the Holy Spirit rests on a person according to their deeds.”

 

At first non-Jews had a soul from the outside of the klipah even their good inclination is from the klipah. But when they began to believe the one God they drew a higher holiness on themselves from their higher root. This applies to non-Jewish nations as a whole also, for every nation is like a whole person with some people representing the head and some the hands and others the heart and others the soul.

 

·

 

The reason God brought Bach, Beethoven, and Mozart was to create music that would tie ones soul to the higher sephirah (divine trait). That is Bach - glory, Mozart - kindness, Beethoven - Judgment, Handel - Royalty.

 

Incidentally, Beethoven did intend his music to be specifically ethnic which for Germany and Austria is the trait of judgment and it is only softened by the belief in Jesus but after they threw out Jesus in the 1860s the basic ethnic philosophy of Germany took it's place, i.e., war and conquest.

 

·

 

The reason a non-Jew is not allowed to keep the Sabbath is that he is not effected by the Shabbos-field energy. Jews are affected only by the straight sephirot energy field, and non-Jews are affected only by the circular sephirot field. Each one of the 10 sephirot has its own energy field. There are certain sephirot that draw wisdom or children etc. And there are combinations of the fields of the sephirot that draw different combinations of blessings.

 

A field is usually created or drawn by what one occupies himself with. So if one for instance learns math he will usually draw upon himself the math field energy. Kindness draws a kindness field. Learning Gemarah brings its particular field energy. Evil has its energy also. A place or country has its energy. Every day has its own energy. The reason to be by Rabbi Nachman on Rosh Hashanah is there is a certain energy field around a tzadik and every special day has it's own energy field. So on Rosh Hashanah when the two combine and there is created a electromagnetic oscillation by the presence of the chasidim, and a spiritual electro-magnetic wave is created.

 

Many times one can't help what type of field is drawn upon him or how he will be affected by it. He can just try his best to do what is right. But general principles can fail in specific situations and therefore God has given us a certain intuition in the heart to be able to detect energy fields not seen by the eye or detected by the mind.

 

·

 

It seems to me that the world points defined by place and time are only approximations as in General Relativity and it's really only the properties of the field around one determine his spirituality and closeness with God. As Rebbi said to Antoninus, “Esau, but not all Esau”, i.e., what the Torah says in general is only an approximation unless it says “all”. Of course the idea of the mitzvot is to draw the field energy. Every family has its specific energy field around it.

 

·

 

There is a disagreement among the first authorities if the Jewish and gentile soul is the same thing. The other authorities say there is a difference in the souls and this opinion I have followed in this book since it is of Rabbi Luria also.

 

·

 

Thought in Judaism follows a parallel path to that of their neighbors (but they add a Jewish touch and talent to it), since non-Jews are from Tohu which is above Tikun which is the root of the Jewish people. For example after the Romans codified their laws in Justinian's reign, the Jews codified their's in the same period.

 

·

 

Since the western Catholic Church followed rationalistic tendencies, so did the Jews in western Europe and in Catholic lands like Poland and Lithuania. (The hard headed rationalism of Jews from those areas is quite famous.) Since the split of the Roman Empire Constantinople and the Eastern Church followed mystical tendencies and subsequently when the Muslims took over that area they incorporated the same ideas in the Sufi. And so we shouldn't be surprised to find Sephardic Jewry from Islamic lands and Russian Jewry (who lived in lands under the Eastern Church) having strong mystical tendencies. The Kabbalah originates in fact in Islamic Spain before it was conquered by the Christians.When Martin Luther broke away from the church and said one needs only faith not reason, this same idea became the prevalent pattern in Western Jewry also until nowadays. The clear opinion of the authorities and even the great saints of Chasidut that one needs to combine Faith and reason has been forgotten. Rabbi Nachman held Faith was the main thing, but he clearly held one needs reason also.

 

·

 

Jewish music from Islamic lands is totally Arabic in character. The yeshivot are the Jewish version of the monastery, and this is why they only existed in Catholic lands, not in Russia (except a brief attempt before World War I), or in Islamic lands. Jewish music of European Jewry is almost an exact duplicate of Ukrainian music.

 

·

 

The ethical system of the Duties of the Heart (which is the basis of the ethical system of Judaism) is almost identical to the system of Christian authors who were about 200 years before it. -(Those same authors provided the Islamic thinkers with their system also. However this isn't to say that Jews aren't creative or original, but their special power is that of integration -i.e. the welding together is disparate ideas to come out with a result where the whole is more and better than the parts.

 

·

 

It is obvious that we see a case of the dialectics of Hegel, i.e., the Jewish people representing one principle and each non-Jewish nation representing another principle and their interacting to create a new synthesis which then further interacts. But the Kabbalah would explain it differently - that the non-Jewish nations have fallen from their higher root in Tohu [ which comes from the Divine Name of Numerical value 63] and need  to rise there and the Jewish people  need to draw that light of Tohu into their vessels.


CONCLUSION

Now science, I have been saying throughout this book, is on the level of understanding higher than any religion. However there also the degree of goodness is dependent on the closeness to the origin, not how high one can climb. This can however be the subject of debate. Some people may want to put Judaism at the top others Christianity others science and still others kabbalah. I don't want to enter that debate for I think it is irrelevant as to determine one's degree of good or evil or horizontal closeness with God. But it does determine vertical closeness.]

 

[Now I have in this put all systems to the left of the y axis and said goodness refers to closeness to the axis. However it is possible that in fact the column of infinite light is in the exact center between good and evil, I tend to this that is the case and that is the reason secular People tend to be closer to God than religious. In the vertical order I think the vessels of evangelical Christianity are on foundation of Tohu (since they are from Tohu Chaos which is a higher level than the vessels of correction) But only if it stays pure for the higher something is if it falls, it falls lower than other things. The reason I think this is Jesus being a prelude to redemption contained a higher vessel than Judaism which remained one rung back. However in terms of the light, the light of correction-Torah is higher.]

But since the correction involves taking the broken vessels of tohu and fixing them and creating one large vessel it would make sense to do that with the different systems and then drawing into them the light of the name 45 the Torah. Rabbi Nachman holds that the name 52 is a measure of the entropy of the universe

 

“Science” has come to pervade human thought. In the 1800s it undermined the authority of the Bible, and certainly of the Talmud. It also affected faith in that it became a rival faith. The objective achievements of “science” along with the weakness of Christianity to check violence, impressed the common man, and led him to believe in the new faith of “science”. Respect for it grew in proportion to its achievements. “Science” has already pervaded every aspect of human life while religion has failed in its major objective of understanding the basic meaning of life.

 

“Science” became a religion. It became the messiah. It was thought to provide answers for metaphysical questions and all social problems. [While philosophy became the proponent of the  idea of the invalidity of all metaphysical questions]It was thought to provide the standards to regulate human behavior. It has shaped, molded and formed all modern attitudes more pervasively than any religion. The elite of society were people with no apparent religious belief. It was thought that there was no question that science couldn't solve. Any religious belief in its path was obliterated. [It is interesting to note the year Calculus was discovered 1666,and the year relativity was discovered on the Jewish calender was 5,666.And the Book of revelation considers 666 to be the number of the Beast[i.e., noga]and the Lekutai Moharan considers scientists to be the Head of the Snakei.e., Kilpat Noga]So clearly Science needs to be connected to fear of God or it falls into evil.]

 

Since the 1700's the number of scientists doubled every 15 years. Since the advent of the cold war and the threat of nuclear or chemical holocausts, the fervor for science has cooled off. Now it is pursued mainly for the purpose of making a living. However the effects of its dominance are still here. However, the religion of “science and progress” has been debunked. So people go back to different religions for the answers those religions just don't have. However I hope i have shown in this book a path by which it is possible to combine religion and science into a cohesive  organic whole being cable of progress that each one individually wasn't able to do.

 

The existence of the Metaphysical realm is now an indisputable fact, if from the evidence of people like Rabbi israel Abuchatzaira or Benny Hinn, the Christian evangelists or the miracle workers of India.

 

Now to dispute the existence and validity of miracles is to maintain a faith that contradicts documented facts that have been and continue to be validated every day.

 

I believe that the place where science and faith touch is the world of math, the lowest sepherah of the spiritual world and the top sepherah of the physical world. And to show how there really is no contradiction between faith and science. But each must remember its proper place, and in what it is qualified to judge, and in what it is not (Theoretically physics and the Torah predict their own limits).

 

Also I hope I have shown the meaning of the Zohar that says “God loves the Divine trait (sepherah) of Royalty (Mathematics) so much, that he put the workings of His whole house into her hands, so that all the higher and lower worlds operate under her principles.”

 

My final conclusion is that ONE NEEDS FAITH AND REASON, malchus and chachmah.

 

These two sephirot need to revolve around each other and thus produce the energy needed to make a better world.

Appendix 1

(1.) The Sephirah called Keter of Arich Anpin is the Neshamah of Atzilut, and is divided into 3 mochin, i.e. (Chaf, Bes, Daled), which are the Nefesh Ruach Neshamah of the Neshamah (i.e.  Keter, Chachmah, Binah).

 

(2.) Atik Venukvah are the ( = חכמה ובינה חו״ב  C  , Vov, Ves) of Keter, and Arich Venukvah are the (Zayin, Vov, Nun Sophit, זו״ן זעיר אנפין),  of Keter and together are called דעת.

 

(3.) Sephirat (Ches, Vov, Ves) are the Ruach of Atzilut and are divided into 3 Mochin (i.e. Ches, Bes, Daled), which are (Nun, Resh, Nun Sophit).

 

(4.) Abbah Veimah are (Ches, Vov, Ves) of the Ruach (which are the Neshamah and Ruach of Ruach) and Yisrael Sabah Utvunah are the Daat which is the (Zayin, Vov, Nun Sophit) which is the Nefesh of Ruach)

 

(5.) The Sephirah of Daat is the Nefesh of Atzilut and is divided into 3 Mochin (-Ches, Ves, Daled) which are (Nun, Resh, Nun Sophit נפש רוח נשמה), e.g., (Zayin Vov, Nun Sophit  זעיר ונוקבהare the (Ches, Nun, Ves חנ״ב) which is the Neshamah Veruach of the Nefesh, and Daas Dedaat is Yaakov Veleah.

 

(6.) So Daat anywhere it is mentioned refers to the Zeir of that Bechinah.

 

(7.) So just like Zeir had its Katnut (which is the (Vov, Kuf) וו קיצואות 6 ספירות ) and then there was added Gadlus, so there are 2 Bechinos in Daat - Daat Elyon which is (Chof, Ches, Ves) and Daat Tachton.

 

Druch Haadaat of Rabbi Chayim Vitaal

(1.) Amar Chayim Vital Hineni Mechaber Drush Yakar Harn Beinyan Hadaat vezolat zeto <???> Hakadosh. Ein Shum Yediah Sharshit beinyahn (Hey, Yud, Mem Sophit)

 

(2.) Know that even though it is always  mentioned 10 sephirot they are actually only 5, and each sephirah is one partzuf, and they are arich anpin, abah veimah, vzeir venukvah.

 

(3.) Each partzuf has 10 midot but (zayin, vov, nun sophit) where created chasadim zeir had only (ches, gimel, tof) (nun, hei, yud) and nukvah had only malchus.

 

(4.) Zeir is the sephirah of daas dechasidim of atzilut and is chachmah of sephirat haddaat. (i.e. deah of atzilut has (ches, bes, daled). It's chachmah is zeir, its binah nukvah. Its daat is Yakov Veleah.)

 

(5.) The daat in every place is zayir of that bechinah.

 

(6.) Daat of gadlus zeman of (zayin, aleph) is the nefesh of the neshamah and is divided into ((ches, ves, daled) shebedaas) daas elyon and (zayin, tof)) daas tachton shebedaas.

 

(9.) I didn't hear the drashah habar mitzvah of Nachman Yitzchak (nun, yud) but I do have one comment about what he told me afterwards. He said, by tefilin the mochin are nimshach to the midot. I really don't know what he means, for if we are talking about tefilin shel yad the mochin are nimshachim to nukvah of (zayin, aleph). So I suppose he means the tefilin shel rosh but if that's what he meant then its only the chitzoniyut of (alef, ves, yud, ayin) if the chitzoniyut of atzilut and there it’s to all 5 partzufim (i'm assuming he meant the midot of (zayin aleph) and then which midot the midot of the (yud, samech) hachitzonum) or the (yud, samech) haemtzayim or (yud, samech) hapnimim) if he meant the midot of  nukvah there is a problem because its mamshich only a reshimu of the mochin to nukvah (not the mamash mochin) see pei ves hamoch (ayin ches) sin ledat hamochin. [Maybe ask nachman yitzchak what he meant because I can't figure it out att all.]

 

Actually, tefilah is mamshich the mochin to (zayin, aleph)

Appendix 2

 

Spinoza's Proof OF GOD

 

Existence belongs to the nature of substance since substance cannot be produced by anything external [ie. it exists in itself and is self producing]. For in the universe nothing is granted, save substances and their modifications[i.e., things which cause themselves or things which don't] (since everything which exists, exists either in itself or in something else.)[Substance is that which is in itself, and is conceived through itself in other words, that of which a conception can be formed independently of any other conception.]

 

Now by the fact that there cannot exist in the universe two or more substances having the same nature or attribute.

 

[Proof. --If several distinct substances be granted, they must be distinguished one from the other, either by the difference of their inner essences, or by the difference of their modifications (Prop. iv.). If only by the difference of their essences, it will be granted that there cannot be more than one with an identical essence. If by the difference of their modifications--as substance is naturally prior to its modifications (Prop. i.),--it follows that setting the modifications aside, and considering substance in itself, that is truly (Def. iii. and vi.), there cannot be conceived one substance different from another,--that is (by Prop. iv.), there cannot be granted several substances, but one substance only.Q.E.D.] substance cannot be produced by another substance, therefore it cannot be produced by anything external itself. Q. E. D. This is shown still more readily by the absurdity of the contradictory. For, if substance be produced by an external cause, the knowledge of it would depend on the knowledge of its cause (Ax. iv.)[IV. The knowledge of an effect depends on and involves the knowledge of a cause.] and (by Def. iii.) it would itself not be substance.], it must, therefore, be its own cause--that is, its essence necessarily involves existence, or existence belongs to its nature. Q.E.D.

 

PROP. XI. God, or substance, consisting of infinite attributes[i.e., essential characteristics][each eternal and each must exist], necessarily exists.exist and must be eternal.

 

Proof. --If this be denied, conceive, if possible, that God does not exist: then his essence does not involve existence. But this  is absurd since existence belongs to the nature of substance. Therefore God necessarily exists. [ By God, I mean a being absolutely infinite--that is, a substance consisting in infinite  inner essences, each of which is self causing-or the reason for its own existence]

 

Another proof. --Of everything whatsoever a cause or reason must be assigned, either for its existence, or for its non-existence--e.g., if a triangle exist, a reason or cause must be granted for its existence if, on the contrary, it does not exist, a cause must also be granted, which prevents it from existing, or annuls its existence. This reason or cause must either be contained in the nature of the thing in question, or be external to it. For instance, the reason for the non-existence of a square circle is indicated in its nature, namely, because it would involve a contradiction. On the other hand, the existence of substance follows also solely from its nature, inasmuch as its nature involves existence. (See Prop. vii.)

But the reason for the existence of a triangle or a circle does not follow from the nature of those figures, but from the order of universal nature in extension. From the latter it must follow, either that a triangle necessarily exists, or that it is impossible that it should exist. So much is self-evident. It follows therefrom that a thing necessarily exists, if no cause or reason be granted which prevents its existence.
