If, then, no cause or reason can be given, which prevents the existence of God, or which destroys his existence, we must certainly conclude that he necessarily does exist.[Here Spinoza held like Descartes. Physics seems to bear this out.] If such a reason or cause should be given, it must either be drawn from the very nature of God, or be external to him--that is, drawn from another substance of another nature. For if it were of the same nature, God, by that very fact, would be admitted to exist. But substance of another nature could have nothing in common with God by the fact that two substances whose essences are different have nothing in common.], and therefore would be unable either to cause or to destroy his existence.

 

As, then, a reason or cause which would annul the divine existence cannot be drawn from anything external to the divine nature, such cause must, perforce, if God does not exist, be drawn from God's own nature, which would involve a contradiction. To make such an affirmation about a being absolutely infinite and supremely perfect, is absurd therefore, neither in the nature of God nor externally to his nature, can a cause or reason be assigned which would annul his existence. Therefore, God necessarily exists. Q.E.D.

 

Another proof.--The potentiality of non-existence is a negation of power, and contrariwise the potentiality of existence is a power, as is obvious. If, then, that which necessarily exists is nothing but finite beings, such finite beings are more powerful than a being absolutely infinite, which is obviously absurd therefore, either nothing exists, or else a being absolutely infinite necessarily exists also. Now we exist either in ourselves, or in something else which necessarily exists (see Ax. i. and Prop. vii.) Therefore a being absolutely infinite--in other words, God (Def. vi.)--necessarily exists.Q.E.D.

 

Note.--In this last proof, I have purposely shown God's existence a posteriori[external], so that the proof might be more easily followed, not because, from the same premises, God's existence does not follow a priori[internal and absolute]. For, as the potentiality of existence is a power, it follows that, in proportion as reality increases in the nature of a thing, so also will it increase its strength for existence. Therefore a being absolutely infinite, such as God, has from himself an absolutely infinite power of existence, and hence he does absolutely exist. Perhaps there will be many who will be unable to see the force of this proof, inasmuch as they are accustomed only to consider those things which flow from external causes. Of such things, they see that those which quickly come to pass--that is, quickly come into existence--quickly also disappear whereas they regard as more difficult of accomplishment--that is, not so easily brought into existence--those things which they conceive as more complicated.

 

However, to do away with this misconception, I need not here show the measure of truth in the proverb, “What comes quickly, goes quickly,” nor discuss whether, from the point of view of universal nature, all things are equally easy, or otherwise: I need only remark, that I am not here speaking of things, which come to pass through causes external to themselves, but only of substances which (by Prop. vi.)[PROP. VI. One substance cannot be produced by another substance.] cannot be produced by any external cause. Things which are produced by external causes, whether they consist of many parts or few, owe whatsoever perfection or reality they possess solely to the efficacy of their external cause, and therefore their existence arises solely from the perfection of their external cause, not from their own. Contrariwise, whatsoever perfection is possessed by substance is due to no external cause wherefore the existence of substance must arise solely from its own nature, which is nothing else but its essence. Thus, the perfection of a thing does not annul its existence, but, on the contrary, asserts it. Imperfection, on the other hand, does annul it therefore we cannot be more certain of the existence of anything, than of the existence of a being absolutely infinite or perfect--that is, of God. For inasmuch as his essence excludes all imperfection, and involves absolute perfection, all cause for doubt concerning his existence is done away, and the utmost certainty on the question is given. This, I think, will be evident to every moderately attentive reader.

 

 

GLOSSARY

13 principles of faith

13 principles organized by the Rambam that define Judaism. These principles are from the Talmud but the Rambam organizes and clarifies them.

 

Adam Kadmon

The region above Emanation. It is associated with the crown on top of the yud of the divine name.

 

Baal Ha Tanya

 Rabbi Shneur Zalman of Liadi. A disciple of the Magid of Mezritch.

 

Baba Sali

Rabbi Israel Abuchatzeira, a Kabbalist of the Twentieth century, great grand-son of Rabbi Shmuel Abuchatzeira, a disciple of Rabbi Chayim Vital.

 

Banach space

A  normed space that is complete.Any normed space can be made into  a Banach space by completing it. Complete means every fundamental sequence has a limit.It is like having an outside hull. A linear space is called normed if  for every element there is associated a real number [a distance more than or equal to zero] and it has these basic qualities  ||only if , , even if a is complex:


 

The bars mean the distance.

Binomial

 

Breaking of the vessels

שבירת הכלים הוא מושג יסודי בקבלה, מעשה בריאת העולמות וכלל סידורם מעליון לתחתון לפי דרגות התכונות האלוהיות המכונות ספירות, תוך הפיכת עולם האצילות שבו אירע לדרגה העליונה בארבעת עולמות היסוד הרוחניים, וכן כיסוד הנדרש והמחויב להשתלשלות בריאת העולם הגשמי. המושג הופיע לראשונה אצל האר"י.

 

The shattering of the vessels is a functional concept in Kabbalah, the process of the creation and ordering from higher to lower according to the ranks of the worlds, the godly qualities that are called sephirot through turning over of the world in which appeared in the higher worlds

Emanation

The highest of the four worlds. The are from top to bottom Emanation Creation Formation and the Physical universe… It is associated with the yud of the Divine Name.

 

Cantors diagonal argument. Take the list of all the real numbers between 0 and 1. Go down the diagonal and change every digit by one. Put a decimal place in front of the number you get. Now, this number is different than the first one because it has a different first digit. It is different than the second because it has a different second digit,... So you found a real number between 0 and 1 not on the list of all real numbers between 0 and 1!!!

 

Chasidishe. Something related to the movement within Orthodox Judaism called Chasidus.

 

Chaya

The fourth highest level of the soul.

 

Empty space. Because of the compassion of God, He created the world. For he wanted to reveal his compassion, and there was no creation on whom would he have show his compassion. Therefore he made everything from the top of emanation to the center of the earth in for this purpose.”(Lekutai Moharan)

 

Guide

The guide for the perplexed by the Rambam.

 

Henkin sentence

A sentence in mathematical logic which asserts its own validity. In fact it is always valid.

 

Higgs Field

It refers to a field that transfers energy into matter.

 

Hilbert space

In mathematics, Hilbert spaces (named after David Hilbert) allow generalizing the methods of linear algebra and calculus from (finite-dimensional) Euclidean vector spaces to spaces that may be infinite-dimensional. Hilbert spaces arise naturally and frequently in mathematics and physics, typically as function spaces. Formally, a Hilbert space is a vector space equipped with an inner product that defines a distance function for which the space is a complete metric space. — Wikipedia

 

Kabbalah

The esoteric literature of the Torah.

Klipat noga

The outer shell that is a mixture of good and evil. It is associated withe tree of Knowledge of good and evil.

Klipot

The Outer Husks [The Evil Side]

 

Lekutai Moharan

The Collected Teachings of Rabbi Nachman. The major book of Rabbi Nachman from Breslov. A great grandson of the Baal Shem Tov HaKadosh.

 

Metric space

The distance between two points is more than or equal to zero.This isn't the same as Banach space where distance is associated with each single element.

 

Matrix. An array of numbers each representing the value of a variable, these variables can be algebraic but in this book I mean the term to be applied to spiritual variables. And variable equations in the creation.

 

Mitzvot. The 613 commandments of the Old Testament.

 

Raisha delo isyada. The head that is not known, i.e., the highest point of the crown of emanation.

 

R-L-C Circuit. An electric circuit that contains resistance, inductance, and a capacitor.

 

Rambam. Rabbi Moses Maimonides

 

Sephirot. Divine traits specified in the verse To You O Lord is the Greatness and the Power and the Beauty and the Victory and the Splendor, for all that is in the heavens and the earth, to you is the rulership and the sovereignty to all to the top (Chronicles 1, chapter 29).

 

Sephiros deYosher. The straight sephirot. When the world was created first God had to make spiritual space-time which would be empty of his Infinite light so that there would be a place for creation. Then his drew into it a ray of His light [the light of the name 52] which after it had progressed a bit turned a right angle to circle the empty space like an electron in a cyclotron indicating that first light was charged. Then it went down a bit more and circled again in this manner until ten circular sephirot were created. Then He drew the light of the name 45 into the empty space and it came down and became in the form of a person. Now in those higher worlds which are above Emanation there is no concept of vessels or form and the use of these words is just to give us some vague idea of what was going on up there.

 

Shemita opinion. The opinion of Rabbi Issac of Akko and Rabbi Abulafia and other Kabbalists of the late middle Ages. They say that the world goes in cycles of creation every 7000 years and that this is the fourth of such cycles. If you add to that the other opinion of rabbi Issac of Akko the each day of these cycles is a day of God which is 1000 of our years you get the age of the world to be about ten billion years.

 

Schwarzschild Radius. The region of a black hole from which no light can escape.

 

Teffilin. Phylacteries

 

Tensor. A tool to measure mass-energy, energy density and momentum at any point in space time

 

The Alter From Slobodka. One of the Sages of the Musar Movement

 

The Shemita opinion. That this 7000 year period is just one of several that came before which is the opinion of R. Issac from Akko,  Rabbi Abulafia etc., this was used by the Igeret Israel to explain dinosaurs. But Breslovers think Rabbi Nachman didn't hold from this, but I think Rabbi Nachman was objecting to another shemita opinion that each 450 years in our time represents a different sepherah which the Baal Hatanya held from, but not the Reshash, for he divides the years into cycles of 10, so to him each 100 years is a complete cycle, however the Rabbi Chayim Ben Atar seems to have held from the seven seven option since he divides a persons life into cycles of seven years seven years etc.

 

Somehow I remember the Rashash going according to the shemita for the eons of the world.

 

Super Numbers. Numbers that must exist if we add a sixth axiom to TNT, i.e., that it is not true that for all “a” (0+a) = a. It turns out with this that we have one axiom that says all natural numbers have a certain property and another which says there are numbers which do have it. Thus we have a number/s that if you add a zero to them come out different.

 

Tikunim of Rabbi Moshe Chayim Lutzato.A book by Rabbi Lutzato similar to the Tikunai HaZohar of Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai.

 

Torah. The Five Books of Moses and the Oral Law which was also handed down to Moses at Mount Sinai.

TNT.TypographicalNumber Theory.

 

Tzadikim. Jewish saints

 

Yidishkeit. Orthodox Judaism

 

Yechida. The highest level of the five levels of the soul.

Yud. The tenth letter of the Hebrew alphabet

 

Zohar. The major work of Kabbalah by Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai.

[1] But we can change the type of infinity from a null to a higher type in the Cantor hierarchy of infinities.

[2] However even though Godel proved that every closed system must be incomplete, he still proved the existence of God.

[3]However the son of the Baal Ha Tanya said that one still needs to draw the light into the knowledge of the vessels (i.e., by the learning of the Eitz Chayim) otherwise the light just breaks one's vessels.

[4] This may imply that in regards to religious vs. non-religious Jews, that it is forbidden to change to the others side, though one may and probably should learn from them.

 

[5] A visual way to understand this is thus: the position of  one in religion is graphed on the y axis, and on the x axis there is the degree to which one is good or evil.

 

[6] Hebrew: Rishonim

[7] This may explain why communism, which was applied with force, resulted in an age of terror for the Russians.

[8] This way both the name of 45 and the name of 63 will arise and become included in the name of 72.

[9] Perhaps other universes were created in order to fill other lacks?

[10] This is based on the Ramchal, the beginning of the Eitz Chayim and the Lekutei Maharan, but with a bit of integration.

 

[11] A pentode is an electronic device having five active electrodes. (Wikipedia)

[12] In mathematical logic, the Peano axioms, also known as the Dedekind–Peano axioms or the Peano postulates, are axioms for the natural numbers presented by the 19th century Italian mathematician Giuseppe Peano. These axioms have been used nearly unchanged in a number of metamathematical investigations, including research into fundamental questions of whether number theory is consistent and complete. -- Wikipedia

[13] An Euler spiral is a curve whose curvature changes linearly with its curve length (the curvature of a circular curve is equal to the reciprocal of the radius). Euler spirals are also commonly referred to as spiros, clothoids, or Cornu spirals. -- Wikipedia

[14] And if the whole congregation of Israel shall err, the thing being hid from the eyes of the assembly, and do any of the things which the LORD hath commanded not to be done, and are guilty: — machon mamre translation

[15]Acts 9:10

 [MR1]                          Chapter 3  [MR1]

                    THE SONG OF PHILOSOPHY

[1] The purpose of the creation of the world is the revelation of the oneness of God. This is accomplished by the system imbedded in the nature of the world, "trait for trait" . (By the rewarding of good and truth and punishment of evil is revealed the oneness of God.) This happens on every level or in every society, in every level of existence. This is called the 'sifting' out of the bad and bringing up the good to be included in the oneness of God. The idea of the creation of man is for someone for God to do good to. For there was a basic lack in the divine traits before the world was created. That lack was not in the traits themselves but in royalty of the infinite one i.e. in the revelation of the traits. So God had to create man to have someone to do well too. And the highest good are God himself. But how can man have any connection with God himself? So God created free-will so man could chose God. (This by choosing good from evil.) And thus have a connection with God. Based on his own deeds and words and thoughts and desire, not based on a free hand out which is in itself on the level of royalty which needs to receive and that was the problem in the first place. But now man has united royalty with the higher trait of giving by choosing God and not needing a free-handout for his reward of the light of God by his merits. This is based on the Ramchal, the beginning of the Eitz Chayim and the Lekutei Moharan, but with a bit of integration. The idea is that God fills all worlds and surrounds all worlds so one must unite the sparks of holiness in everything with the infinite presence of God himself by choosing God in everything he does says or thinks or desires and thus uniting himself and all creation with God. When one is united with God than he can too create Godliness and this is the first commandment in the Torah of being fruitful and to multiply, and children and ideas, and music. [But why wasn't man created in a way that he could receive good without doing good? Perhaps in another universe this is the case, but here it seems we were to be like God in the way of choosing. Perhaps there are infinite universes and this is the universe of choise.In other universes there may be other traits.]

 

[2] The trait of "the measure that one gives is the measure he receives" is the "sifting" out of the bad and bringing up the good to be included in the oneness of God. But from this deterministic principle results infinite chaos depending on every slight variation in events. The end result of good being rewarded doesn't happen until the next world where the oneness of God is revealed. How the chaos here results in the oneness there is not known in detail. But the sages said that the good suffer in this world the punishment for their sin's which they have done in this life time or in previous life times, so that when they get to the next world they can receive the undiluted light of God with their loved ones.

 

[3] The idea of the creation of man is for someone for God to do good to. "Because of the compassion of God, He created the world. For he wanted to reveal His compassion, and there was no creation, on whom would He have to show his compassion. Therefore he made everything from the top of emanation to the centre of the earth for this purpose" (-Lekutai Moharan) for there was a basic lack in the Divine traits before the world was created, the lack of the revelation of their unity. [I.e. As Hegel said that each trait implies its opposite.] There was a different lack in the perfection of each trait in itself which was that as long as is hasn't been used, it is lacking the quality of being used. (Perhaps other universes were created in order to fill other lacks?) [This assumes the Divine traits weren't creations, but essential aspects of God, like Goodness and Wisdom.] To correct these two lacks were created the world of the circular sepherot and the world of the straight sepherot. So God had to create man (who includes in himself all the higher sepherot) in order to have someone to do good to. And the highest good is God himself.

But this idea seems to be different from the idea of revelation of the oneness of God.

 

[4] How can man have any connection with God himself? God therefore created freewill so man could choose God (this by choosing good from evil) and thus have a connection with God based on his own deeds and words and thoughts and desire, not based on a free handout which is in itself on the level of royalty which needs to receive and that was the problem in the first place. But now men has united royalty with the higher trait of giving by choosing God and not needing a free-handout for his reward of the light of the light of God are by his own merits. This is based on the Ramchal, the beginning of the Eitz Chayim and the Lekutei Moharan, but with a bit of integration.but then why not make man in a way he could receive infinite good while being finite?This probably relatesto the fact that mankind is not really created. Only God exists since he is existence in itself and man only exists in as much as that divine existence includes him and sustains the illusion of sepatness.But when one choosses God the illusion disaoiiears.

 

[5] The idea is that God fills all worlds and surrounds all worlds and so one must unite the sparks of holiness in everything with the infinite presence of God Himself by choosing God in everything he does says or thinks or desires and thus uniting himself and all creation with God. When one is united with God then he too can create Godliness and this is the first commandment in the Torah of being fruitful and to multiply, in children and ideas, and music.

 

[6] Pleasure is on the level of the tree of knowledge of good and evil and therefore not good or bad in itself but dependent on what one uses it for. If one brings up the sparks of holiness in that pleasure into holiness, he himself goes up and the evil falls. Just saying a blessing has nothing to do with this. It depends a lot on how he raises the children. If it's food it depends on what one does with the energy. Pleasure for the sake of pleasure remains on the original level and it falls into evil and becomes evil itself. Pleasure however for the sake of God and done with attachment to God is like a sacrifice, and is on a very holy level.

 

[7] One problem with Spinoza is he is totally deterministic and doesn't incorporate the uncertainty principle in his philosophy or his idea of the personality. However the idea of a mathematical approach to philosophy and to personality is good, but not the Euclidian approach, rather an approach based on Kabbalah and Non-Euclidian geometry -because no one personality consists of straight lines rather curved relativistic space and time. Rabbi Nachman has already mentioned this (Lekutai Moharan Vol.1, Chap.49) but it still needs to be developed. Anyway Spinoza's approach which is consistent has to be incomplete as all formal systems are.

 

[8] Free thought is important, for ideas can't flow in a constricted vessel. But logic (in it's purest form) limits free thought. Similarly Revelation also limits free thought, for there are things beyond the comprehension of the mind that only revelation can reveal. Reason and revelation are the two outer vessels that contain free thought corresponding to Chaya and Yechida, the two outer fields surrounding and protecting a person. Logic and the heart must work together but when there is a disagreement, then one of them is wrong. In that case reason reigns in the physical universe and intuition reigns in the spiritual universe. The dichotomy of universities and religion (reason and revelation) is the divergence between chaos and correction, and the goal is to bring the light of chaos into the vessels of correction. Rabbi Nachman and the Rambam disagreed whether logic is subjected to revelation or vice-versa, but in fact there is no disagreement. Each has its own area where is qualified to judge.

 

[9] "Things of the spirit can be revealed only by the spirit."   However, since there is nothing but God and He permeates and is unified with the physical and spiritual universe so God's presence in the physical universe is subject to logical proof which is what Spinoza does. But he can't go beyond that into the spiritual realm which works with mathematical principles but isn't subject to proof. That is the result of the original condensing in which God removed the revelation and proof of his presence from the empty space and only as we progress through time does God reveal his presence and proof of his Presence one level at a time, as Rabbi Nachman comments on the empty space and relates levels of revelation to the outer makifim (field's) in which one level at a time enters humanity. So at least Spinoza got the first step.

 

[10] "It takes many years of sifting through false teachers to find a wise one. Don't be so fast to give up the wise teachers of history for they have been sifted from millions of false ones and their teachings have stood the test of the ages."-Greenfield. The Bible the Sutras, the Talmud, Reason and Science may seem to contradict but in fact each sees a different aspect of and points to the same truth. Each were digging up the building blocks of the final structure. (Not to say that the structure is ever finished) Some people are content to poke around the stones, and others to try to knock down someone else's stone I think it is wiser to assemble them into one great building and then to ride the elevator to the top to see further.

 

[11] Rabbi Isaac Luria says that the generations from Adam to Noah were evil and so were reborn at the time of the flood to receive their punishment, in this world. Similarly the generations before the dispersion and the tower of Babylon. Similarly the generations before the destruction of the first Temple. And similarly the generations before the Holocaust.

 

 

[12] The contradiction between absolute knowledge and free-will is that God knows what one will choose not just from the future but from now (I.e. not just because He knows the future). This problem I once wanted to answer thus: One can choose what he wants, but God knows what he will choose. The problem with this answer is the truth value of that knowledge. This is really the sea battle problem. Take a look at these two statements: There will be a sea battle tomorrow. There will not be a sea battle tomorrow. Clearly one is right and the other wrong. If we say the past is unchangeable the truth of one of these statements is unchangeable.

Now we can say the past is changeable and get out of all these problems.

or we can say time is a loop and there is no past. It is future. And thus the past is changeable in the next time cycle. Or we can go with probabilities i.e. that everything is simply probability waves.ie that everything is at present neither true nor false but only probability.

This is not the same as quantum mechanics which says things are probability waves until they are resolved into one thing or the other.

 But can this resolution go backwards? Take matter or energy and unreslove it into waves. Of course. But then can we take a present wave and unresolve it in the past into matter? If time is reversible then yes. That leads me to think that in fact everything has an absolute true or false value right now. And that the possibility now of a true statement about the future changing its value implies a

Meta time [strange loop again]. And in fact who says present is like past or future. Are not the past and future literally non existent right now? And in fact all time is one predicate used by physicists to describe things. But in Aristotle we find ten predicates. Of course physicists don�t ignore them but we simply don't know what place in reality most of them have . But they may have a place.

 

 

 

[13] Ideas are wave functions that have all the characteristics of a quantum wave. [This includes the property of the probability wave that travels with the idea. Thus with any idea one needs to evaluate the probability that goes with it.] That's why it's important not to think about your enemies badly so that yours and their wave function doesn't mutually interfere and just darkness is left. Don't send your waves in that direction at all, for their waves can't bother yours at all unless you do.

 

[14] The uncertainty principle applies to all aspects of life and is the root of free will. An example is the conflict between freedom of thought (thinking for yourself) and listening to the wise. We find in the Torah itself this conflict, for even though we are supposed to listen to the Sanhedrin, still there is a whole section of the Torah which describes the types of sacrifice which must be brought when the Sanhedrin makes a mistake. And the Sages say that if one knew they were wrong, yet still acted on their opinion, he is responsible for his own actions.

 

[15] Ideas rotating around a common axis will give off its rest energy and energy of motion in the form of idea waves. That is the power the works of philosophy of Spinoza who takes a few basic axioms and revolves them around each other until a whole work evolves out of it which represents the energy of motion for after Spinoza was done, the idea's implications of the axioms were fixed in idea space. However, the rest energy continues to affect a larger circumference of people.

 

[16] The book Madragas HaAdam [The Level of Man] created a vast mass movements but that movement disappeared in one generation because it was built on one idea alone -absolute trust in God. That is a great idea but doesn't give off much energy since it rotates on its own axis, not around another major idea. That is the same problem with Rav Shick's books based only on the principle that nothing exists besides God which is also good but again nothing comes of it because it is only one axiom. (Most Christian books I've seen have the same problem except for Thomas Aquinas, who basically does the same thing as Spinoza.) Rabbi Nachman creates in every individual chapter a revolving system, and all the systems revolve around a common set of basic axioms. I believe that the Bible represents one revolving system (on one axis God, and the basic 13 axioms of faith) and that is the reason for their power. [Rabbi Nachman says a person should have three points, the teacher, his friend, and himself.]

  God created the world based on two principles, chaos and order, which stem from the Divine names, 63 and 45. The purpose of creation is to integrate them and bring them up to the name 72.

 

[17] The will to truth is to understand something not based on any formula. It is examination by a specific formula which has no bearing on the idea itself. It is examination from a different viewpoint than that of the idea's maker and cannot do (accomplish) anything. It is insensitivity to the idea. It is lack of understanding. [For example] to examine myself from an entirely psychological and rational point of view is not to understand myself.

[18] a) Assuming that a persons essence is always good and that he can always choose what course of action he will take, then the closer he gets to his soul, the more the soul will control his will. And the more control the soul will have over the will.

  b) But true thinkers think with concepts and ideas with no root either in self or words or in logic. Pure thinking is just a free interplay of concepts between the mind and the soul with only intuition used to choose the good from the bad. If the ideas truly come from the soul then they will eventually fit into the world of logic either by the one who though it. Or the idea will die until another time to be given birth by another mind. Ideas in this form are truly logical and not just rational.

c) Logical thinking results in a creation of value or of no value depending on the path of the logic taken by the mind. Many paths may seem logical to the mind with only one resulting in some valid result. To find that path one needs the help of the soul.

 

[19] Zeno's proof that there is no motion is that, before an object can go any distance it has to go half that distance. And before it can go that much it has to go a half of the last amount. Thus by an infinite progression it is impossible to move since the object always has to travel an infinitesimal amount and infinitesimal amounts can't add up since you need an infinite amount of them to add up to anything.

  It has seemed to me in general to answer Zen's paradox to say that space is quantized. Just like there is no time below Plank time, there is no space past a certain point. However Calculus derives motion by reducing the distance of the motion down to an infinitely small amount and by this it derives the true equations of motion. So apparently there is a reality to an infinitesimal amount in the real world?

 

 

[20] We would think numbers are descriptions [predicates] of things and therefore not real in themselves. But tensors are also just the coefficients in front of a vector and are the most real of things since they are the invariant quantities that define basic physical reality.

So there is reason to believe the Pythagoreans got it right.

But we assume there is some soul or essence to people since they behave in certain ways i.e. they talk and walk etc. numbers also behave in different and very unique ways. Like the derivative of e is e. no other number does that etc. so it would be reasonable to say numbers also have a soul or essence, not that they themselves are the souls of everything else. But it could be that since the kabalah says numbers are in royalty of emanation that they are the soul of all physical things but that they themselves have a soul of some higher essence and a soul of a inner essence.

 

[21] in torah and Christian thought there is an absolute right and wrong. But does this define the meaning of our lives? i saw once in the talks of Joseph Isaac that every person has a particular destiny and meaning of his life.. But now the question is how does one discover the meaning of his life. There is no question to me that this was the main cause of the baal teshuva movement in America. But does following torah values in fact provide us with meaning? This can only be done by living our lives and making the best choices we can and hope that in this way the meaning and purpose will become clear. [This is not like existentialism in which there is no absolute right and wrong. here we have right and wrong but meaning and purpose for each individual differs. possibly right and wrong is a means to come to meaning — or the opposite.

 [MR2][20 Continued] So really we could have infinite levels of existence. I.e. existence itself may not be one thing. There could be infinite levels. And all these levels may be right here and now, not just in other universes. For instance math may be a sub level and below that there may be another level and so on.. Similarly there may be higher levels of existence of which we here are the cause. [MR2]

So when we say there is a first cause of existence, we may just be referring to the first starting level that precedes the physical universe by many levels. The kabalah perhaps hints to this when it talks about the previous shemita cycles of 7000 years each. [and each on is a day of Hashem which is thousand years.]

 

 

 

[21] Aristotle mentions some people that thought proof could be circular. He doesn't say how this works, but it is supposed to answer the problem of limiting the number of causes. I think the idea is thus:

The problem with cause and effect is that it is linear. Who says existence is linear? In fact in Physics we find all quantities that are linear have circular parallels.[matter -inertia, velocity angular velocity etc.]

So perhaps for any object to existence you need a bunch of causes to converge in one place. Maybe you need two causes or three or an infinite number of causes like the points on a circle. [This would correspond to the idea in Aristotle of an infinite number of principles in his metaphysics]

So from this we can understand that every bit of matter is the sum of a convergent series. [the probability wave which is a sum[a Fourier series] has to converge.] of course there are different types of convergence so perhaps and electron is only partially convergent

At any rate this reminds me of what a student at Hebrew university told me once in a conversation about how he was working on an idea of an electron being a singularity and I mentioned to him that in math there are a whole bunch of types of singularities. The one physicists refer to is only the first type. But this is the opposite of the idea here of an electron being a convergent series.

[22] A problem with cause and effect is that nothing is caused and complete. Everything is a probability wave. Anything may be found anywhere in the universe or may simply become a light beam at any time. So cause and effect is really incremental.

[23] The proof of Aristotle is two fold. First things need to be potential then actual. Proof is that both need a first cause to made things possibly exist and the actually exist. But here too we have Zeno's paradox. So you have to say the causes can be incremental. For just like motion could not exist unless there is incremental motion so existence could not exist unless there is incremental existence. But what is the bridge between incremental or infinitesimal existence and actual existence? For clearly infinitesimals can't add up. And an infinite number of points on a line still don�t make a continuous line. So there has to be some process bridging between infinitesimal and finite. That is integration in mathematics. But what is in the physical realm?
